This bairro never sleeps!. Great by day, even greater by night. Cultural, multicultural, free spirit, fun, offbeat, original, cool.... do i need to say more?
Lively. Great place to wander. Lots of fun at night, with plenty of bars to visit. Hilly and crowded, but with a fun atmosphere.

It is okay. We were there for a short visit and the streets were interesting. Lots of restaurants and bars. It is very touristy and we found the restauranteurs were all very pushy. We did find a good restaurant and had a good meal. If you are in Lisbon, you do want to visit the area but should go with an open mind and not have very high expectations.

Take the Tram. This is a very cool neighborhood to wander around in and check out. Ride Tram 28 through the area to get a sense of things. Also check out the park at the last tram stop. Nice slice of local life.

Good and lively . The mix of bars and restaurants is good. Different types of bars available such as live music. Everyone drinks in the streets. Ultimately. If you want to get drunk, Bairro Alto is the place for you.
Nice part. A lot of ups and downs you have to walk to enjoy this neibourhood. Do recommend it for those in search of great yet local restaurants - its full of it!
Super Neighborhood. We stayed and loved the food and bars in this part of this scenic city. A must to visit. Excellent music and DJs in this part of town.
Cool area. Lots to see. Numerous shows and restaurants. Felt safe and the walking can be tricky. Wear comfortable shoes. Recommend.

City break with a difference . Fabulous city, very underrated, clean , friendly and safe , we loved it. We walked and used the tram on them first day , sat in the sun at lovely coffee shops and restaurants , the coffee and fresh pastries were delicious and if you keep out of main squares very cheap. Second day we hired bikes for two days and cycled the designated paths all along the coast . You can catch a ferry for around a pound with your bike across to the other side of Lisbon, wow the beaches there are amazing, a real surfers paradise. You can get a big glass of wine for £1.20 , a great meal for a fiver. I will definitely return , in my opinion it knocks spots of Barcelona

Best in evening, lots of people, great food choices!. This is one of the best areas to wander in the evening, although fun in daytime on the weekend. Be prepared for the crowds at certain times, but this is what makes the area fun. Lots of restaurants, pubs and shops. Prices are from reasonable to pricey, depending on what type of food you want to try. Great place to try a variety of Portuguese foods. Very hilly as you can see by the pictures. You can ride the trolleys, but they do get crowded with tourists and I assume locals using them as well. Overall just fun to wander and hang out!
take a walk and relax!. Every corner, every little street is really amazing! Rest at daytime in little cafés and at night in the bars, it won't be boring!

Get you walking shoes on - it's hilly!!. We first went to Bairro Alto by tram and at some points the ups and downs in this area make it feel like a roller coater. We also walked Bairro Alto, the hills aren't the only hinderence, the pavements are cobbled and slippy. That said, it's a must
Love the place. Beautiful colorful area of Lisbon! It has a very good energy, as if you were at home or in a very familiar place! Authentic houses, little streets, old trams , load of charm!

Winding side streets. Stopped here off the sightseeing bus. It's old world Lisbon with side streets full of coffee shops, restaurants and local shops. You can spend hours just getting lost in the side streets. Only about 25-30 minutes walk back to Marques de Pombal.

Right place if you wanna drink. This bairro is famous for the sheer quantity of its locals, most of them selling cheap booze, being it beer or shots.The target audience are especially foreign young people, like Erasmus students.Expect to see drunks and litter on its narrow streets after 1am.

Great Mix. Perfect for any first-time visitors with a wonderful mix of old & new restaurants, panoramic views & beautiful artsy extras. Just spent the whole afternoon wondering around...but don't visit in the middle of the day because you will get very exhausted!

Tom Bridge . Fabulous place to explore . Lovely old narrow streets full of bars , cafes and restaurants . We found simplesmente pizza bar . Best pizza ever and a great atmosphere . Definitely worth a visit .

Wonderful Mix. Wonderful Mix of panoramic sites, old and new restaurants and bars, boutiques from local designers and explore the reconstruction and inovation of architecture presented everywhere. In case you like Fado many choices available.

Great for new exploration. I spent a day wandering Bairro Alto. If you don't mind walking up and down, you'll have a great time. Like Chiado, there is many a magic moment to be seen, caught or written about. If you have a camera in hand you'll have a ball. Feeling lazy? Get a tram up the hill. Feeling hungry? There's many a cafe hosting Pasta de Nata behind their windows. Amazing facades all around, tiles here there and everywhere. Sip on an espresso and people watch, there's no lack of curious things happening on the street. Highly recommended.

The best place to discover fado. Known as Bronx of the Lisbon, this neighborhood was once build for working class workers, during the dictatorship filled up with prostitutes, and later on was refurnished by the students. Now it is the heart of Lisbon’s night life, where you can find dozens of the bars, street venders and crowds of people thirsty for beer and fado music.
Enjoy the atmosphere.. This area is full of arty shops,hilly streets,(use the trams),chic shops,little bars and galleries. Lovely view from the Miradouro de Santa Catarina
Most Enjoyable. I have been reading what others have to say , and I totally agree , well Worth the visit and most enjoyable

head here for a night of fun !. lovely cobbled streets full of little bars and restaurants , place was buzzing on a fri night , had a great night in a little wine bar , tables got put away and we danced till dawn !

Fascinating place. We had intended to stay in this area when we visited Lisbon, but waited too long and the place we wanted to book was full. But, we did manage to tour through the neighborhood, and while it is teeming with character, (one could spend their entire time absorbing up the culture on your doorstep), it is not the easiest place to get around on foot, what with all the hills, narrow streets and cobblestones

Amazing place!. I just love all about Lisbon, the trams, the sidewalks, the coffee shops, the water front view, the people and the food... if you go to Europe and do not go to Lisbon... then you did not go... (old saying).... 100% recommended.....

Lovely area. Picturesque and great restaurants & bars. A must in Lisbon. Get lost just wandering around the small streets and discover bars, shops and restaurants offering excellent drink, products and food. A hidden treasure around every corner. My favourite area during a week long trip. Use Bacha Chiado tube station.

Very Scenic. I'd say that this is one of the best neighborhoods to stay in while visiting Portugal if you're looking t take great pictures or if you're interested in the nightlife. I stayed in an Air B&B off the Main Street and was so amazed by the scenic view point. You see most of the city and can even see the San Jorge Castle in the distance. The infamous street/hill with the old yellow trams is here too. It's an easy hill going down, but brutal going up. Take your time and bring water!
Very cosy area. Nice to walk around, always something to see and to do. Step into a local bar and order a simple but always good coffee!!
Old world. a lot of hills, great views, if you like old world this is it. The food was to die for and I've been around Europe.

Bustling nightlife. We spent the second half of our Lisbon trip in Bairro Alto. I highly recommend the British Bar - great atmosphere and fantastic beers! If you stay in this area, ask for a higher level room or you will get street noise well into the AM. This is the place to stay if you're into night life and bar hopping. Fun place, lots of little shops and restaurants. Spend a day (or night) here.

Great Place to Explore. There are lots of clothing stores, restaurants, bars and museums located throughout this hilly neighbourhood. It is fun to explore the narrow streets. You may end up in a church, in a small taverna or at a lookout having a beer and watching the sunset. Great place.

Good night ouy. Had read a lot about the area before we actually travelled there. Was not at all disappointed. Took slot of energy and stamina to walk up there but the views were absolutely breath taking. A must when visiting Lisbon!
Lively area with nightlife. This part of the old town has several narrow cobbled streets to explore with lots of restaurants and bars.

A pleasant walk with good views.. This is a pleasant neighbourhood to walk through and there are good views over the city. If you have time visit the Port Institute and simple some of their vintages. Solar do Vinho do Port. You can also buy excellent Douro wines here. This institute is located very close the tram stop.

Great walking experience of Lisbon.. Because its the higher up neighborhood the views are great. I love this city. Safe, beautiful and family friendly. Also, lots of good restaurants. Some of these restaurants offer fado music, which I learned to love during my visit.

Decent . Loads of small individual bars and fast food places. Gets pretty busy post 1am. The popular places get really rammed so be prepared to barge ur way through to get to the bar and around the place.
Pitoresque. Narrow streets, great atmosphere.. Didnt plan anything. Just strolled. Chilly weather in February. Lots of great small shops to visit. Area is in pretty bad shape but safe.

Lovely area with boutiques, bars and restaurants. Although some buildings were not occupied, there is enough places to browse, eat and drink in this lovely old area. I'd return to try a lot of these places out if I return to Lisbon.

Amazing castle. The view is fantastic. We spent there 3 hours but we was really slow and we was enjoying in the nature. Birds were singing the song and we been also in some dark room where we could spy on hole city ....it was fantastic because they had like "live camera" at that time.
Always something to see and do!. I travelled here alone and loved that there was always something to do and see and it was so relaxed, bright and colourful and interesting!

Great night out. The Bairro Alto district of Lisbon is the best place to experience the city's nightlife. You'll find many small bars and clubs right next to one another, and they're all different in their own unique way. The bars are relatively small, therefore a lot of people just go in to buy their drinks, then drink together in the streets. It's an overall really cool atmosphere! Only downside is that there are many people who walk around the street trying to sell you drugs, but they aren't pushy, and will leave you alone if you just tell them you're not interested.

Perfect for a fun night. So let's get the negatives out of the way. As in any city nightlife I've been to you will be offered drugs, a polite no and those selling left us alone. We wanted a nice meal, some live music and a couple of drinks. We went slightly wrong on the restaurant sadly but the live music bar we went to was fantastic and the bar we visited afterwards was so fun. A really fun place to come (in flat shoes) if you want a fun evening.

Really disappointing. Two friends and I headed out for 3 night break in Lisbon in mid February. We stayed at a hostel right in the middle of the Bairro Alto area which we hoped would give us a good choice of restaurants and bars to choose from. What we actually got was constantly hassled by drug dealers in full view of the police who didn't seem bothered at all. When I say hassled we must have been asked a hundred times over the 3 days! The bars were brash and largely empty (time of year possibly).

A great little restaurant close to the Elevador.. This is a delightful area of LIsbon, and the three minute ride on the elevador leads to a lovely lookout area with some delightful adjoining restaurants. We went twice to Decadente which was a lovely eclectic olde worlde place with excellent food and friendly staff.

You can wander here for days. We DID wander here for days - in the rain. Doesn't matter. The area is full of character and theres always a cup of coffee and a nata (you have to try these) somewhere close.
Pretty Downtown. As pretty as it can get - tight streets with vehicles, trams, people and cobbled roads. Loads of great local food options all around.

Great night out. Loads of pubs, restaurants, great music, many different types, jazz, Brazilian, pop, r'n'b... You name it they have it. You can find live music as well. Great cheap drinks. Simply a must go area when you're in Lisbon.

Mourinho is not the only 'special one' from Portugal!!. We cannot recommend this Hotel highly enough. Every single member of staff were absolutely fantastic respectful and courteous. This was our first visit to Portugal and we were unsure what to expect from the people. We should not have worried, they are genuinely a warm and friendly race - not only in the Hotel but in the local shops and restaurants. The hotel, which was in a perfect central location for access to the old and new town, was clean and nicely laid out and decorated. The bathroom was enormous with all the facilities you could need. The bed was very comfortable with choices of bedding and pillows for those with allergies. We were particularly pleased with the downstairs bar which we were able to smoke in!! (weather was not great on our Valentines break). Only thing missing from the room offering was a coffee machine, but there was a fully stocked mini bar and bottled water provided free of charge. Our breakfast experience was also good, with options for light or cooked breakfast fresh from the kitchen. Our Valentines day evening meal was in the Hotel restaurant and the food wine and service were out of this world!! A very nice touch to be greeted by name when you said your room number. The staff are by far and away the best we have ever experienced for their good humour but at the same time respectful approach. We cannot remember individual names unfortunately but they were all keen to engage in conversation, especially about english football!! They recommended local restaurants which were just awesome, and really sealed our enjoyment of the whole visit. We had pre-booked a tuk-tuk from Eco-tours for a 'one to one' tour of the city. Our guide who was called Enrique, was so knowledgeable and spoke perfect English, he was patient and didnt rush us along, and we even got to sample some local delicacies and drinks. It was a day to remember and a city break we will long remember thanks to the genuine warmth and courtesy we received from all we met, but especially the wonderful staff at the Bairro Alto Hotel. One word of warning is that it is a very hilly City and some of the streets are very steep, this did not affect our enjoyment in any way, but if you have difficulty walking, it could be a challenge! In any case this location and Hotel are both highly recommended - dont think twice just book it!!
Vibrant lively part of Lisbon. Lots of delicious restaurants, bars and clubs. Something for everybody. Prepare for a late night. Beware of pick pockets. Keep your bag zipped up.

Short journey with good experiance. As I was staying at Rossio it was very convenient for me to have this ride with a unique Tram going uphill. The journey was short and was covered under Viva Viagem, a 24 hrs pass which covers all the journeys including metro and bus. The frequency of Tram was good and you can return after spending a few minutes at the nearby viewing point to take photos of beautiful city.

Melancholic view, streets full of History and people full of life!. The arty Oldtown of Lisboa is the perfect place to get lost exploring small streets with all of a kind shops and bars. Also to visit the places once in daytime and in the night will give you the exprience of visiting two worlds. If you come to Lisboa, bring some time and visit the different Parts of the Town. It is worth every step!

It's all about the nightlife. I love the Bairro Alto night scene! All of the small bars can't hold too many people so people mingle in the streets. If you're looking for a quiet stay, do not get a flat in the area because from midnight to 3am the streets are noisy. This place is really unique and you can find a beer for under 3 euros

One of the great views of the city. Nice panoramic view of the Alfama area of the city and the river. Just got back from Castle San Jorge and had a better view up there though of the same area and more
Party Party Party. It`s the heart and lungs of Lisbon party side. People all over the streets, decent prices, music , live music with local bands, good food . You won`t regret it .
Lovely neighborhood . Go up by tram, bring a good condition.Fantastic lookouts, calm sites, narrow streets, enjoyable bars, creative shops, nice streetart.
Tram 28. We took the Tram 28 on our first day in Lisbon. It was a great experience. Just remember to brace yourself :)

Two faces - day & night live.... In the day time descover this beautiful neighbourhood by walking in the empty streets... at night - the day doors close and the night doors open - and you are in the middle of lisbons sweetest confusion of people, sounds and nice party ambience...

You need to know what you are coming into.... The area is dead during the daytime. It comes alive at about 8:00 when places that look like ordinary houses suddenly morph into bars and clubs. The music goes on til 2:00 / 4:00 in the morning with lots of people milling about. I would be concerned about bringing a young family here as the buildings certainly aren't sound proof. After dark we were openly offered a range of drugs in the street (which we found a bit intimidating). That said it is a lively area with a good vibe. There are many small bars and restaurants, including numerous fado performances. You could probably visit 3 or 4 a night and not see them all during your stay.

Artistic district. Very nice to have an afrernoon walk There. It will be nice to end walk in restauradores to eat a dinner. It is a monument on its own - planty of azulejos on walls, narrow s treets, viewpoint - and you are feeling lukę you co me into Life of regular people.

Go there and feel the essentiality of Lisbon. If you love comforts and lux, Lisbon is not the right Town to be visited, because of its simplicity and essentiality. Here you can see and smell people who grill fish near home, you can have a romantic sight from the height, walk for a long time and climb the stairs, so comfortable shows are highly suggested! 👟

Hip District of Lisbon. What a cool neighborhood! Lots of bars and street side restaurants offering anything from very inexpensive and local to very posh fine dining. Everything is in walking distance.
We would stay in this area again when we come back to this beautiful city.

nice area interesting places and restaurants. Old narrow streets with very good restaurants ,nice view from the town and river from above by the pharmacie museum . You need to have good legs because all the streets are stiiff and paved. Good food . Did not go out in the night but heard from friends many places to listen to fado . I loved it . The tram 28 Take you every where aroud this are too.

Amazing place and definitely recommended. Don't miss this one on your trip to Lisbon.The place is full of small bars,pubs and restaurants with great value for money. Electrifying atmosphere with bars buzzing with people all around and playing live music. You can do your own pub crawl with so many options close by. Every pub is trying to match the price offered by others, so you can get shots for like 1 EUR as well. Quite a easy reach and on the way of the classic Tram 28E. You might be surprised with people asking you to buy drugs at the place, so beware of that. The streets are Cobbled and uneven with lots of highs and lows , which definitely demands easy walking shoes and not heels. But a must try place in the evenings, if you are planning Lisbon!!

Be careful. We visited this area both on Friday and Saturday night! We had been told it is the most popular area forFood and drink. We got a beautiful traditional Portuguese mealThe first night and then went to two other small bars for cocktails afterwards. Bairro Alto has over 250 bars and restaurants so there is lots of variety and great value for money. Be warned it is very hilly and the cobble is extremely uneven. Don't make my mistake and leave the heels at home it's better to be comfortable here.  To men in particular be prepared to be harassed by men selling cocaine and hash. On one narrow street on Saturday night my boyfriend was asked if he wanted to buy drugs 8 times. I wish we had been pre warnedOf that as it really turned us off the area and we left quickly after that.
Lovely area.Independent traditional shops.. Could have spent a lot more time in this area.Truely recommend taking the tram up and walking down to the central area.Gin Lovers is a must!!to visit.

Very Nice area... walking is tiring some.. It is a very nice and intresting area, lots of shops an Cafes, but the streets go up and down all the time, so walking is really challenging in this area. At night it is more suitable for the Bars seekers.

A place with character!!!. I loved Barrio Alto, it is a nice place to go for a walk, get to see the city and enjoy a warm cup of coffee and some pastry. There are also some beautiful little stores you can get some Lisbon objects.

Great part of the city!. Lisbon is a wonderful city to walk around in. At night this area comes alive with bars, restaurants and music. It is also a very lively and busy area that gets jammed with people. Great for nightlife just protect your valuables, pickpockets are plentiful in the crowds.

Amazing Pub Crawl. Had an amazing night here, the street was crowded and there was just a sense of everyone having a good time. Everyone seemed well behaved compared to the streets of London where everyone falls over drunk. Burgers at the kebab shop were great after a night of drinking.
Nice neibourghood. We spent 3 days and nights in this neibourghood. We enjoyed during the day the small streets and at night the Fado bars and cheep but really good restaurants..

Interesting place to walk around. Narrow streets with a collection of bars, shops and restaurants. Some of the streets are more interesting than others, and there is a mix of buildings, some derelict and abandoned, and others well looked after. Definitely worth a look.
For the atmosphere. I suppose one could not visit Lisbon without doing this! You will scream in the trams as they go along but it has to be done!!

Lively. Some good little bars and restaurants. Will me mad in season. Plenty of offers of Hash, Marijuana and Cocaine..!!!!
Had a good vibe though
Beautiful side of Lisbon. We stayed in Bairro Alto for 5 days and it is cozy and full of life. Just walking the streets is nice and one can spend the whole day like that.

Our favourite area. We ended up spending most of our holiday in this area. It's perfect cobbled streets, bohemian Portugal... scatterings of wine bars, tapas bars, artists residents, galleries and independent shops. A lovely area.
Stroll.. Get in good physical shape to conquer steep streets.Plenty of boutiques with good quality and fashionable clothes, cozy restaurants.Plenty of photo opportunities.

Peculiar. Beer is so cheap there.
There are too many to possibilities to enjoy and have too much.
Walk around, stop, take a beer and keep walking until your drink is over.
During the week it doesn't close so late, i'm sure about the time though.

Awesome place for all party goers . We reachd lisbon at night and started looking out for our hostel . While walking towards hostel, saw huge crowd with drinks glasses in their hands...Road was full at it's capacity ,atmosphere was mesmerising.And this place was bairro alto.Luckily our hostel was in the same area so we njoyd our both night stay at this area.Must visit place during night if you ever been to lisbon.

What else can one say?. What else can one say that hasn't already been said? Bairro Alto is a fantastic neighbourhood. Shopping, restaurants, nightlife, cafe's, hotels.... it has it all. Night life seems to be never ending - great for anyone who likes to stay up late, but if you want a quiet neighbourhood in the evening, you may want to look elsewhere. You will NOT run out of things to do here! Ive visited Lisbon many times, and NEVER go without a visit to Bairro Alto!
Evening escape. This neighborhood (Barrio) is very alive during the night. There are plenty restaurants and bars to spend the evening and have a nice dinner.

Boutique with bling. Great service from the start. Great food in the rooftop bar. Highly recommend. Breakfast is a wow. The location cannot be beaten. Situated on an old square. Our room had a balcony which wrapped around the hotel giving us views of the water.
EAT AND DRINK. Divine places to have dinner and then to have a drink among the diferent bars. After a certain hour to much crowded especially young tourists
The best place for restaurants and cafes. Great place to wander, lots of unusual and quirky cafes and restarants. hard on your legs if you are older like me, but taxis are cheap!!

Barri Altofts is always buzzing full of life and people . Barri Alto = the high neighbourhood is more genuine than Barcelona. Full of life and more friendly to your pocket. Check out the area around Largo Chiado. You find Vista Alegre and Leitao & Irmao next door. Beutiful silverware and porcelain. Genuine shops and also mainstream shops. Worth while a day or two

Bustling with life!. Bustling with bars, clubs, people, a walk in this trendy barrio is a must for any visitor in Lisbon! You can walk down straight to the river stopping every other minute to take a picture of the life going around you. Enjoy!
Good location. But hilly. We stayed at airbnb. Many restaurants around. Also fine access to metro and bus. Do not use car if you stay there
loved it. old charm small streets, lots of shops, amazing views and restaurants. easy acces to everywhere :) add a few great caffee shops with great deserts.
Lovely streets!. Really enjoyable to walk around at night, lots of hidden bars and restaurants to discover, would recommend getting the tram up as it is on quite a steep hill.

Trendy and easy. A must place for anyone that wants to know the heart of Lisbon.
There is shops and plenty of restaurants available in the area. Good bus, tram and metro service to take you anywhere.

Nice place. We stayed in an apartment in this area. The energy of the surrounds is really great, with several good places to eat and drink. Plenty of people offering you drugs on the street, but not in an aggressive way and there's something very non-threatening about it (since personal use has been decriminalized in Portugal).
Good area to visit. Plenty of good bars, some with entertainment most nights, All staff (in the one we went in-were very friendly) We frequented one called Wine Seller (or cellar) Really nice

Good place had a drink and get to know some amazing people.. We walked the streets of the Bairro Alto and had a surprise with a fantastic architecture with lots of lively people and beautiful people enjoying the night.

nice neighborhood for a walk. It is a hilly neighborhood, nice for a walk, and centrally located to go either to Ave. do Liberdade, or to clubs, or to the Miradouro to overlook the city. It is an old neighborhood with history. The streets are not as unusual as Alfama, but it's worth seeing on its own.
The best party place. I love party in Lisbon. The evening was very amazing. The bars, the drinks, the music and athmosphere was very different. We love it sooo much and plan to go back :)

Support your local dealers!. The bad thing is that more and more "big players" are getting into the Bairro Alto. Whenever you see one of these small stores, grocery etc. go support them instead of big supermarkets or clothing companies. Otherwise the flair of this place will be gone someday. Its up to us travellers!
Dead!!. Must have gone too early at 8pm because the streets were very quiet and as most of the restaurants were so quiet and lacked atmosphere, it put us off eating here.

Excellent walk downhill. I followed Rick Steeves’ guide book on Lisbon and went up to Bairo Alto from Rossio by Elevador Funicular da Gloria and took a left to walk down Rua Sao Pedro de Alcantera. Right across the Funicular stop, the Port Institute was an interesting stop and to the right, Miraduro de Sao Pedro de Alcantara provided a very nice terrace for taking nice photos of rooftops and the castle. In a small lane to the right, I found least expensive souvenirs in the city (probably because this is out of the way). While going down, I found a very cozy and small restaurant (Papo Cheio). It was clear that local inhabitants come here to watch football games on TV, chat with Papo Cheio behind the counter and eat their excellent meals. I was the only foreigner in the restaurant, they didn’t speak English, but had an English menu. It was easy to walk into the residential area of Bairo Alto to the right and weave down to Rua Garrett. This is a slightly steep walk down with Church de Sao Roque on the left, followed by a very nice gallery and famous Cervejaria da Trinidade, also on the left. This area of Lisbon is great for just walking around, if not for eating, drinking and shopping.
Not soooo noisy.. Stayed in a wonderful apartment and near all the restaurants. Great access on to all parts of Lisbon from here. Don''t miss out on Rua das Rosas.

Old town district with lots of pubs and partying at night. At day a very nice and quiet old town district of Lisbon, at night it turns into a party area with lots of pubs, restaurants and night music venues. A huge part of the party takes place out on the small streets. Definitely a must see on your Lisbon trip. You have to know, that a big part of the party crowd are tourists, the Lisbon party people prefer to go to the bars and clubs a little bit closer to the river, because there not that much tourists.

Should have gone at night. Passed through during the day, lots of bars and places to eat. The nightlife is recommended but didn't get a chance to go in the evening. Still, it was busy enough during the day

soul of lisbon. bairro alto is full of clubs, bars and restaurant. if you visit lisbon and you dont visit this place then your visit to lisbon is not worth it. you must go to this place on friday or saturday night.

The place to be at night. Bars and clubs are everywhere in this area, you have allot of choices, and when the weather is good, people just drink in the streets between the bars, very refreshing and a good place to mingle and meet people, very diverse types of bars are all in this area, and the easiest way to pronounce the name of this place is "bai-khoalto"

If you like free shots and cheap cocktails and super busy streets during the weekend.... Great place to start your night out. Most of the bars offers free shots and happy hours. There are some really cool places to hang out with friends, family and follow travellers...

great architecture. this beautiful area is located in the heart of lisbon. it hosts lots of pubs restaurants and shops. All places are open untill very late so you can never get bored of it. the atmosphere is nice and it is filled with people of all ages, tourists and non. I highly reccomend this area in case you find yourself in Lisbon and want to stroll around

Quaint, pictureques area. Enjoyed exploring the area & discovering little shops/cafes & squares - off the beaten track, where there appeared to be many more locals Note it is quite hilly to reach - though there is a tram that goes up from Avenue da Liberdade (near the station) to Rue de S. Pedro De Alcantara. We had a map/ plan of a walk, which I'd copied from a guide book and this was very enjoyable, with us going off it at times to explore a different building/park/square. Would be easy to get lost without some quide & then time would speed by more than ever!
Where "alfacinhas" go to drink and have fun. You should not miss the opportunity to have a night out in one (or several) of the bars in the bairro alto.
Woahh this walk lol. The walk up this hill is crazy lol what a work out just saying! but worth it. Just do it! haha the area is great for nightlfe

Truly beautiful . It's a stunning place to wander, get lost and search a little. Stunning views and picturesque trams too. Just be careful to hide you wallet. Or maybe don't take it out with you. Just take as much cash as you might need and one card.

I love too Bairro Alto - Lisbon. Bairro Alto, a neighborhood laid out in 1513, is a place that truly changes from night to day. In daylight this bohemian district is a sleepy place, hungover from the previous night, with not much going on except for the shops down Rua do Norte. When the sun sets a new life begins, with restaurants opening their doors, and crowds showing up to spend their bar-hopping night. The bars are small, forcing everyone to spill out onto the streets and creating a street party atmosphere. Rua da Atalaia, Rua do Diário de Noticias and Rua da Barroca become filled with caipirinha-sipping crowds, most under 40, but mixing different urban tribes, straight and gay. It's a place inhabited by old ladies and young artsy hipsters, giving it a vibe that is simultaneously old-fashioned and avant-garde, a shabby-chic neighborhood that really needs no name. It's simply the "bairro," the neighborhood where everything happens -- at night. Crossing the street (Calçada do Combro) you step into the small Bica neighborhood, known for its famous funicular. This is another picturesque neighborhood that goes down the hill, together with neighboring Santa Catarina which is known for its lookout terrace.

It's a Different World by Day and Night. My husband and I stayed at an Airbnb in the heart of Barrio Alto during our stay in Lisbon. By day, it is a quiet place where seniors walk their dogs and tourists explore little streets up & down the hills. By night, it transforms into a lively area of bars and restaurants, complete with bands and people drinking on the streets. Little doors you overlooked in daylight roll up to reveal cute eating places, pool halls, and clubs. You must, must visit, but do not plan to stay overnight if you are a light sleeper. My husband and I can sleep through about anything, but not this neighborhood on a Saturday night. Regardless, we had a great stay. It's central to everything and we would definitely stay here again.
Must visit. A place where you can find lisbon people and a lot os tourists as well. Full of little and typical restaurants.

Lisbon main place to have FUN!!. Beyond being one of Lisbon traditional neighbourhoods. At night all the streets and alleys becomes full of all nationalities, interacting and enjoying Lisbon night.A great place to make new friends, have fun or even walk around to see all the diversity.

intersting nightlife. It is intersting to go from bar to bar in the night. The nightlife it is unique in Lisbon. I like it and it is not expensive and you can chat with locals and other turists when you are drinking a beer, a sangria or a cocktail....

Bars. Went here for a night out to see what the bars were like. Seemed like a very shady and seedy area and I was approached numerous times by people offering me illegal substances. The bars I went to were also very shady and the crowd did not seem safe at all. If you are used to mainstream bars and nightclubs, this is not the place for you. I would rather recommend the nightclubs along the beach which have a sense of sophistication and sexyness that I've not experienced before.

Fun and lively part of town. Touristy, so keep away from most of the restaurants as the food is poor and expensive for what you getHowever it is a lively area with shops, narrow streets and s typical Zlidbon atmosphere

Great place to wander around. We had a wonderful time wandering around the neighborhoods of Lisbon, and this is one of the best. The streets can be very steep so wear your walking shoes. I can't remember the street but we ran across a wonder section where there were portraits of people who live there posted on the walls along the street. It was a wonderful introduction to local living in this area. Also, look out for some great wall murals. We found one about fado music that was so beautiful that I used it on coffee mugs and t-shirt family gifts.

MUST DO IN LISBON: Either during day or during night. This is one of the most beloved parts of Lisbon. In the very heart of the city, Bairro Alto offers typicall restaurants during the day (or if you go to have dinner you have many typical houses there too). These tiny and small streets are the most typicall things in Lisbon! During the night, this place is full of life, bars, clubs places to drink whataver you want. Suggestion: If you are more than 40 and travel with your family, this is a typicall place to have dinner but not to go out because its too crowded. If you are travelling with friends and if you want to have a piece of the vibrant Lisbon nightlife, you've found your place!
Really nice place to stay in.. Everything is close . Full of restaurants and nice hotels. Do not go there for new years eve as it is very crowded for this time of year.

Gorgeous neighborhood. Plenty of great places to eat authentic food and enjoy a glass (or 3) of the Portuguese wine in a quaint atmosphere. The streets are gorgeously steep and narrow and worth every step. Be sure to wear shoes that have some grip... my converse tennies didn't fare to well on the slippery cobblestone sidewalks when it started to rain.
the place to be. strolling around made easy. some steep hills but all managable. at night full of light and people. a fun place to be.
lovely neighborhood. lovely neighborhood to walk in the little streets, enjoy a good glass of wine and try local food. Go for an evening walk

Excellent restaurants. This is a hilly neighborhood with quaint and narrow streets. It is full of excellent restaurants. The food in Lisbon was fantastic and very reasonable priced ( particularly considering the high quality and excellent presentation).

night life. go there after 8 pm
alot of restaurants, pubs and bars
street musicians and good wine
I m in love with this part of Lisbon

Do not miss the amazing Carmo Ruins in Bairro Alto. I’m puzzled that I can’t find any reviews specifically for the Carmo Ruins and Archaeological Museum in Bairro Alto. It was a highlight of our visit to Lisbon. I’m putting this review under Bairro Alto, which we enjoyed wandering through to find the Carmo church. Definitely take the funicular up to Bairro Alto. Avoid the super touristic Santa Justa Elevator with its endless lines. This medieval Church of Santa Maria do Carmo, founded in 1389, was ruined in the 1755 earthquake while congregants were attending mass. At the time it was the largest church in Lisbon. Now the gothic arches open to the sky in amazing beauty. Reconstruction of the church started in 1756 and ended in 1834, when the religious orders were abolished in Portugal.Today you can wander through the exterior with open arches and walls. A museum, located at the site of the original main altar, displays sculptures from old ruined buildings and items found in the rubble from the earthquake. The scope of the small museum is impressive; it even includes South American mummies.
Lively. Lively and bustling tourist area. Lots of restaurants and bars. Loads of the restaurants had live fado.
Rustique. This is the place to stay in Lisbon. Close to main attractions (walking distance). This is the heart of the historical part of Lisbon.
Nothing to do during daytime. Better go at night, not much to see and do in the daytime. The Alfama neighbourhood is much nicer with narrow streets, squares and vieuws.

Awesome location!. Bario Alto is not for everyone - it can get super loud at night and is filled with interesting characters. However, we snagged an Airbnb and had a great time. The night life starts late and goes late. You'll have easy access to the entire city, the metro, and great view points. The restaurants and local market shops are ideal. We walked everywhere and felt safe the entire time. Also, there are excellent wine bars all over the place.

Superb area of Lisbon day and night. The Bairro Alto really has a buzz and energy about it pretty much all of the time. We stayed right in the centre of it for a long weekend to celebrate a birthday, and were so pleased to be right in the heart of the city.During the day, there is the bustle of the tourist trade, with countless bars, restaurants and cafes to partake of, with many street performers adding to the atmosphere. At night this continues, but even walking back from dinner late in the evening, the area felt safe.The only downside was that sometimes it was a bit noisy in the apartment, but we felt that was a reasonable price to pay for being in the heart of things.Love this area - would certainly stay here again when we come back to Lisbon

Not my favorite part of Lisbon. Let's start by saying that this old part of Lisbon is safe to walk around, but it's in bad shape because of the great nightlife.Lots of narrow streets crossing one another,cafes and restaurants in the area. Good for a stroll if you've time.
A Great Walk. When in Lisbon walk around this area. Lots of churches, markets, restaurants and street scenes. Tram Gloria is one very hilly block long -take it just for fun.

Interesting geography. Lots of interesting narrow winding streets to explore and a few good viewpoints out over the city below. I walked up here from the Chiado area: a bit of a distance, but quite easy to reach by foot. Not sure I would feel so comfortable to be alone here late at night.

Pleasant districy of Lisbon to stay. Very pleasant district of Lisbon to stay (there is a Bed and breakfast called Barrio Inn which is is a wonderful place to stay. Great public transportation but if you have a car do NOT park in the underground parking at the large plaza - very expensive.
Nice in the daylight. Walking around was fun in the daylight. We stopped for dinner and ended up walking back to our apartment in the dark. Honestly, it was a little scary at night.

must go but get 24hrs pass ticket to free take. it is touristey point that we need to take some amazing photos.
good.
very nice scene for photo.
negative points
just few minutes journey
expensive fare at 3.60eur, cheating tourists
one staff drive very rude
recommend
must buy 24hrs pass ticket at metro station to free take it.

Good strolling. This is an area of 16th century homes on top of one of the two major hills in Lisbon. You can take a funicula up from the Avenida Liberdade right across from the Hard Rock Cafe and then stroll through the narrow streets going downhill all the way until you arrive at a shopping street Rua Garrett and then wind up down in the lower part of the town. Best to take a guide book. There are lots of little restaurants and this is definitely a nighttime place.

Narrow, Steep Streets and Fun to See. It was pretty quiet on a rainy night in mid-December. But it was a sweet place to be. Especially the Wine Bar. I did enjoy the old buildings, but it wasn't spectacular. Still, I could appreciate the area and I wouldn't have missed it. We took a taxi, although there is a tram. I'm not big into nightlife, so maybe I would have given it four stars. I do love cobblestone streets!

Don't Miss the Bairro Alto. Wandering around the Bairro Alto is always a highlight of our visits to Lisbon. It is chocked full of charming streets, beautifully tiled façade buildings, quaint restaurants, unique shops (as well as some global chains), beautiful churches and amazing vistas including the Rio Tejo and the Sao Jorge Castle. Don't miss it - but do wear comfortable shoes!

Dirty and nothing special. Personally I did not like the area at all.Safe to walk in but no comparison to other old European cities.All the streets looked the same. Narrow,steep,dirty,in bad shape and a ambience that was for sure lost years ago. A big clean up is needed.
Great for nightlife!. Loved Lisbon cant wait to go back! so much to see an do! an for this time of the year the weather was amazing!

Old world experience. One of the grand cities of the "old world", Lisbon still has some very special venues, such as the tram that conquers the hills or the elevator (see Santa Justa). Lisbon has kept an atmosphere in the old city that reminds of gone by times. One of my favourites and something new to discover on every visit.

Bar round. Went out on a thursday. Not packed with people but still a lot of people around.
Some of the bars was closed. Guess that there are more people there during the weekends.

A world inside Lisbon. Bairro Alto is a world inside the city of Lisbon, with its own life and where found everything and everyone! No taste is unfulfilled, no desire unfulfilled. It's a great place, always delicious and different! Like. Very much!!

Great place for nightlife and wandering. Jammed with bars and clubs, the nightlife goes on all night!
Cheap too!
During the day the neighborhood is very atmospheric and authentic.

You need comfortable shoes!. A great place to walk around, day or night. You may need to get the tram there to help you get up the hill. In the evening great bars etc. and lots of people just strolling around.

The best area of Lisboa. I loved this neighborhood of the city the most for its vibrance. It has great restaurants and bars, so it's especially fun for the younger visitors. You can just make your way through the streets observing locals and other tourists enjoying themselves. There are also a few places, where you can listen to Fado. It's best to go there in the evening to have dinner and some drinks afterwards.

Don't sleep at night...go to Bairro Alto!. Bairro Alto is the place you're looking if you want to have fun at night in Lisbon. Alone or with a group of friends, this is the perfect place for having a great night experience of one of the most iconic old neighbours of Lisbon.

never seen before. high and down in this city gives it a lovely place, the vieuw upstairs is wondrfull,everwhere the people are very kind, please take your pictures, ubove there is areally lovely marketplace.

Nice lane. It's sad to see that the tram was badly vandalized.. U don't get to see this kind of sight with the narrow and steep lane runs a tram.. A pity that they didn't making the look of the tram else it's really a nice place to take picture.

Amazing Night Life. This neighbourhood starts to get busy from about 11pm to 2am. After this, move down to pink street or the waterfront to party until 6am or so... So many streets to explore. Neighbourhood is full of locals, students, and tourists. Great mix. Seemed like there was quite a few gay bars in the area, but it was a great mix of all people at every bar you go. It was pretty neat to see this openness and inclusion. Come here to meet people from all around the world. Not just for young party kids either. Many Fado bars and restaurants in the area as well.
amazing night life. you can find there nice coffees places, small bars and most of the night life in Lisboa is over there enjoy

Excellent walk. An excellent area to take a walk and enjoy the crowds! Lots and lots of bars and restaurants to choose from. Beautiful traditional streets and local buildings and vibes. Lots of things you can choose from.

Too much choice. You cannot go wrong wandering the streets of the Bairro Alto in the evening searching for a place to eat and drink. There are a mixture of traditional and modern restaurants offering great food and to complement them, bars are a plenty. Be prepared to eat late in Lisbon and expect late evenings back at the hotel.

The perfect spot for day and night. Walking through the sloping and narrow streets of Bairro Alto, you'll find a place where, amazingly, the cosmopolitan lifestyle meets the typical, traditional Portuguese life. Full of bars, of all kinds, where you can enjoy good, cheap drinks during the night, this is one of the mandatory places to be when going out at night - here you can drink outside while chatting with your friends or new people to meet; walk through the streets, from one bar to another; visit some exhibitions and free music concerts in some art galleries. During the day, you can see the beautiful typical colourful houses, shops from different kinds, restaurants, ... go there with comfortable shoes and have fun!

You can't miss it. Heart of Lisbon. Second best place to stay after Alfama. The streets never sleep, bar hopping is mandatory, you can smoke (whatever you want) inside some bars, everyone is chill and laid back.

cool place to unwind. definitely a place to chill in the evening. There are so many nice restaurant and bars in the neighbourhood. It is one of the place you have to visit when you are in Lisbon. It gets busy at night but it is safe. Tips for ladies: high heels not recommended. Make sure you are wearing comfortable shoes.

Night life.... We took the funicular to reach the Bairro Alto where you can find bars,restaurants & shops.It is where the night don't really sleeps.You will never be bored here.You can also have a great view of the city downtown.

Bustling Shopping Area. Up the hill from central Lisbon you will find many chain shops, the shopping mall and plenty of cafes. Street entertainers of all sorts to amuse either whilst walking by or if you decide to people watch whilst enjoying a coffee and pastry.
Magic. Bairro alto is so typical, you have the feeling to be in a fairy tale book, it is so simple and colourful, don't miss it
Not the best in Lisbon. It is a great place, with some nice views. But it is not the best in Lisbon, for sure. Worth the visit if you are around!

Not as amazing as I expected. We walked through the area in the afternoon just to get our bearings and then returned later at night. We already had dinner and were just wanting to browse and have a few glasses of wine and catch some Fado. Tons of restaurants, bars and clubs but what turned me off was the hucksters out front of many places trying to coax you in. I'm just not keen on that.We did find a few places with Fado but the cost was way over our budget in the ones we found. Honestly, this area is overrated IMHO. Lots of cities have similar and better nightclub areas and most others are cleaner and feel more secure.

Great architecture. I took the Elevator Gloria (a cog railway) up to the top, then wandered down through this neighborhood. The tile work covering some of the buildings is very beautiful. I ended up at a mall and took a a regular elevator to the lower town. Lots of good local places in the mall. Great views of the city.
Bar area. This is the place where the night life happens. Tons of different bars and restaurants that are open till morning hours. Cheap drinks and crowd everywhere.
A good night life area. This is where u need to be to check out the night life in lisbon. With quite a few trendy bars..this place is best when ur with a group of friends.

Great atmosphere ! . Really enjoyed this part of Lisbon. Great shops, restaurants and bars. Sunday evening was terrific fun as we sat in a bar and watched the world go by. Good nightlife and many variety of restaurants.

For great nightlife. A my husband and I love going out to bars and listening to live music and this is the place to go. We went our second night and every night thereafter.We went about 9.0. o'clock and wondered why this was supposed to be the place to be as it was empty and quiet. By 10.30 pm people started arriving and by 11.30 pm it was so busy that at some bars we were standing out in the street, as there were so many people about. Every night after we didn't go out until about 10.30pm. We didn't go clubbing as we are far to old for that, so I cant tell you what the nightclubs are like, but bar wise, there is every kind for every age. We had a great time. PS there are good quiet bars as well, if that's what you like.

Best place at night . One of the best places at night in Lisbon, is full of bars all over it a lot of people enjoying the night life. Good access by taxi or bus. Cheap bars and some of them with thematic themes. Mandatory to visit it.
For the young. Bairro Alto means High Town and this is right at the top of very steep hills, There is a Funicular railway takes you up but you will miss the sights of the old part of Bairro Alto,

A good hike. I think this part of the city is great to visit if you´re in a mood for a small hike, since there are a lot of steps to climb. Full of little restaurants and bars, you can stop at various places to have a quick drink, enjoy the company of others, ot have dinner. It is also a good intro to the night life, as on weekends the streets are just overflowing with people, and this neighborhood is very close to some of the main clubs in the city.
Great night life. Great place to eat and go for a few drinks before heading to a club, also did a walking tour through here in the day and was great to have a look around. A must visit!

The Heart of Lisbon. Well, perhaps the Bairro Alto needs to share this accolade with the Alfama, but it is a fabulous part of this great city.The Bairro Alto is where you will find fado, wine bars, eclectic coffee shops, people, interesting houses, small shops, people, quirky little corners, trams rushing by, small restaurants offering delicious food and above all, the Soul of Lisbon.Visiting the Portuguese capital without heading into the Old Town would simply be unnatural!

Bairro Alto Lisbon. The best place to visit in Lisbon at night!Very active night life, bars all around and nice people.You can also find Casas de Fado (Houses of Fado) where you can dinner with live music(Fado is a unique kind of music from Portugal)

Funky, eclectic and fun. An amazing area of small winding streets with the most amazing selection of little tapas, wine bars and clubs. Something for everyone. We ended up in a great jazz bar...heaven! Definately a repeat trip...many more times.

Picturesque, narrow streets and alleys. This is often thought of as a bar and restaurant zone, but there are also historic sites, like the army barracks where the 20th Century Dictatorship fell, the Jesuit church of St. Rock, and some beautiful viewpoints over the city.

Quiet during the day and lively at night. We stayed 2 nights in the Barrio Alto area in an apartment and glad we picked this area. There are many restaurants and bars but not so many that it gets overly raucous. At its heart, it is a residential area with cobblestone streets and the occasional street art on the walls. Be prepared to walk the many streets and alleys with their ups and downs. Wear good shoes, but you probably know that if you know Lisbon. Beautiful city and this area was wonderful for us to stay in.It is much quieter in general than in the busier Alfama area, so it really depends on your style. That being said, there are still the Fado bars, and many good restaurants to choose from.Apartment rentals are inexpensive and can be found through VRBO or Home Away. We found a nice one on Rue Vinha, and really liked the location. The street was quiet and all locals except us. But we were literally 2-3 short blocks from finding pastry shops and restaurants. We felt we had the best of both worlds.It is an easy walk down the hills to the main parts of the city. And you do get used to the walks back up surprisingly enough. All in all, the Barrio Alto worked out really well for us.

The charming old town. I´ve been in Lisbon about 5 times and every time I like to visit this beautiful part of the town. It is like travelling back on time. It is my favorite part of Lisbon and as a brazillian, I can see something of the center of Lisbon in the old town of my hometown. Lisbon is an enchanting city, with wonderful food and beautiful places to see. It is worth exploring on foot the narrow cobblestone streets.

Great neighborhood. We stayed in the neighborhood and are really glad that we did. There are lots of great streets with lots of character to stroll along. There are loads of neighborhood bars and restaurants and all types of shops to sell you anything you may need. We did our laundry here and were to buy groceries and enjoy the nightlife.

A neighborhood that transforms itself as the daylight vanishes.. Bairro Alto was built in 1531 after the tsunami.The streets were arranged orthogonally which is remarkable in the XVI century.Some of the streets are so narrow that you can literally shake hands with your neighbour across the street not leaving home.During the day is a quiet place with regular trade and some with marginal trade.There live all sorts of people in harmony; old people who always lived there, young people, bohemians, musicians, painters, hippies, punks, straights, gays...you name it.When the sun sets the neighborhood metamorphoses itself and you can see crowds of people filling the bars, the restaurants, bookshops, avant-garde hair dressers, decorators houses...well you name it.And you go with the wave of the crowds, drinking in the narrow streets, chating, singing, in perfect security.You should try it.You'll never forget.

Must go place for nightlife. You must go to bairro alto if you want to enjoy a typical portuguese nightout. Full of small bars where you can grab your drink and come out to thw street to chat or get inside for a dance. Lots of choices for music, wines, beer or spirits. Late at night avoid the quiet streets. Enjoy

Bring your camera. What a great place for photo opportunities. Lisbon was so beaeutiful and we got to stop in the Bairro Alto area while we were taking a trip on a TUK TUK. If you have any problems walking or driving for that matter, then I wouldnt recommend with tight streets and old roads.

If you want streets full of lively bars this is your place!. The area is full of small bars and restaurants and is genuinely vibrant all evening and most of the night! It's not for the feint hearted, its not very refined, and beers may be served in plastic glasses, but it is one of the most memorable areas I've ever visited! Enjoy!

La Reina de Vida Nocturna. It is the number one place for tourists and locals as well to go out at night. This place has tons of bar and club, which are always ready for you to go in to have a beer and chill out with other people. Start to be crowded after 10pm. Same in other area, control yourself and your belongings because there are bad part of Lisbon existing
two very nice nights. It had everything we wanted to see..views of the bridge and river, parks, restaurants. Metro access, close to museums, trams and cable cars. Nice mix.

Not Sure What All the Fuss is About. I had been looking forward to seeing Lisbon's Bairro Alto but left slightly disappointed. We walked (steeply uphill) from our accommodation in Cais Do Sadre and eventually found the Bairro Alto (not as obvious as it had seemed).It is an area of narrow, cobbled lanes, famed as a haunt of artists, writers and other bohemians - today clearly by graffiti artists. There are loads of bars, cafes, fado houses and restaurants, masked by day but coming alive at night. The place is crowded at night with most people spilling-out into the lanes to enjoy their drinks (most of the bars are so tiny). Glad we visited but no great desire to return.

Choose a street to suit your mood. Rua da Rosa is probably the quietest street it starts opposite the funicular; bars at the highest point and restaurants more towards Calcada do Combro. Rua Altaia dining looks more select, still plenty of bars.Rua del Norte is very lively and starts right from the Praca da Luiz Camoes and adjacent to the metro station Chiado-Baixa so the start of a bar crawl for many groups - chose a bar about 5 doors up the street (bread/cheese/ham as snacks rather than cooked tapas drinks not rock bottom prices but fair beer 2 euro, cocktails 5-6 for 50cl). Many bars still empty at 22:30 ,drinks frequently sold by size. Smoking inside some bars, you can usually take drinks outside from bars and these served in plastic. Suggest avoiding the Fado offerings unless you are desperate. A few souvenir shops (Night) and small art displays/galleries (day)

If you are in the area. If you are staying in the area or if you are going to one of the other sites or are taking a trolley ride around the city...stop and take a picture. If you are not and have other plans, I wouldn't alter it to fit this in. It is nice, but so much of Lisbon is amazing and you will see many narrow streets with trolleys so please take a peak if it on one of your routes, if not skip.

Good restaurants in this area. You can choose a restaurant from the many they have. If you are an early dinner you have your choice. It is Europe and they eat late. But you will find restaurant catering to visitors. There are shows in restaurants "fadas" and the table you get is yours for the night.
A maze in the old part of the city. Lots of narrow streets crossing one another, with hundreds of cafe and restaurants dotted here and there. Take a stroll and soak up the atmosphere of old Lisbon.

An area of Lisbon to Experience. This is an area of Lisbon where the bars are in the streets because they are so small the people do not fit in them so they drink in the street...along with cars, scooters, etc
Underwhelmed . My wife and I were both underwhelmed during our visit to the area....we loved Lisbon, were ok with Bairro Alto. Next time we go, we will pass on this experience.
One of the best area. Local coffees bars nice music georgeus food every where you can find from the luxury to the cheaper local food and drink

Great neighborhood for wandering and accommodation . Stayed in an apartment in Bairro Alto for 4 nights and absolutely loved it. Safe, friendly, and a wonderful variety of options for restaurants and bars. It's also very centrally located, so all of Lisbon is a walk (or short metro/tram ride) away. Would happily stay here again.
a street with some cafes and bars. This street is very hectic to me. everywhere drug sellers, weird guys, very low profile. waste of time
No no no. This was so hard for us to walk up and we were lost, it was also raining and we did not know what to do. The people in the area are not as friendly as other parts too.
a nice walk uphill. A great walking area. An open air restaurant where you can find a lot of people and spent a pleasant night

Nightlife in Bairro Alto is a disappointment. Architecturally speaking Bairro Alto has very similar homes with the rest of the Lisbon city centre (which I loved), the miradouro (panoramic point) offers an amazing view of the castle and of the Baixa but the nightlife was a huge disappointment. Just very young crowds (mostly under 25) drinking cheap cocktails and cheap beer in plastic glasses in the streets, the bars are too small even to get in and the streets are full of litter. Piss and vomit at every corner. If you're looking for a fun crazy night go to the 'pink street', which also has a couple of clubs, unlike Bairro Alto.

Stunning City. Bairro Alto is in central Lisbon... a must see..... appreciate the cobblestones with incredible patterns.... plenty of museums and coffee shops..... the pastry is excellent.... order a traditional lunch.... Found Lisbon to be very affordable! What a treat!!!
great place to visit at night, buslting atmosphere. There is a main area here of 4 or 5 cobbled streets lined with bustling restaurants and bars. Great atmosphere, recommend a visit.

Excellent nightlife scene. We spent hours here the one night, hopping from one wine bar to the next. It's atmospheric cobbled streets are brimming with energy, places to eat and drink. It's worth the visit and loads of fun!
Very touristy. I like this place a lot. You can enjoy it with friend, couples or family members. you should visit it if you are in Lisbon.

Hot spot . Bario Alto is where an abundance of small bars and clubs populate these tight small cobbled streets , there is a lovely almost carnival feel to the area with everyone out mingling in the streets as many of the establishments would not be able to hold the numbers of people within , a great place to experience.

Great nightlife. We found this area on our last day. Went in several bars. Bali bar. Alface bar and others. All were great. Live music blues and others had music to dance to. Great atmosphere and great value drinks. Wish we found this at the beginning of the holiday!

Visit @ night. Different nigh life ambient.. Bairro Alto became famous more than 20 years ago because of some disco, restaurants and fado (typical portuguese music). All the place grow in that offer, nowadays with also shops. Go there. Don't miss.

Eat , drink And have fun in Bairro Alto. Bairro Alto is one if the most interesting spots in Lisboa. Lots of restaurants both fancy And family small business were you can eat at very reasonable prices. Known for it's vibrant night life yet safe to explore and discover by yourself. You can also small concept shops of alternative designers and very near Chiado ( metro station) And Príncipe Real . The streets are narrow And Nice to discover by foot , parking is pretty impossible.

A fun neighbourhood. The Bairro Alto neighbourhood is a fun one to ramble around. Lovely shops and great streetscapes offer lots of window shopping, rubber necking, photo taking and just absorbing the delights of this oh so walkable city.

Best area in Lisbon for me!. We were so glad we chose to stay in Bairro Alto as having traveled around the Centre and the outskirts it is the best area to stay. So many little bars, wine bars, restaurants to suit all budgets. We went for a serviced apartment which worked out so well to come and go as we pleased. The people are so friendly and helpful and want their tourism to grow, but they are not pushy even when you learn how low wages are in this City centre. They don't expect much of a tip but the service deserves digging a bit deeper.

Good night life. Bairro alto is actually just a small area that at day isn't much, but at bight it transforms. With loads of restaurantes and bars that are open until 2am. The good thing about this area is that people usually stay on the street and go into the bars only to grab drinks giving the hole area a really good vibe. Definitely recommend for young people that want to have a meal and go for some drinks after and with the wide variety of bars you'll sure to find a place that suits you.

Hilly shopping area. If you are old and cannot walk up the hill, you can take the elevator in H&M store and go out to the upper street. There is an Apple store and other specialty stores along the street. House wares, clothing,ect.

Noisy, dirty and narrow streets. The Barrio Alto is a very old neighborhood of Lisbon where the streets are very narrow and steep and made of cobblestones. The main street of this area is the Rua da Rosa, a one way street leading up the hill. In the daytime vehicles scream up there scattering pedestrians as they go. The old people who live there seem very adept at escaping death. There are many restaurants and bars as well as some trendy shops selling unusual wares. The night time hides a lot of faults and the lighting may make it look attractive but it is noisy and extremely crowded with drunks and drugos who spill out of the bars etc down the Rua da Rosa and the other streets of the area into the square at Camoes every night yelling and screaming obscenities, and worse, well into the early morning. Luckily the council clean up truck usually hoses the debris away before sunrise. If you enjoy this type of thing, go enjoy but if you like to get a little sleep, don't book a hotel in this area.

Amazing!. The neighborhood is small but full of beauty everywhere. The houses and buildings are unique and the vibe is really cool. Totally recommended if you're looking for a bar. People go out every night

Nightlife central . Bairro Alto is the main tourist nightlife area of Lisbon.Lots of restaurants and bars in the area, all trying to entice you in, some better than others but that's what nightlife is about!You can find a large (500ml) Super Bock for a little as €1.10.Two tips:1. Don't go for the XL beers - these are the largest size at 750ml but they invariably cost more than two large (500ml) beers.2. If you like late night munchies then don't stay til the bar shuts. The two takeaways that we found close religiously at 3am with the bars, so if you've hung about for a last beer then make sure you've snacks on your room.All that aside you should have a great night out in the Bairro Alto.
Night Life. Amazing for a nice night out, with friends or for a romantic date. You should be carefull in the weekends because it's too crowded. But still, pretty awesome.
Loads to see. A great place to wander around loads of shops, bars, and restaurants, comes alive after dark great place to spend some time

Most visit. Barrio alto is and old neighborhod in one mof the hills of Lisbon. Very narrow and old streets with many bars, cafe's and Fado's places. Late ant night, specially on weekends, the streets are full ofr people including tourists. There is not a lot of vehicle transit because of the narrows strees so getting a taxi is not easy. Most visit
The neighbor hood in the evening. Go here in the evening, it is always cosy crowded. A lot of bars, restaurants, most of them quite small, each with a lot of atmosphere.

Charming. One of the best city districts in Europe. We loved our caipirinhas served on the street. Great concept. Many restaurants with tasty,traditional local food. Charming narrow streets and old architecture. Must see and experience!
Quirky shops. Lots of little bars & restaurants in this area. Some really great independent shops. Nice to wander on a weekend. Good place to find unusual gifts.

the spt to be on the weekend. great night life here, it gets packed and wear comfortable shoes. A lot of young people hanging out at the bars drinking and having a good time. Shoulder to shoulder standing room in the streets.
Nightlife.. This historical area offer some very lively nightlife and also is one of two gay areas in Lisbon. Nothing here gets going until about 11pm

Interesting part of Lisbon, especially for food!. A definite must see in Lisbon, particularly in you are interested in food. Makes for a great half day walk with lots to see and photograph. One of the essentials for time spent in Lisbon.
The other old part of Lisbon again with some seriously steep hills.. Just get to the top and have a gentle walk down taking it all in. In the evening the whole place changes and becomes

Lively nights out. Bairro Alto is the primary neighbourhood for nightlife in Lisbon. In a wider European context it has a charming nightlife setting with its narrow streets, trams, hilly terrain, public squares and terraces. The action and parties last late into the night; no wonder it seems relatively quiet during the daytime. As long as you venture deep into Bairro Alto—away from Chiado—it won't take long to find the bustling bars.I visited as a student and it was very cheap for nightlife. You can get drinks like cocktails or treble shots for barely a few euros. Bairro Alto is very lively and it can take some time to traverse because of the number of people that can spill outdoors. In terms of nightlife much of the area didn't strike me as particularly touristic, which makes for a nice experience with the locals!

A great vibrant area of Lisbon.. Wander around to get the best of what Bairro has to offer. Take your camera. Brilliant bars and street life at night, for all ages. A really good and very popular Fado bar ( and there are a good few in Bairro that are not touristy) is A Tasca de Chico. Lots of hills to negotiate but its doable. Def try the old Ascensor da Bica (funicular) that goes from Rua Duarte Belo off Rua de Sao Paulo and Largo de Calhariz. Visit the really lovely lookout São Pedro de Alcântara - you wont regret it.

Not special. The Bairro Alto is the bar zone of Lisbon, there is nothing much about it during the day, just leftover bottles and trash on the floor from the previous night's party. The restaurants are overprices and aimed at tourists so food is not the greatest quality either. It's fun to bar hop as there are hundreds of bars on these small streets! It's definitely an experience, but nothing particularly special.
n i ce. Nice streets lots of bars and restaurants but while walking we were offered cocaine to buy this was very unnerving

Nightlife good. Recommended to us by locals for nightlife and it was buzzing on a monday night. Lots of small bars and cheap drink. Used the funicular to get up to it but at 1pm there were no drivers in it although we were told it opened til 4pm. Don't wear high heels in Lisbon, ground so not suitable especially for the hills.
The place to stayin Lisbon. In Bairro alto you can find everything you need: restaurants, late night bars, friendly people, music. You will be in the heart of Lisbon!

Local Lisboa offers lots to see and do!. Enjoyed 4 wonderful days in Lisboa last month and kept finding ourselves coming back here for the food, wine and atmosphere! Two of our party had been to Lisbon numerous times before, so we simply followed our impulses, walking down whatever streets looked inviting & stopping in a number of the tiny shops to see what they had to offer.When the steep hills and cobblestones started to get tiring, we then popped into a wine bar that was open and how lucky we were! (Check out "The Old Pharmacy Wine Inn" on the Rua Diario de Noticias if you like great wine & food in an informal setting. Ask for "George"!)Wear good walking shoes & enjoy whatever comes your way!
Charming and one of a kind. Lisbon´s local area with lots of attitude and personality. The best of Old Europe. Many tourists, many back-packers, many bars

Novelty. We spent a day here, it has all the usual tourist trappings, and the issues of overcharging that come with it. However, I found much of the place just very grimy. There was too much dirt about and when wearing light clothing, they become soiled.It was good for a once ever visit but the many hills were challenging and took the enjoyment of being able to just stroll about. The small trams get very overcrowded.

Just walk the streets for your favorite food.. The Bairro Alto is such lovely neighborhood with its alley ways and its great selection of restaurants, Stella was exceptional. This restaurant had great service and even better food. The Bacalou dish was outstanding.
Lovely.. Old town Lisbon is a treat of cobbled narrow streets full of lovely little boutique shops and restaurants.

bairro alto. Lisbao city got up and down place like hill, so use this tram will be good for explore, but the ticket is quiet expensive, about euro 2,6 per ride. so better you buy 24 hours tickets in metro station, can use for metro, tram and bus.
atmosphere. loved going to find a great restaurant at night in this neighbourhood. tiny little alleyways full of people, tons of restaurants and bars, fado, good variety of places to eat.

Bairro Alto. WE took a walking wine tour through this neighborhood. We also took a tuk tuk through this area of Lisbon. Many nice opportunities for shopping and plenty of places to quench your thirst and you appetite!

Go here at night!. I strolled through this place at midday, and while it was a pleasant walk (uphill), you don't get to experience the wonders of Bairro Alto until after dark, when all of the restaurants and clubs open. Then it's a whole different experience!

tipical tourist hand. just small streets full of ttoursists hangout for groups and lonely traveler, no much action just bars, some eateries, for small break all medium class. Took a short walk around and it was enough. Not necessary to put this area on your program unless you are bored and have free evening with nothing better to do,
Good for a walk. Lovely area with lots of atmosphere and quirky places. Quite steep but worth it and views of the city stunning.

Come for the views and atmosphere. You can take the cable car up but the walk is just as enjoyable as you get to see the shops and cafes along the way. We had a beer and sheltered from a brief downpour in a small square outside Igreja de Sao Roque; and listened to a guitarist. It was lovely. We ended up having cocktails and dinner at Insolito which has fabulous views of the Sao Jorge Castle on the opposite hill and the town below.
It's hilly and quirky. Some lovely shops fantastic night life.. Great friendly shops bars cafes you can get lost all day in here. Comes into its own at night. Try some.

One of Lisbon gem. The atmosphere is Amazing, a mix of different style and way of life all concentrated in one district.
Wonderful nightlife and fantastic tasca ( little restaurant ) to eat

Nightlife and narrow streets. This neighborhood of Lisbon comes to life at night with lots of bars and restaurants. It is great just to wander around, explore the streets and find a great bar, have a drink and some snacks.I did find all the dealers somewhat troubling and do not like to constantly be offered illicit drugs, but that seems to be part of the nightlife....

Great neighborhood. You can visit two Miradouro in this neighborhood, or you can take 2 funiculars to reach this area. One of Lisbons's Oldest neighborhoods.If you want to take the funiculars don't pay on spot(3.6 euro is a lot for Lisbon prices) you have to options:Buy the Lisbon card and you get also the trains for Cascais or Sintra covered.Buy the Viva Viagem card(0.5 euro) and get a day ticket 6 euro or a 3 day ticket 13,5 euro and ALL your transportation is covered,, including trams 28,18,12, 15
Great Walks. Very nice neighborhood to walk. Lots of great restaurants and a nice atmosphere, with narrow streets.

Memorable. Lisbon is a very attractive city.I liked this part. Why? Because it is so Portuguese!!Wear comfortable shoes and enjoy discovering the lanes, streets and have no plan..just explore.Have a camera ready, you will find some beautiful views or stuff.

The heart of Lisbon. At day and night this is a special place to visit. Rising above the main squares of the city, the panoramic views of the city and the river are fantastic. Not to mention the cobbled stone small alley ways and the numerous restaurants, bars and night life entertainment. But you do need to be in good physical condition and wear comfortable shoes. The climbing and descending are not easy even when you use the elevators and cable cars.
nice atmosphere to walk. nice atmosphere to walk, at at nights lots os small clubs and young dancers around the strrets. you feel cozy and sugessted to stay in one of them to feel the atmosphere.

Student Quarter with Flair. The Bairro Alto is many things, but it’s an important area for university student housing. Streets are barely alleyways.
