Visit at night. Visit during the arraial parties, great music, food, and lots of fun. Avoid wearing things that catch too much attention, same for guys, don't carry your wallet on the back and have always cash easy on hand. It was so much fun

LIVELY !!!. Gets going late on and carries on !!! Even for a pair of oldies !!! Very eclectic mix of bars ,restaurants and people the party people in the Rio society are bonkers !!!!! theres something for everyone so get yourself along and go with the flow !!!!!!
Great place. Great place for dining and going for a walk. Narrow streets, lots of restaurants and a nice feel to the place.

Nightlife. We stayed in this area. There is always a crowd - lots of music, food and entertainment. Just walking by a restaurant that has lots of locals will mean good food at a reasonable price. There are so many little streets and and alleys to explore in the day or evening or just sit outside at a cafe and people watch. A must see area!

High Place. We stayed in the Bairro Alto in May for a week. Great spot for seeing Lisbon, easy walk to the water, train station, Chiara and the main shopping areas. The area is full of little restaurants, shops, and music places - good to explore. If you stumble across 'Churrasqueira da Paz' restaurant, stop and eat; they do the best grilled fish I've ever had.

Party town woo hoooo. This is the village on top of the hill opposite the castle and it's party town . A gorgeous maze of alleys, squares, bars and restaurants which gets more and more lively as the night goes along. 9pm it's busy and the restaurants still have a few seats, 10pm most are full and the bars are getting lively, 11pm the bars are getting full and the streets are lively, 12pm the streets are full and there's laughter and partying everywhere, 1am, 2am, 3am, party party party. 4am people are pretty much out of it but a few joints for the serious hedonists are just opening (not saying where - you will have to ask) Lisbon is a super little city and Bairro Alto is one of many highlights
Buzzing . Lots of live where u can enjoy drink with locals. Live music perform on the streets are entertaining walks

The place to be for nightlife. If you are going out for a few drinks look no further than Bairro Alto. The streets are alive with people and the bars are mostly busy. You will meet some of the most interesting people and have a great time.

Unhurried wandering needed. This is a lovely area of the city to spend unhurried time in. Stroll down old cobbled streets, take a tram ride, have an ice cream. It's peaceful, the sunsets last forever and there are plenty of restaurants and cafes to enjoy no matter the time of day.

Bairro Alto full of life. Very nice place to visit! The access either with the antique elevator or the electric bus was a very interesting experience. We took beautiful pictures of Lisbon from the top at night. Lots of restaurants are located there. Enjoy!!!

The real Portuguese Night!. Want to have a nice time during your night in Lisbon? Go to Bairro Alto them!! Lots of nice restaurants, nice bars, Fado and lots of nice Portuguese people. If you are in Lisbon at moment, just stop reading and go!

Touristy. We were in Lisbon for one evening, and decided to walk through Bairro Alto. The restaurants seemed to cater to tourists with low standards (i.e. cheap), and finding a reasonable (and hopefully authentic) Fado music show became more daunting as we progressed. After some very annoying hard-sell professionals pushing us into overpriced dinner/show combos, we decided to just have dinner in a street restaurant and enjoy the environment. During dinner, near a busy crossroad, we observed multiple people lingering, following tourists closely, returning, and repeating. I assumed these were pickpockets, but didn't really know. At any rate, if I returned, I would do more research, skip the tourist madness, and try to find some authentic Portuguese fare and entertainment.

Fun Neighborhood. We stayed in Bairro Alto for 4 days along with our 7 year old. It sits above the city on a hill so be prepared to do incline walking but transportation on the Elevador da Gloria brings you down to the city hub if walking is not your thing and Chaido is within walking distance if you're looking for shopping. The nightlife is a bit noisy but we stayed in a 4th floor apartment and so it did not bother our sleep. If you are hungry at 11pm you have no problem getting a meal for the neighborhood is awake at that time.
Fun fun fun. Our favorite part of Lisbon! Wonderful restaurants and bars in quaint little alley streets. And good shopping area too. Great exercise going up and down the hills to get there. Go!!!!!

Active and adventurous.. Many winding streets, plenty of bars and restaurants. Very active night life. Hilly area and easy to get lost (in an adventurous way!) if you enjoy people all around and a very active nightlife, you will enjoy staying in this area of Lisbon. Note: the sidewals are everywhere made of cobblestone. If you are in heels, and drinking a bit, beware!

Important Central Neighborhood in Lisbon. Next to Chiado Neighborhood and all this area is where all the old Buildings in Lisbon are located. Hard to tell apart if you are a tourist, but together with other neighborhoods they are the soul and center of Old Lisbon. A feast for Architects, Art Lovers and just the Center of the Old City with many hotels, restaurants, FADO, etc.

Spend an evening over the Weekend. Lively area with loads of services around, snack bars, cafeterias, Restaurants. The best time of the year is between spring and summer, when the locals gather outside the bars as an example of social life. The walks around the area can become quite dangerous if it rains, it is quite slippery. You can also find some live music bars or stay in the area for a good touristic offer.

Bars and restaurants on every corner. A lot of nice bars, cafees and restaurants in a small area. Obs! There is cobblestone everywhere - so high heels or wedges are not recommended! All the local girls wear flat shoes or sandals. Beware of the Fado "restaurants" in this area - some of them have lousy food and horrible fado.
Great nightlife!. What a lively place to be.. throngs of young and old hanging out in front of bars having a good time in the hilly streets of Bairro alto.. great bars, good music and fun people!

Happy hour all night. In this area of Lisbon you find locals and travelers starting happy hour at about 4 but happy hour never ends--people in squares, outside of tiny restaurants (and inside) just talking, having some beer or wine, etc. there are lots of great restaurants and bars as well as some places of interest. It is a good neighborhood to stay in or to visit.

Awesome experience. If you're looking for night life in lisbon, look no further. Bairro Alto is the coolest collection of bars and restaurants you'll find in all of Portugal. Behind an unmarked red door at the top of the hill, you'll find the "Pavilhao Chines" a bar/ lounge filled with wordly knick knacks, a few pool tables and a smoker section. This place is incredible to say the least, and a great hub for the inhabitants of all of lisbons world class hostels. The Staff is likely the only Portuguese you'll meet there, as a variety of other cultures frequent the place. A must visit.

Quiet on a Tuesday night. Walked around the neighbourhood on on a weeknight. A bit quiet, but found a few nice places to have a drink. The Sangria at one place was five drinks in one and very potent, but amazing (€5) so worth it!
The heart of Lisbon. Tiny little streets, alleyways, always going up or down. People cooking in the streets, kids playing, washing everywhere, but so real. Great atmosphere.

The place to be when in Lisbon. I stayed in Bairro Alto during my stay in Lisbon and this neighborhood is the epicenter of the nightlife of Lisbon. It's fun, trendy, hectic, vibrant and full of great restaurants, bars, and cafes. People from all walks of life come here and it's a place where the old Lisbon meets new. Don't be surprised if a local walks up to you and offers to sell narcotics. A simple no will get them to leave. Enjoy a stroll through the old and narrow streets, stop at a restaurant or cafe for some great food and drinks. You won't be disappointed.

Trendy place to visit. Trendy place to visit when in Lisbon. You'll see the old and the brand new, mixed together. Nice coffees to stay for a while, nice shops and a variety of cultures. Most of the exquisite restaurants are located here.So, good place to stay for a while. Enjoy and take lots of pictures.
Absolutely fun!. Love it there! You can find all kind of bars and a few restaurants, it's super cheap and the vibe is just insane!

Intriguing cosy neighborhood with shops, bars and restaurants. This is a must see area for your trip to Lisbon. The narrow alleys and streets are lined with local shops, restaurants and bars making it a great daytime or night time destination. The views from this hilltop neighborhood are spectacular. Make sure to have drink or a snack from the terrace at the Jardim de S. Pedro de Alcantara and check out the upscale boutiques on Principe Real.

Vibrant. Ah the bairro alto, such an amazing place.never know what your going to expect their full of good eateries n pubs/clubs but when we stayed they had a open brass band playing in the street. It was amazing soo many people crowded in this 4 part alleyway singing along.did cause havoc for the cars driving through but they were great as people place their empty cups on them as they pass. I hope to retire there one day one place of few I can say that
Meh, nothing different. Not much really to see. Overpriced and not really that nice. I didn't have any problems with pick pockets but it definitely is a place they would conjugate.

The fun and nightlife area. I am actually a bit disapointed by the way portuguese people having fun or clubbing.There are many bars in narrow bairro alto streets, but all the fun is outside on the streets.Most people have their drinks and hanging out on streets outside the bars, leaving them empty inside. This is also a way to of having fun i suppose .

Lively in the Evening!. During the day apart from the odd street performer this area is pretty but quiet, cobbled streets and alleyways and a welcome shade from the heat. In the evening it is lively and bustly, great atmosphere, lovely restaurants and small bars full of characters and charm. we left the area at 2am and it was just warming up i think!!

The very best of the traditional Lisbon nightlife. Everything just shouts "Lisboa". The environment is tipical old school Lisbon nightlife since the 70s. You have numerous bars and restaurants from cheap to expensive, all of which are pretty good. Lot's and all kind of people, inside and out in the streets. I just can't get enough of it.

Lovely restaurants and bars...but. On a couples holiday to Lisbon we loved the evenings strolling around this district. There are some lovely bars, cafes and restaurants to suit all types of traveler, you really get the feel for Lisbon city life. There is a but.. From time to time in the city ( Central Lisbon) we were offered canabis, cocaine or grass. Usually when I sad "no" the vendor took the hint. However on one night this one individual keep hassling us to buy cocaine. He kept following us and tried to get between me and my partner, we eventually had to go into a bar to avoid him, he even waited outside for ten minuets until he gave up. I have traveled for many years and I know dealers will try to sell to tourists in city's, I am not naive but be respectful if someone says "no!" Lisbon authorities take note!
Great night out!. Perfect place to visit for a lovely night out in a beautiful city!If you're looking for a great night out this is the place to visit in Lisbon.

Sturdy Walking Shoes and Relaxed Attitude. We stayed in this district for 6 days and we loved it here. Everyone is friendly, every street corner you turn promises something new for you to look at, looks like a chilled place by day and by night... phew! It's very vibrant and alive with people, restaurants, bars, chatter and atmosphere! Be prepared to be lost and love every second of it!

In staying here and it is definitely party centeal. Definitely party central. Lots to eat and drink. Our apartment is beautiful albeit a bit noisy but the bedrooms in the back are super quiet. The tangle of hilly streets make this such a quaint place. But when night falls. The party monsters emerge and the quiet streets turn into fiesta avenues :)

Put on your wandering shoes and bring a little bag for your purchases. Atmosphere, sights to see, food, ice cream, pastries, and coffee to die for. Wander, shop, taste, try on, and experience. This IS Lisbon for the population of Lisbon. Authentic and refreshing.Shop keepers are friendly, helpful and just nice to meet.A great day wandering, tasting, eating and indulging yourself.I wanna go back tomorrow........

Great place...at night!. We took the metro from Marque de Pumbal to Baixa Chiado with a very short walk right into the heart of Bairro Alto. We went first on the day time when quite frankly, nothing happens!On the night however the thin streets transform, restaurants, bars and clubs all open their doors as it progressively gets busier and busier. Definitely worth just hopping from place to place taking it all in, well worth a visit as long as its after 9PM.

traditional neighborhood. It's a very traditional neighborhood. With tiny streets, with bars, restaurants, coffees and shops. You can walk around during the day or enjoy the bars at night ( i think a visit duriung the day is more amusing).You can't park nearby, be prepared to walk.

Traditional neighborhood. This very traditional and lively neighborhood in the heart of Lisbon has attractions for the the day and the evening. Its shopping area and squares by day, and its restaurants and bars by night make an all day round attraction for the visitor to Lisbon. Try to get one of its streets going down to Baixo and you will have a pretty good idea of this very nice city.

Lively neighborhood full of bars and restaurants. We found a VRBO in Barrio Alto. Great central location with lots to do. We walked to landmarks, museums, and nightlife easily. One draw back is the area is open till 2 am so it can be quite noisey if you are looking to rest. I prefer Chiado neighborhood better.

Cool streets lined with cafes and bars. This is a nice area of town full of cafes and bars. Some of which are easy to miss! The main street has several touristy restaurants with waiters outside trying to get you in and dodgy menu boards. However if you avoid these there are some lovely authentic places. Quiet by day but definitely worth a visit at night!!

A great place to be for good food and drinks!. This place seems to be buzzing with energy and enjoyment every evening! A great place to go to find gorgeous little restaurants which offer excellent food at good prices! There are also lots of bars in this area all with their own character and charm! A must visit for some fun on an evening!

Worth to visit. If you are in Lisbon, definitely check this little area. In the evening, it's full of young people and music.I explore a lot of these narrow steep street, refusing to go up with the funicular. From the top, in the garden you have a fantastic view over the city down and the castel Saint Jorge. Worth to visit.
very alive district. A district that you should definitely visit. A new surprise awaits you behind each corner. Nice shops, nice views of the city.

Shabby Chic. A very atmospheric part of the city. The cobbled streets are packed with all sorts of shops, from Gucci to the small market trader. There are plenty of bars, bistros and restaurants available where you can enjoy a full-blown meal or just sit in the sun and enjoy a cool drink.The whole tempo is relaxed and friendly, tough during one 15 minute period as a colleague and I sat at an outside table drinking a glass of cola we were approached no less than three times and offered different combinations of grass, marijuana and cocaine. Somewhat disconcerting when considering you are in a main tourist area with loads of families all around.

High place over city for fun, dining. visit this section of Lisboa every time I come to The city.There is so many interesting places, restaurants, bars, plazas, parks, and people watching over a cup of coffee.

Miserable tram driver. Enjoyed Bairro Alto tram ride. The tram driver however didn't add anything to the experience which was a shame. He was the most miserable man I've ever met, couldn't muster a smile or acknowledge any of the passengers. He was extremely rude. Think they would be better replacing him with someone who can deal with the public and tourists and would make it a more pleasurable experience.
Great area to spend your time. This is one of the three places in Lisbon that are great to spend some time. Narrow streets, small shops,

A cozy place to have a few drinks. Personally, I liked it. I went out on my own that night, but I felt totally secure. If you are taking the crowded narrow streets that are illuminated, the "worse" thing could be some men offering you some drugs for example, but nobody is forcing you to buy anything. A lot of bars to have a drink, and take a walk, even dance with your company or some other tourists.
Lovely neighborhood . Need to visit Bairro Alto when be in Lisbon to feel the atmosphere of arts in the narrow streets and to try a glass of vinho verde!

Narrow street packed with history. The Barrio Alto is one of the well kept parts of Lisbon. I believe it was the home district for the not-so well off workers. The streets are filled with many small restaurants, lively at nighttimes.
Amazing spot!!!. The atmosphere is amazing in every bar and street! And have different music styles in different places.
Cute area with a lot of shopping. Cute area with a lot to do, especially with friends. A lot of shopping and cute coffee shops, definitely a neighborhood to check out and explore!

Would have liked to spend more time here. Built on a hill, the cobblestone streets are an adventure to navigate. Looked for a restaurant there on Easter Sunday but a number of places had closed. Wonderful view from the plaza overlooking Lisbon. Took the bus tour through the Barrio so I have a good picture of the neighbourhood. Would like to see more. Took the tram/cable car down to the Centre( a bit pricey-but you get two trips) we only took one

The youthful district. There is the youthful district of Lisbon. Many little bars and restorants. You must go there with the tram and you can see an incredible view of Lisbon. You must walk to the vintage streets. After the sunset the small roads became to a big party. Nice and cheep drink everywhere. But sometimes you need be carefull some ''strange'' blokes.....
The old city. Very nice surroundings a must if you are in Lisbon. Try the small restaurants and bars. Nice shops also

Well worth the walk up the hill. Lovely area of town to wander around in. Nice shops and bars, especially at night - it got very lively! Loads of restaurants and a lovely atmosphere, and lots of lovely views over the city and the river!

Pretty winding streets with lots of bars and restaurants. We visited Barrio Alto 4 times during our long weekend visit because we absolute loved it. It's such a lovely area to just wander around and explore, there are so many little windy streets, walk ways and steps leading to other streets.We loved the feel of Barrio Alto, more bohemian and relaxed and there are lovely small bars and restaurants everywhere so plenty to choose from if you want to get something to eat or drink. It really comes to life at night as more people tend to go out in Barrio Alto in the evening as its one of the most popular night life destinations in Lisbon. Lots of bars with music, live music and fado.We found it to be very safe to walk around - day or night. Barrio Alto is a must if you are visiting Lisbon.

Maze of narrow cobbled streets comes alive at night. This is one of the older areas of Lisbon, with narrow cobbled streets clustered on the sides and top of the hill. During the day there are a few restaurants open for business, and you can wander the streets and look at the tiled fronts and rather run-down houses with relative ease. All changes at night when this area throngs with people, bars and restaurants appear from behind their shutters and fado music (and other music) wafts from doorways. We visited over Easter, so it may have been uncharacteristically busy, as it was difficult to find a place for a quiet drink or meal. But there's plenty of choice and everything is open until late.

Great area to explore on foot or by tram (take the 28!). One of the more attractive barrios of Lisboa, to be explored on foot (if you feel enough in shape) or by tram. Tram 28 is bliss !!Every narrow street and every tiny building may house a shop, an artists work shop and/or exhibition space, a restaurant or wine bar ..... surprises everywhere waiting to be discovered.

Steep hills but fun to explore. This is a great area for restaurants, bars and night life. During the day, you can see the views of the city from here due to all of the hills and steps. At night, people come out to mingle, eat and drink. It's a very happening area of the city. The prices for most of these restaurants are reasonable as well since Lisbon isn't too expensive compared to other European cities. The thing I really liked most about this area and Lisbon in general, is how nice people are. It was so refreshing after being in Spain where people aren't big fans of tourists, especially in Barcelona. Customer service is wonderful, even the guards at the airports are just so nice. Kids are very loved here, so our kids got a lot of attention. I just wish that this city was a little easier to walk on. Don't try walking heels here or having strollers, there's tons of steps and hills!
Wander to your hearts content. I love to wander the different neighborhoods and this one is great! Visited during the day so I cannot say what it is like at night.
Fun to wander. Wear a good pair of walking shoes. You'll encounter steep hills, but what wonderful cobble streets, shops, and restaurants. Here is the real Lisbon.

Back to our College Days. walking around Bairro Alto during the day is charming with a maze of streets and interesting shops. By night it transforms into a winding, crazy street party. The bars have music, booze, and lots of people. With nice weather, a great place to stroll and people watch

Vibrant and interesting old Lisbon. So many bars, restaurants, Fado clubs, shops etc. Really great atmosphere and great to visit in the day as well as the night. Lots of tourist traps so make sure to check the menus pricing before you commit and there are lots of people touting their "fantastic food" obviously some are better than others but there is a vast range so keep going until you find one you like. Certainly worth a visit, if you haven't been here on your trip to Lisbon then you haven't seen the best of the city.

Great Location to Experience Lisbon.... We are staying just a couple of streets off of Rua de Rosa and it is very typical of the area... beautiful! There is a good mix in the neighborhood as our street is very quiet but only steps from ones which are very lively. Everything to experience Lisbon is here, or just a short (but hilly!) Walk away. Soak up everything you can!

Best area to walk arround in the evening. walked around in Bairro Alto area in the evening.You can see lot of people around mostly tourists.The area is dotted with road side and other restaurants,small time and branded shops. the more than couple of squares are buzzing with activities .We saw two boys showing dancing skills, ring maker, painters,and other artists.All varities of food is available in the joints from buffet, to ala carte.Over all nice area to spend 4-5 hrs.

It can go from a couple of beer to complete self-destruction. I lived some years in Lisbon and I spent more time than I can remember at Bairro Alto (college days). It is a great place to go whether you are local or foreign because you have all kinds of bars: local bars, erasmus bars, fado bars, electronic music bars, gay bars, shot bars, wine bars, anyway you get the idea. And, although Bairro Alto has been becoming slightly less... how shall it put it... traditional, every passing year, everyone who has lived in Lisbon most surely loves Bairro Alto. Keep a sharp eye in your belongings and if you are going to get wrecked make sure you do it with people you trust. You will most likely get sold drugs as you walk the streets later in the night, accept it at your own risk and know that you will most surely get ripped 9 out of 10 times.

Mostly for the party people. If you like clubbing/bars/nightlife this is the party central. During the day you can stroll around, there are some cute looking buildings but unfortunately graffiti and trash (from the nightlife) dominate. There are some good restaurants. Be careful with the people walking around offering suspicious items.

Enjoy the sights and sounds. We walked around a lot in Lisbon, wondering through the streets and enjoying the architecture.Good variety of restaurants in the little side streets which are full of Lisbon character.

Best part of Lisbon. We spent a lot of time walking around Lisbon and thought that this area was by far the best to spend time in. Lots of bars, restaurants and stores to cater for all and a great place to people watch. We were fortunate that our hotel (Agenda Palace - see separate review) was conveniently located to all of the attractions on offer here.

Great Area For Eats and/or Shops. Nice area to wander around with a wide variety of restaurants in the little side streets which are full of Lisbon character. Easy way t get up is use the fernicular that goes up from Restauradores...
Party!. Looking for a party? more bars than i can count, cheap, thousands of nice ppl! The variety of bars is just astonishing

Quaint Little Bars and Restaurants. We had a great night in Bairro Alto (although not as long as it could have been as we were shattered). First stop was a little bar with cocktails for a very modest 5euros each and where the owner was very happy to chat to us at the bar and offer some tips on visiting Lisbon. We then went for a lovely meal in a quirky little restaurant that was very reasonably priced. Expect lots of bars and restaurants about as big as a good sized family lounge and an authentic Portuguese experience. The area is quite steep (so ladies beware of wearing your high heels) and although there is a funicular, we thought it was quite expensive at a around 3 euros each for a very short ride.

Disappointed. Having lived in Lisbon in the past, we were looking forward to a stroll in the Bairro Alto. But we felt that the area has gone downhill a lot: it looked unkempt and unloved, with lots of graffiti disfiguring the buildings and even Amalia Rodriques' great Fado house "O Forcado". So sad.
Brilliant night life. For the nights out hopping from a bar to another. Good vibes and lots of people around inside and out of the bars

This is where the party is at. This was THE place to go to for a Friday night out on town in Lisbon. We reached there about 11pm and the party was just getting started. Alcohol is quite reasonably priced here, there are loads of interesting bars that you can hop into, and as the night progresses, the music gets better and the dance floors get packed. We left early in the morning after a great night of partying.
Nice View. Everyone goes here to take a selfie/panorama. I recommend you grab your selfie stick and do the same.

Interesting little bars but did not like the area. To be honest a few people had said it was a place you have to visit but I was not impressed. We visited an "Irish Bar" run by a guy in a wig with no top on who was clearly not "Irish". They sold British Ciders and beers but somehow thought sticking a few nostalgic Irish logos, signs or memorabilia about made it into an Irish Bar... we left after 1 drink! We continued onto a small Jazz Bar which we enjoyed, it was busy so we had to wait a few minutes for a seat but enjoyed the atmosphere and cocktails. We then went onto a small disco bar which again we enjoyed. Now for the down side... there are a lot of (we were told) gypsies in the area who offer you drugs as you walk up the street. They make you feel extremely uncomfortable. At one stage as my partner had gone to the bar and I was in view of the window 4 of them gathered and stared in at me making nose signals indicating did I want drugs, I tried to ignore them and turned slightly but I felt extremely nervous then and wanted to just get out of the area as quickly as possible. If the police were more present the area may be somewhere I’d recommend as it is quirky and different but after my personal experience I wouldn’t go back...

Go Here. I stayed in Bairro Alto. This is the best neighborhood and the reason I feel in love with Lisbon. The tiled buildings are so unique, the lookout is breathtaking, but the night life is the best part. The bars open their doors to the public and people crowd the streets to drink and mingle. It was the best time I've had going out in all of Europe!

Great area for bars. We really liked the Barrio Alto area for bars and restaurants, we were out late on Friday and Saturday nights and felt perfectly safe. We did get offered dope a couple of times, but it was never more than an enquiry and made me smile rather than be offended.Be warned though girls, do wear your "flatties" if you are walking far because of the cobbles and the hills

Brilliant!. There are so many bars, cafes and restaurants to visit in this district it is hard to know where to start. Some look a bit unprepossessing but can turn out to be great; others look trendy enticing but can disappoint. Take your pick - it's fun finding ones you like.
A Must See !!!. It has to be seen, Walked, Shopped and enjoyed at your own pace.... Early morning or late evening is Magical...

Lovely and Sao Roque is not to be missed. Took a trip up the Gloriana tram and then to Sao Roque Church and museum - beautiful. the views from the park beside the tram exit provides a wonderful vista over the City. Bairro Alto is old narrow and twisty and is interesting to see. In all a pleasant way to spend a morning.

Nice place. Very old and interesting area to walk around. Fill with locals and tourists and lots of little shops, bars and restaurants. You can either reach by a tram or walk up steep hill to reach here.

Lots of choice. This area has lots of bars and restaurants to chose from it seems never ending. As you walk around you have people promoting their establishments handing out flyers and cards. Lots of the bars have live music which we found excellent, many of the bars display their prices outside on menu board which we found pleasing also we found the prices so reasonable.As we went in February the area was pretty quiet but we were told in high season the place is buzzing . Some of the bars allow customers to smoke. Its well worth a visit.
nigh live. here you can find everything, bars, restaurants, hostels, hotels, very nice places to go with friends...until late evening. I enjoy a lot.

A fun area to walk around.. lots of nice smaller restaurants, parks, shops in this hill top area. If you are not into walking hills, take a bus or the trolley car up to the top....nice views of the city too.

Nightlife, Dining and Entertainment. In Bairro Alto you'll find many fine dining restaurants with live fado (Portuguese music genre) music. On the weekends you'll find a lively, thriving bar and nightlife experience down every side street. It is a pretty awesome experience that I'd recommend to anyone visiting! Enjoy :)

Historical buildings and crazy nightlife. The buildings there are very beautiful and historical interesting.Moreover, the night life there is something that you have to explore.It's something like that you just go out for some drinks, but it ends up that you come home drunk and late in the morning.The drinks are cheap, good and not rare of alcohol ;) 0,5 liter pina colada was € 4,- I think.At around 2 o'clock in the morning it gets quite empty, because most of the people go to the clubs, but the pubs are still opened then.So for some good time with your friends - go there!
Nice to walk. Walking thru history, great restaurants and shops. The character of the area is like your at a different time in history.

Out & About. Lively atmosphere and great street musicians. Loads of restaurants & cafes to choose from. We sat outside for over an hour just watching people go by and some local musician playing.
There are lots of known shops too for that bit of shopping.

A touristy area that gets noisy by night. We were staying in the area, because it's so central and already on the hill.
Most of it, especially the lower part, is a bit of a disappointment. Full of cheap souvenir shops and pretty awful bars, you'll be better off in either upper parts of the area, or elsewhere altogether.

Very nice area!. Bairo Alto is both in daytime as at night a very nice area. There are many good restaurants and shops. Especially at Rua Dom Pedro there are a lot of shops which are great to wander around. A must to go there when you are in Lissabon.

What a place to watch the sunset :). We visited at about 6 o'clock in the evening and were lucky to find a table. Gorgeous spot with lovely views especially over sunset. We shared a bottle of Vihno Verdi and watched the Sun go down. It had a great atmosphere as well as the views and I would definitely recommended it.
Fado Bairro Alto. Very good place to hear fado while you're eating. the ambient is very good and nice. it's a good place when you want to have action.
Best nightlife in Lisbon. Good restaurants, music, tradition, clubs, stores.... love it all!! Fun for the young and the young at heart. The best place to experience Fado Vadio!
Vibrant heritage city part. THE place to go if you like narrow streets, hundreds of bars and local restaurants and, not to forget, beautiful old buildings.

Great area for walking and trying different places. Spent an evening just wandering in the area, good for restaurants bars and music, so much to see in a reasonably walkable area.Not so great for wheelchair access or those with difficulty walking.

Nice place to stroll around. This area reminds me to the old town.The street is quite narrow and building seems to be old as well.It is a good place to walk around for hours.In evening this place is a party place, so if you have small kid, I suggest to avoid this place.In daylight, it is home for many gift and souvenirs shop and restaurant as well.To go here you can take Elevador da Gloria close to Miradouro Sao Pedro de Alcantara.
fun place.. Great place to stay and walk around and fabulous restaurants. Really gets going in evening whens stores bars restaurants open

Bairro Alto - the almost medieval, post-colonial hood. I was looking to buy some hashish and I went straight to Bairro Alto. I went walking, as I am not one of those lazy tourists who get on the tram uphill. I like it cuz it's rough, yet multicultural. The crowded, narrow streets going uphill, covered in cobble stone, the architecture (so much Portuguese ceramic), churches, spaces to be explored, people to run into, pickpockets, kids playing football and old ladies hanging clothes. It's authentic, not sugar-coated, a living area in the city, where the traditional and the new confront and colllide. Ive fund my dealers,some very well read kids, who lured me first by playing loud some french rap on their smartphone. I approached them, had some Brock beer (the kids were Sporting Lisbon fans) and we shared a spliff as the sun went down. What a day. It's the rough area of the city, but still not as rough as Alfama or Amadora, on the city limits.

I always love old neighborhoods. We really did not spend enough time here and should have but there was so much else that we wanted to explore that we couldn't do everything in depth. You don't have to be into the bar and restaurant scene to enjoy the Bairro Alto; there are museums, churches and architecture to be explored--for those who like that kind of stuff. Next time we visit, Barrio Alto will get more of our attention.
Romantic. Small streets, lots of bars and restaurants, nice atmosphere. Just perfect place to relax and enjoy this beautiful city :) Big like!

"Bairo Alto or get out and have a party". Definitely worth a visit, bit of a trek uphill first but rewarded with marvellous narrow streets full of bars, restaurants, and cheap coctails. Almost everyday is like festival here, specialy lively at night time. Restaurants tend to be on smallist size but it adds to the atmosphere. Generally need to be patient and queue but well worth it. Just go for it and have a beer for 2 Euros!

Bairo Alto. Definitely worth a visit, bit of a trek uphill first but rewarded with marvellous bars and restaurants. Very lively at night time. Restaurants tend to be on smallist size but we felt it added atmosphere. Generally need to be patient and queue but well worth it.
Get social. Narrow streets full of bars, restaurants, and cheap coctails. Almost everyday is like festival here.
Place to Party. Nice people, nice place to dinner and to hang out for the night. A very characteristic place from Lisbon old town. Here you can find people and bars from all types. Wonderful.

have fun!. There are a lot of bars, restaurants and Fado's places. You have to go there, for dinner, drinks, or dance!! Live concerts in some of the bars and surprisingly, in some bars it's allowed to smoke... So, there is place for everybody there...

THE PERSONAL VIEW. WHEN ..as a tourist, we begin to tire of the tried and true path of shopping stores and regular sites, slightly off the beaten track are the places the locals go to or live in--such is the Bairro Alto. On the walls as you enter are the famous and infamous of the neighborhoods as well as prints on the walls of some of the local elderly. This area is considered home to the birthplace of Fado and has several buildings that used to be homes or ill repute (brothels) it is from these racy surroundings that some of the greatest voices of Fado emerged, their own lives full of the drama and tragedy that gives Fado its fervor and melancholy. The city took some of these places and redid them making them places that people could go to learn and experience Fado.The screen prints on the walls as well as some very artistic and much sought after graffiti is the result of local artists some Portugese and some ex pats from France and Great Britain--these ladies have become an integral, valued and much loved part of the community because they emerged themselves in the neighborhood.As you walk these streets there are small shops, and above the homes on the second floor are doors with flower pots wrapped in cloths, there are wooden doors with no balconies which seem to open to maybe inner courtyards if what we peeked was correct, Colorful wash draped some of the building walls and there were the usual colorwashes of pastel colors on the homes.The ex pat created a small area for children and even draped quilt sleeves on some of the trees, sort of colorful turtle necks--this is a living and working neighborhood punctuated with shops for light libations and colorful art. This is a place to come to and stroll and to find out finally, about the local people--it is a very personal and private area, with people tending to each other and their neighbors and making a place so in love and loyal that they do much to keep their elderly home so that they do not have to leave their homes to go to nursing facilities.it is beautiful, pretty quiet and very picturesque and tucked into various places are food shops and restaurants many, with an ethnic twist.This is the type of place that provides a counterpoint to all the obvious tourists places--this place is not for show and the people as well as the buildings are amazingly real and beautiful--I think, at least for us, this was a MUST and it helped to put some of what we saw or heard in context and certainly, it made our love of Fado even more intense.
night is never over!. you cant get enough of this amazing part of Lisboa:its s partytime everynight!sangria porto wine and caipirinhas!and the location is superb
Lively and fun ... Lots of stuff going on and I believe it is very busy at night-time. Still on Tram route 28 so easy to get to.

Bairro-Alto. Great place for sightseeing and shoping. Just outside of the above Metro station, great buzzing place. Plenty of tourists and plenty to see. Take the 1900's vertical lift up to the Como Convent.

Must visit if you like to party! ;). Very interesting party place! More then 150+ restaurants, small night clubs, caffe bars, pubs... :)
Prices of alcohol are very responsable for West Europe. Many people from all over the world, but very safe place,with great atmosphere, i visited it 4 times and never saw incidents etc. Local people are very friendly.

Walkon by.... It's a neighborhood perfect for a walk but having in mind that the use of backpacks and purses is dangerous!Lots of bars, restaurants and a few Fado houses but if you want to avoid messy situations don't be there after midnight on weekend nights.The buildings resisted the 1755 earthquake so we can see a part of the city that remained almost untouched in the last 5 centuries.

See Lisbon of the XVI Century !. We enjoyed walking these winding streets and browsing the shops. This is an elegant, poetic, bohemian part of town.It was created in XVI century as part of the housing traders whose actions were in the lower part of the city Baixa.Later rich people are buying houses here-they wanted to be as far away from poor people who lived in Alfama.

HIGH ABOVE IT ALL. This area of Lisbon is old world mixed with bohemia brand new! The streets are narrow and cobbled; while there is a night life incomparable to many cities! A world of caution....DON'T ATTEMPT to drive here. You can get the GLORIA tram up to the top, walk (quite a vigorous climb) or take a tram or taxi.The restaurants and bars are crowded into the wee hours and there is always something happening..........shopping and sightseeing during the day; old shops to wander thru and all night music/dancing and many family run restaurants where the food is incredible. We had one of our best meals at a fado club in the Bairro Alto. A must do when in Lisbon....

Do not forget an ice cream and buy a book. One of amazing place to walk in Lisbon. Has a fantastic ice cream and historic libraries. At Summer the people are very happy and fun. Don't forget to visit the both side churchs at principal street, even you are not catholic.
No other nightplace like this. As young people, you must go there. So many bars & peoples in so tiny spaces/streets !Great fun, pretty cheap. Just be aware that some peoples steal out there ;)
trending spot. if you want to meet lot of young people visit Bairro Alto at night,There are many restaurants bars and shops.During the day is quieter and you can see the inhabitants.Don´t miss

Centar of city nightlife. This is an elegant, poetic, bohemian part of town.It was created in XVI c as part of the housing traders whose actions were in the lower part of the city Baixa.Later rich people are buying houses here-they wanted to be as far away from poor people who lived in Alfama.  Today it is the center of night life.Restaurant to restaurant,bar to bar...taverns....restaurants with fado music.It's full of people.You can buy a drink at one bar and than drink down the street and than continue to drink to drink in another bar.Simply does not know where one bar begins and where it ends of other.In the air is muzic, laughing, cheerful voices locals, tourists...who seeking fun. Be careful, there are plenty of sellers of narcotics.Every Monday, many of the bars or restaurants are not working or close rather early. In the beginning you may confuse the tangle of streets, but eventually somehow get used to the orientation. Until this work can come from the lower parts of the city by cable car, walk the stairs. At day was it is quite empty,but there is at some art shop, gift shop...unique boutique. But you must visit this place during the day because there is a park terraces with great views-viewpoint-monastery Convento de Carmo now museum, Theatre Trinidad and lot of beauty atractions.

Music, music and more outstanding music. Don't be a wimp and do not get too trashed too early because 'Tonight's gonna be a good night, tonight's gonna be a good good night. I've got a feeling.............' Bairro alto lasts well into the early morn. Fado, if it's your bag for have a more traditional feel, and then anything goes. I've listened to everything and I've not been disappointed, only when I've had to leave, ignore the nutters and have a do.

Go in the evening!. Its a hike, but if you're game you can skip the funicular and hike through Barrio Alto. Like Rio, you get a sense of community with people milling from bar to bar and music running into each place. A fun night out, in a historic area.

Crazy place!. This place is full of character. It is where you go if you want music and late night drinking. People drink outside the pubs on the cobbled streets as there is limited space in the pubs. One bit of advice for the girls who are visiting here, DO NOT wear heels. It would be impossible to walk over the cobbles etc in them.

Historic Area With Lots Of Bars!. Well worth a visit during daylight as well as the vibrant bar scene which begins around midnight and goes to dawn. Many interesting shops in historic buildings, such as an ecclesiastical candle maker, rare books and apothecaries. Don't miss the historic cable car down to the water front. Several historic churches on a more managble scale than cathedrals welcome you to services. Unfortunately the chain stores are moving in. Did I mention that the bar prices are reasonable with no tips expected, but watch for late night pickpockets.

Great area to eat!. Some will argue that it has gotten too touristy so that may put me in the minority but I still believe this neighborhood caters to locals and tourists alike. I thoroughly enjoyed walking these winding streets and browsing food menus. I never had a bad meal in the area nor were the prices hiked up because of the big tourist influx. I think you can't get a good feel for Lisbon without going to this neighborhood, pulling up a chair at an outdoor cafe and enjoying the sights and sounds of Lisbon.

Great place at night (not daytime!). This is a great area however save your time by leaving your visit to the evening. Be prepared to walk around a very crowded area but lots of fun and friendly people. During the day it was totally different, everything is shut up and it's just dirty with no atmosphere - this changes at night time (maybe we didn't see the dirt) and was a fabulous experience.

Like Europe 30 years ago. Research your restaurants before going .....I had recommends from locals ...Busy with locals and some tourists - Reminds me of Europe 30 years ago - we headed there many nights for a drink, dinner or both

Keep your eyes peeled and then relax into it. This area is a must experience for the festive feel of the Lisbon people. I enjoyed the charm in the decay and even the grafiti in this historic area. In the day it's great for photos and finding a place to have a drink later at night because in the evening it's not ideal for wandering around. Perhaps due to tiny tavernas the Portugues people spill on to the Streets with their drinks giving a carnival feel every night. That said, as a New Yorker I was on guard while walking around at night. With so much narrow crowded Streets I kept my wallet in my front pocket, left vital IDs, creditcards at the hotel and brought only enough cash for the night. I would keep on the main Streets and not wander off on to narrow alley or stairways. Many drugdealers gets too close for my comfort. But after that...just relax and enjoy because it is really a unique area.
Too touristic.. Nothing spcial to see. Only a place for tourists. All restaurants around are expensive and most of theme, as we found out, were ouverpriced. Just go around, but don't stop!

Great place for food and fun!. Went to Barrio Alto to try the bars and many restaurants. There is a place for everyone. We tried a seafood place to sample the local catch and drink the local wines and ports. We also went to a crowded restaurant to sample sardines, cod, octopus and clams. Very tasty. The owners would normally come at the end of the meal to offer all a shot of port. Wonderful!

favourite area of lisbon. its charming, its full of restaurants and bars, it's busy and bustling during the evening and quiet during the day, the steep, winding streets are full of history and lovely to look at. I love this neighbourhood.

International party district!. First I came over the neighbourhood I thought that it is over rated and pretty dangerous. Well, most erroneous assumption! It appeared very welcome with most of the international crowd and positive people. All variety of bars and coctails. Very touristic though and not sophisticated you can find your own crowd and fun there even though you might be there alone with no friends. You will find new one there ;)
Nightlife of Lisbon. If you are looking for the nightlife of Lisbon, you found it!Don't go no further, you will find here a bar to your likings for sure.

Great place for Night and eatting. If you want some bars and night place, this is the place.Good restaurants and bars, near to Cais de sodre (other place to go)Can walk for Bairro Alto and see the place, and check the churchs nears to Chiado
Bring your walking shoes!. Not as special as Alfama, but a nice neighbourhood to walk through. Going up and down, so bring good shoes and take your time.
nice neighborhood. cafes and restaurants. you need a few hours to enjoy the area.when you are in the city if you dont mind climbing hills you can walk there *- or you can take the 28 Tram

Nice. A very remote area of lisbon, prepare to walk steeply up. Many nice little café's where one can have a typically Portuguese espresso at only 70 cents. Lots of nice architecture and little churches.
Too much grafity.... Lovely neighbourhood. But overrated. Too much grafity everywhere ! A waste. But a very nice area to visit. Lots of bars, small restaurants. A must see in this city.
Great walk. Put on those walking shoes and start walking. Explore as much as you can and take it all in. Allow a few hours or more.

Pleasant place. Bairro Alto is an old place in central area of Lisbon, which is very easy to get to by metro. During the day is nice to walk through the narrows streets and watch the downtown at gazebos. At the night the streets turn into crowded spaces by lots of people looking for bars and nightclubs.But, prudence its a good advice everywhere. So, be awake and avoid desert areas cause there are a lot of drugs dealers and pickpockets surrounding this places.
A must for nightcrawlers. Very nice area, plenty people in the streets, lots of bars and restaurants. Nice Fadobar, big Mojitos. Only thing thats negative is all the drugdealers :(

Good place to visit. Bairro Alto is one of the oldest parts of the city after the Alfama. You may find a lot of small restaurants and bars. You shoud visit this place after 10 pm and eat a lot of very good seafood dishes and drink delicious porto!
Beautiful. A must-see in Lisbon. One of the oldest parts of the city, picturesque and charming, with lots of restaurants and bars to choose from.

Fantastic old quarter of Lisbon. Lisbon is situated on a number of hills on the coastline of the vast sheltered estuary of the River Tagus. Bairro Alto is situated on one of those hills and provides a compact microcosm of the life of the city. Narrow cobbled streets straggle up and across the steep hill, many are served by the traditional trams (try to avoid the hideous tourist trams blaring out loud music!) and the steeper Escalador funiculars. Get a day pass for the city transport and Lisbon is easy to get around.There are great little bars and restaurants in every backstreet and we found the best pastelleria in the area of Rossio, where you can watch the traditional custard pastries being hand made, and can eat them warm straight from the oven.Lisbon is a great city to walk through but sadly there are pickpockets both in the street and metro. Our backpack was nimbly opened by a girl of about 15 but luckily returned the stolen purse when confronted then ran off.We stayed at Casa de Santos B&B near the market which was a great find.

A lot of popular restaurants with fado music. Bairro Alto is one of the oldest parts of the city after the Alfama. Lots of steep narrow streets, well-connected trams. A lot of popular restaurants with fado music, where you should definitely stop by and try the famous cod with a glass of green wine, which is also a trademark of Portugal.
Fun night. There are bars, restaurants and shops everywhere. The streets are tiny but filled with people esp around 11pm onwards. Wonderful place

Do not go at night. It's a beautiful old part of town but not safe at night. I felt threatened and a friend has his pocket picked in a bar. He knew exactly who had done it and when he politely and non confrontationally asked to have his money back it all turned ugly and we were chased with rocks and stones being thrown at us. The bar staff just smirked in amusement so it's obviously a known situation. The security at our hotel informed us it's not unusual to happen at night to tourists. If you go, do it in daylight and definitely don't carry anything in your pockets and keep your hands on your bag at all times!

street labyrinth full of pleasant surprises. Impossible not to fall in love with these tiny narrow streets, that cross each other, end-up, appear, make one to get lost and then.. discover small cozy cafes, fado bars, wineries, galleries, - the true and authentic face of Lisboa..
Nice area for nightlife. If you look for cozy restaurants and bars, it is the right place! Also lot of shops in this area. Nearby all sights

Amazing place to wander around... minus all the offers of drugs. This place has its little charm when you wander into all the alleys, stopping off for a drink or bite in the cosy bars/restaurants... and at the end you can wander down the hill to either the viewpoint or tram 28...or if you want the single line tram (don't think its part of the Lisbon network so its extra €3.50?)only let down is all the druggies offering drugs for sale.
The best!. Best restaurants, best bars, best B/B, best Hostels, best neibourhood, quiet during the day, happy and festive in the evening.

very nice. walk up the many little streets there are many restaurants, cafes, bars you will be spoilt for choice. Very crowded on weekends and cars do somehow drive along these little narrow lanes how people don't get run over is a miracle just press yourself closely to a wall lol. Always a friendly and lively buzz in the air stay away from the randoms trying to sell weed or whatever, not worth the risk. Otherwise go enjoy and have a fab night out

The place to go in Lisbon at night!. Very traditional part of the city. Most buildings are beautiful and a huge selection of bars and restaurants to choose from. The most vibrant part of the city at night. Must go!

Had so much fun....in Barrio Alto. We went and had dinner...then decided to join all the masses...walking up the steep hills ..I am sure there were over 1000 stairs ..well it's called Alto for a reason...= high .....we later found out the tram goes there too ....there are little clubs and bars and restaurants., in this little medieval town ...and although you can drink inside the bars most people seem to enjoy drinking in the streets and yes you can walk around with your drink through the streets...policeman roam the streets but there is no trouble...There is also good restaurants with live Fado music! And if you Find it. there is a long set of Stairs where people are drinking and singing Fado. As you keep exploring the streets you end up walking to the beautiful look outs ..of Lisbon...bars close at 3am....to get home plenty of taxis roaming around ....

This place is great. The small streets make you feel like you went back in time. I went there every day of my trip for a drink, or at evening for having dinner. There are many view points where you can sit, drink a glass of AMAZING wine and just enjoy the view.
Typical area of Old Lisbon, great bars. Bairro Alto is very fashionable for a night out, Lisbon by night is here and this is where the locals hang out, great bars and restaurants, its not expensive.

Heart of Lisbon at night!. Bairro Alto is a must visit if you are in Lisbon! This is a cool place to go out during the night for bars, clubs and also good restaurants with live Fado music! It is very close to famous Chiado which is also very nice. You can walk and enjoy the atmosphere hours without getting bored. Most of the bars are open till the morning. Get yourself lost in puzzled alleys and neighboring streets!
Typical Portuguese. It's typical portuguese district. Best by night with a lot of alehouses. I nice place to spend a night with friends.

The Living Heart of Lisbon. We, a family of four adults and one 4 year old, stayed in a nicely renovated apartment in an old building on the Rua de Pocos Negros, right in the heart of the old town. We enjoyed the constant stream of traffic below our balcony -- cars, mortorbikes, Tram 28, merchants, tourists and bar-hoppers. It was a bit noisy at times, especially late at night -- but that's what the screens and shutters are for!It was usually pretty difficult to get on the Tram 28 but it was an easy walk into the center of Lisbon where we could take the very efficient underground or the lesser-used trams.There are stores of every kind along every street, so it's really easy to keep in groceries, wine and anything else you might want..
Cool. This is a really terrific old neighborhood, plus it's good exercise getting here. Lots of fun bars and restaurants. Had the best shrimp ever here. Easy to get lost.

No recommendation needed.. The historical bairro (`neighbourhood`) is organized into a matrix of roads and lanes. Each and every one of them is packed with cocktail bars, tapas bars,… = bars. Despite the huge amount of restaurants in this area, it is better to make a reservation if you found a favorite one. Places can be quiet packed, and certainly not only during the weekend. The guide form a touristic walk we did explained many of the bars in the area were forced to close their doors at 2.00 am due to noise complaints. But in 2009 The restriction was revised with an extension to 3.00 am.
Nice. Cool place to go out during the night for bars and clubs and also good restaurants around. It is also very close to Chiado which is very nice also.

Fantastic place!. I remember when I was living for one year in Lisbon, I have spend there so many weekend night with my friends, friendly outdoor drinking atmosphere, nations mosaice :), if you like night life, you really need to go there :) the funny thing is that when I was there during the day, I could easly get lost in that naighborhood, it looks completely different in the day light :)

Food, bars, hills!. It's uphill into Barrio Alto from Lisbon centre (Baixa), but completely worth the effort. Great choice of bars, restaurants, and clubs, if you aren't an old fogey like me. You can also cheat and get the tram/funicular for 3.60 Euros - if you are a wimp or have a heart condition!

A must visit area. Wandering the streets soaking up the atmosphere and samplingThe cafés and Tapas bars in this area was interesting and exciting.!This area comes alive at night and it was fantastic to sit outside sipSome good wine listen to the music and feel part of this city!

Great for shopping and eating. I stayed at a hostel in Bairro Alto when visiting Lisbon. There are great restaurantes with portuguese food. There are also lots of stores for shopping and the nightlife is great.

For a few / quite a few drinks. Definitely this is the place for night life. Very lively over the weekend at night, lots and lots of charming little bars with great atmosphere, practically one after the other. Some nice places for dinner too.
Visit at night. The area is famous for its nightlife - daytime visit is less enjoyable. Yet traditional local funicular offer fun for these hours too.

Excelent walk , shopping area some restaurants to eat. Old neighborhood , shopping area , you can get a funicular / tram that goes on a steep hill from Praca Restauradores , opposite side of Hard Rock Cafe there is an excellent Mirador at the end of the tram , on the way to the Barrio you can see an a great church and the runs of a basilica or cathedral that was trashed at the 1755 earthquake , major disaster of Lisbon in the e17 th century
Awesome night out. This is a must visit sight in Lisbon. During the night on Friday and Saturday it is fill with young people that are drinking on the street. Super

Great nightlife. Great nightlife, exciting authentic bars. especially for gay people the place to be because a lot of gaybars are situated there. But also to be recommended at straight people :) Great vieuw over the city from the miradoro. Tip everywhere in town you see the sign miradoro it meens excellent vieuwing point, so just follow directions and you get there.

once upon a time…. This typical district of Lisbon has life all day long. The small roads and the commercial areas mixed with the bars and restaurants make it appealing for the visitor. Go and take your time as it's worth to be digested slowly.
Walk and eat place. Interesting part of Lisabon. Small streets, restaurants on every corner or few meters. Safe to walk in the evening
Entertainment. If you are in Lisbon, definitely check this little area. In the evening, it's full of young people and music. A perfect way to end your day :)
Wow. That place is amazing, over 200 bars and so much people that drink outside and inside. The choice and everything there makes me thirsty :-D nice place to drink before you go into a club!
The restaurant area!. The best restaurants are located at the "Bairro Alto" área. You can get there trough the hop on hop of bus. The view. From the city and the river is also fantastic!

Very pittoresque part of the city.. I explore a lot of these narrow steep street, refusing to go up with the funicular. From the top, in the garden you have a fantastic view over the city down and the castel Saint Jorge.
Last evening. We visited this area on the last evening Fabulous views over the city and a lovely outdoor cafe serving great coffee and pastries
Charming and thriving. Very charming area with narrow streets and thriving life. Very enjoyable for dinner and especially for a night out.

Pumping at night. The streets are bustling with students and tourists alike.
Cafes and bars overflowing on the street.
A lot of colour and movement to watch and be a part of…
Get to this area later in the night and go through till the wee hours especially Friday-Saturday

Weekend in Lisbon. To really get a true gauge of the nightlife of Lisbon, you need to visit Bairro Alto and the Fado houses. We ate in one listening to a girl accompanied by 2 men, one with a guitar, the other with a viola. Although the singing was rather melancholy, it certainly was a great experience.

Great athmosphere. It is a great place for young and not so young people to spend time in the evening. All the streets are full with people, music, food. Everyone is happy. You should try all the streets, even if you don't know where it will take you

Living La Vida Lisbon. During my first night in Lisbon, my friend took me to the most happening part of the city for nightlife. We had to get the metro from Marques Du Pombal but when we arrived I was quite amazed by all the little bars in quaint side streets and just how happening the area was. We visited a couple of bars and I was pleased (but also pleasantly amazed) I could also get something to eat there. I was very glad to get something there that made me feel right at home in the simple pleasures of a cheese and ham toastie then after I had some energy food I was ready to let my hair down. I enjoyed some local speciality drinks in the form of a margarita, caperina and also a couple of caiporoshes....after that I certainly let my hair down. Great atmosphere and the locals very friendly with one assisting me in some alternative salsa dancing. Fun and very lively.....loved it!
Fantastic views. A fantastic area to look over the City and see places that you would like to visit. Also good to wander round the local antique stalls.
Night life. Good urban night life, nice atmosphere, people spilling out from restaurants and bars in to the street, range of people, quite bohemian, feels safe

One of the most atmospheric parts of Lisbon. This is a beautiful part of the city scattered around its hills with lovely small crooked streets full of cute little bars and pubs. The views are gorgeous, especially at night. Truly beautiful, especially with the historic trams running up and down the hill.

Opposite the Alfama district. Bairro Alto is situated accross Alfama on the western part of Lissbon. Take one of the electric streetcars or the famous vertical elevator (Eiffel) to go from the verious shops (low to high end) at the lower part to the higher region of the city. Again, lots of shops but mainly historical buildings. Make sure you visit the half restored ruins of the old cathedral.

Best nightlife in Lisbon. Been many times to Bairro Alto over the past ten years and the area has only gotten better as I've discovered more bars and my local friends have introduced me to corner 'bars' where you can buy €3 caipirinhas, caipiroshkas or beers (no room for standing inside, that's what the street is for). The area is a grid of cobbled, semi-pedestrianized streets similar to the Old Compton Street area of Soho in London but absolutely packed in the evenings with patrons going in and out of bars or buying drinks from the cheap corner bars and standing outside. Both gay and gay-friendly, as well as straight and straight-friendly bars abound in this largely accepting neighborhood of this small but cosmopolitan city.

Give your legs a workout. Wander the back streets of the city centre (hilly back streets) to find little hidden gems. There are trams which are packed with locals & tourists but it's a fun way to get around.

Overestimated . The touristic industry of Lisbon organized very well by selling everything there is, a little more expensive and overpriced. We tried to find places where locals went but unsuccessful. Also be very careful of your belongings because of the many pickpockets and the absence of the police forcing us to almost get involved in a street fight.

Lisbon's "meltingpot" "quartier". A place to go, to stay enjoyng a drink in a ber or "in the street", crowded by different generacional layers, where you can have a nice dinner or listen to some music in a great bar or just live (night) life in the streets...

A pleasant night life!. It is a huge area. We visited the lower part not far away from the market. The street was filled with people having a good timet until after midnight. People wete happy and night life vibrant without anybody feeling insecure. It was easy to get a taxi when the bar was about to close, and we callex it a day.
what a mess!. it worth a walk of course,is very colorfull and nice but all the restaurants are so touristic with expensive prices for lisbon
Party town. There is an air of revelry in this place. When we were there there were streamers across most streets. This is where to come for a huge variety of distinct and varied eateries.
Dizzy heights. Fascinating area with quaint narrow streets hiding scores of quaint eating places. Dozens of squares with with pavement cafes and bars. Lots of unusual shops to browse.

great place to dine, drink and make new friends!. This place is great both if you are looking for good food, or if you wish to party hard during the night! at first the resturants move out their tables and make a great dinning outside scenery! then around 11 pm people start coming for the cheap and good drinks. you would think with maybe a thousand people every night there would be alot of trouble,but people are very good behaving and I have never seen any trouble! Great place to make new friends and enjoy life.

great area of lisbon. we did the tram ride that took in the alfama and barrio alto areas of Lisbon this is a really nice area to look around . we walked up here twice more during our time in Lisbon, there is a really nice shopping centre at the back of the main streets in city centre which is just behind the santa justa tower and as you come out at the front the road going uphill takes you to the barrio alta we passed a lovely ice cream shop on the left hand side going up the hill that has superb ices too

Small bars, very crowded. This place is interesting to see at night. Lots and lots of bars all over the place but very small and crowded. Lots of people spilling out onto the streets with their drinks. Our group was in their 50s and felt a bit out of place in this area as most are much younger. There are some Fado places in this area which we went to and enjoyed.

Worth the visit if you have time. If you are walking around Lisbon and have the time, I would definitely recommend visiting Bairro Alto. It is an authentic neighborhood on a hill (what in Lisbon isn't on a hill?) which has everything that a neighborhood should have, including the occasional tourist walking around. However, if your time is limited and you wind up having to choose between Bairro Alto and Alfama, take the latter every time.

Although it is has been changing is still a place to visit. Located on the centre of Lisbon an old quarter full life and traditional, with a lot of small local restaurants, has been changing to a night life quarter, not always calm as it was

an interesting neighbourhood but it kind of dirty. There are a lot of people who loved this neighbourhood, but i'm not one of them. I think is very dirty and by night is not very safe. It's true that there are many nice bars , pubs & clubs , but is not one of the nicest areas, from my point of view.

Nightlovers. Hello Travellers, this is a good place to get out at night, it has good places to dine some alternative shopping, and alternative bars & pubs, Its a crowded place in some seasons.
This is a good place to go.

Halloween treat. Went to the Benfica match and then headed into Bairro Alto afterwards for some dinner and drinks. What a lively place! Halloween made it all the more thrilling with the costumes, face paint. so many people walking past smiling and laughing and drinking. best place ever! grabbed ourselves a couple of cocktails from a local bar and joined the masses strolling around!

Unique. This is my favorite neighborhood in Lisbon. The feeling walking around through the narrow streets was just amazing. Great architecture and aesthetic shops, caffes and restaurants contribute in a beautiful overall feeling and it is definitely a neighborhood you should visit during your stay.
Neighborhood Walk. We were able to get a real feel for this neighborhood through a walk. Not as many hills to navigate, but interesting architecture and lots of restaurants and shops.
Night life. A nice area with restaurants and bars. A lot of young and nice people. This is one of the most charming part of Lisbon.
Wonderful outdoor cafes!. This is a must visit neighborhood! We walked this area in the early evening and and had a glass of wine and appetizers. The cafes and wine bars are charming!

If you want to know Lisbon by night - this is the place. Lively and lovely to wander through the small streets of Barrio Alto in the evening. Full with both locals and tourists it makes the place the real night life. Full of cafes, restaurants and Fado clubs.

Lively, even on a Tuesday.. We were curious as we had heard how crazy Bairro Alto can get. We went on a Tuesday night for food and some drinks and the area was very lively. The restaurants catered to all tastes and the spot we choose was delicious. The pub scene after was excellent, with bars ranging from solo singers to more hectic dance bars. Bairro Alto has something to please everybody on a night out.

The key to knowing Lisbon. Bairro Alto is, in my mind, the essence of Lisbon. It's a gritty, busy network of narrow cobblestone streets with many restaurants, bars and shops. If I were to live in Lisbon and wanted to experience "Lisbon-life", this is where I would live. There are many locals, young and old, living in the area and it is very safe. There are always people around, day or night. The streets are like a maze but that's a lot of the fun! There are a lot of wonderful restaurants to try but you definitely want to do some research as many seem to have short lives. There are also many tiny, cramped convenience stores where you can grab basic groceries, beer and wine. One of the downsides to the area is that every morning the streets are filled with bottles and cups from the previous night's drinking. The smell of urine can be strong, too, as public urination seems quite common. The sidewalks are very narrow (12-18" wide) and drivers expect that you will get out of the way for them; they don't slow for pedestrians!Our hotel was located in BA and we will definitely stay in the area when we return. It's where the action is.
charming. charming neighborhood with good restaurants and bars to choose from. It felt pretty safe, good ambiance!
Animation. Most busy area of the city : restaurants, shops, galleries, boutiques. Very artistic zone and animated. Easy access by walk or tram (28).

Favourite place for a drink in Lisbon!. Absolutely love Bairro Alto, full of people from all around the world. It's guaranteed if your the socialising type you'll meet people from every end of the world. Everyone is in a great mood, it's extremely busy but such a lively area. The streets are buzzing, make sure you don't get lost!

Easily the most fun district I've ever visited!!. This area is crazy! The entire ground level of this district is dedicated to bars & restaurants! On the weekend the bars get so busy that the party spills out onto the streets, and some streets get so packed you can barely walk through!! If you're a party-lover, I HIGHLY recommend this area! The restaurants are great too - you can find some amazing food in little hidden nooks & crannies!

Crazy area, but very good bars. The bars and restaurants in this area are fantastic and life happens on the street. I do not recommend a hotel directly in the party zone, that would be too loud. But you can easily have cocktails, food and party afterwards without walking more than 100 steps there...

What a startling area of contrasts...stunning. Amazing side streets, eclectic selection of restaurants and bars, interesting selection of independent outlets and stunning contrast between day and night. Funicular(s) are great fun too. Must see area to discover Lisbon at all levels

Great on an evening. This area has something for everyone! Whether its bars, live music, or great food, if your hungry and want to be seated straight away id advise going down 8, as this is when all the restaurants start to fill up. As for the bars, these tend to be quiet until about 11!

Exciting place!. This is where the good restaurants are, but they are sometimes hidden. We used our iPhone gps, but the addresses are sometimes misleading, as the place is around the corner. Weekends there are wild, especially with the narrow streets, pedestrians and cabs.

Quaint neighbourhood which comes alive at night. The Bairro Also is a maze of streets and by lanes during the day and a crowded happening place at night. During the daytime, the place is a quite neighbourhood which you can explore at your own pace and check out typical portugese homes. The buildings can be distinguished as pre & post earthquake with external supports on those buildings which survived the earthquake. During the night, the scene completely changes with huge throngs of people crowding the numerous bars & restaurants in the lanes. There is even a dedicated Erasmus corner where you can participate in crazy drinking and student parties. Great atmosphere for socializing and live music & performances keep happening at various squares in the Bairro Alto
If you are 25 or less!. Don't miss this. Pack crowed with young people, bar hopping and boy/girl watching. Nightlife, bars , narrow streets, good atmosphere!

A Cobbly, Up & Down Neighborhood. One of the three main sections of the old town area of Lisbon. Our hotel was in the Bairro Alto; we spent the first day getting in touch with the steep cobblestone sidewalks in this gritty neighborhood. It became easier as we found our way around. If you are not used to steep up & down streets, this area is difficult. As we navigated our ways better, we liked it better.

Night Life. Well, if you searching for night life and having a bit of fun, this is the place to visit. Every other street corner you find something to do, something to eat or a place to party! A true mediterranean experience!

There are more interesting old towns. Lots of uphill hiking, not as quaint as many other old towns, lots of touristique dining and drinking. Well reviewed restaurants are harder to find. Don't go without a map!

Great Night Life. Lots of restaurants and bars. Don't go to the restaurants where people are on the streets dragging tourists in, they are generic menus and poor service. We had out best meal and wine here and very reasonably priced. Lots of Fado if you want and cherry brandy served in plastic glasses till late from a kiosk in the square.
fantastic break. A warren of great pubs live music wine bars shops and fab places to eat cannot fault the area it comes to life at night
BA. A maze of small streets with many restaurants, shops, and bars. Great people watching and interesting old archtecture.

Labyrinth. Quiet in the day and crowded at night. Multitude of restaurants but most of them too touristic and far too expensive to Portugese standards ( pity) pick,out the good ones.. Nice outside socialising and drinking...

old town, old history , old houses, love it. I like go back to the history, old days, ....we love it...very nice place to visit to understand the real Lisbon, small streets, old construction, tranway the best way to go...and feel the real Lisbon.
Where the action is. What a fun place to stay. We really enjoyed walking all around the area. There was plenty of restaurants, shopping & people watching

maze. Low residential buildings stacked up along narrow sloping streets which form a maze. Interesting architecture. Be sure to take a ride with one of the street cars. We visited in mid-September when the streets were still decorated for some kind of fiesta.

Great Area. Yet another great neighbourhood in Lisbon to walk around. The area has bags of character with cobbled streets and small hidden alleyways. Lots of places to eat and drink and best of all more stunning views.
