You can eat all of that at home and prepared to a much better level as well. Poncey and overpriced that's my verdict.

Authentic bars & restaurants!. Although you're in a super touristy environment, it still feels very authentic. And one of the reasons is probably the architecture and the narrow colourful streets! At night, the bars are filled with people enjoying some drinks and food. Dining might be perhaps too courageous, but this district is definately great place to close the evening/night!

Great atmosphere. we first visited this area at around 11am as part of our walking tour and our tour guide told us to return here after 11pm. Our first impression of the area was not great, it just seemed like a quiet residential area with narrow and steep alleyways.We are glad we listened to our guide and returned at night, the area was completely transformed. Most of the doors that we assumed are jus apartment doors were instead bars. the drinks are not expensive here except for water. Most of the bars are quite small with little space inside, so most people just buy drinks and stand or wander around on the streets. This is a great area and i would recommend visiting but don't go too early!!
Amazing atmosphere!. A must for any young person who wants a fun time in Lisbon! Really great atmosphere... but beware the pickpockets
Place to have a drink at night. It is really animated at nighttime all the bars have deals and you can have a drink outside!However don't waer heels since all the road are pavements

Go and enjoy. Take one of these old-fashioned electric "trams" uphill (e.g. from Praca Restauradores), turn left, stroll through this original quarter of Lisbon. Buy yourself a dink at the booth at the Largo Trindade Coelho (in front of the Church) and enjoy.
Beautiful area. Just loved it up here with the fantastic views of the city , well worth a stroll around . visited a beautiful church in the area and took the street tram up and down . Loved it here

Walking and Watching. Great place to just walk, people watch, eat and drink wine! Nice "Mom and Pop" shops to do all this too. I found a seamstress/coffee shop with a small old woman fixing old clothes who served me a cup of coffee and a glass of port. Amazing experience even though we could not communicate with each other. Also a nice local park (Principe Real) with natives selling cool wares.
Best night ever. Great vibe and crowed, a great place to hang around on fridays and meet new people.It gets packed but still very cool to experience
See the old streets and cafes. If you are fit enough, take a walk through the old streets, have fun in the old cafes and eat tapas in the local restaurants.
Worth spending time here. It's well worth spending a few hours wandering around this area and stopping for a drink and something to eat, lots of lovely little shops and bars

Steep hills, lively, lots of taverns and fado. Bairro alto is a lively place at night. Plenty of restaurants, wine bars, and fado. Just make sure that you have flat shoes as it is not easy climbing up the steep hills. Plenty of activity every night of the week.

Romantic stroll. Lovely area of Lisbon but that's easy because it's all lovely. There are some authentic coffee ships where you can buy a 'beeca' strong coffee and a pastry. You must take a ride on the tram and support this local transport system as it won't be around forever. Beautiful area for an afternoon stroll!
party town/shopping during day. great spot for meandering the streets and taking it all in. There are plenty of boutique shops as well as well known street names.
Really great place. Fab place to visit, full of little restaurants and bars. We went to a Fado restaurant which was really inexpensive and had 2 wonderful singers. Really good night out.
Great view!. It is a great spot to relax for a couple of hours enjoying the incredible view of the city. The gardens at the lower deck are very beautiful on their own and so romantic!

Great for Eating and Drinking. The Bairro is a maze of shops, restaurants and bars. You can spend a few evenings here just walking around, exploring the quirky and funky eateries for drinks and food. Be prepared though as the Bairro is quite hilly (like most of Lisbon) and there is a lot to walk around uphill and down. But its easy to stop for a quick drink along the way, although most places open quite late and are closed on Sundays or Mondays.
great atmospheric area. Engaging area small streets in old town hill area. Gets going in the evening, countless bars and small restaurants. Had a great meal at Bar Alto Restaurant.

The place to be in the evening. We found ourselves returning to this area night after night to eat and drink. Those that say arrive after 22:00 are correct, during the off season it is very quiet before this time. We enjoyed ourselves here though and loved the many choices the area has to offer.I wouldn't mind coming back in the peak season when it is buzzing night after night. Definitely worth a visit to enjoy Lisbon at its very best.
best for weekends. not much happening midweek off season best to go on a summer weekend, when i understand that this is the best place to hang out in the evenings

Quirky, cool.. Cool area with lots of great little bars, we visited during the Carnaval so was a little bit more lively!Lots of choice of eateries and bars and llike most of Lisbon if you can handle being mumbled at from the edge of the street, you'll thoroughly enjoy it.

Lisbon, a quaint neighbourhood on each of their hills. The Bairro Alto neighbourhood is is a great location from which to explore Lisbon . Situated on one of Lisbon's seven hill tops west of city and overlooking Rossio Square (behind the station), it is home to many small hotels, B&Bs and restaurants. It can be accessed from Rossio by "Gloria" a tram made on a slant to match the steep rise of the.

Cute neighborhood in the hills of Lisboa!. I visited Lisbon for the 1st time in September 2013 and loved it so much that I returned in November 2013. Friends had recommended for us to stay in Bairro Alto and we were glad that we did once we arrived! The narrow streets are sprinkled with bars and restaurants in the entire neighborhood. It is mostly pedestrians flooding the streets with Sagres or caipirinhas in hand, having a grand time enjoying live music, food, sidewalk/street cafes, and the company of friends. The beautiful thing about Bairro Alto is how centrally located it is - a short walk from the Tejo and clubs on the river, next door to the Miradoura, steps from the Chiado district, and a short walk away from Cais do Sodre train station, which will transport you to your next excursion outside of the main city area. If you go to Portugal, definitely visit Bairro Alto!

Base of Operations. The Barro Alto neighbourhood is is a great location from which to explore Lisbon . Situated on a high plateau west of and overlooking Rossio Square, it is home to many small hotels, B&Bs and restaurants. It can be accessed from Rossio by "Gloria" the little streetcar that can climb absurdly steep hills. Lisbon is a rail fan's paradise with many old streetcars running up and down throughout the city.
Oldest bookstore in the world. You have to visit this place. Also sit next to Fernando Pessoa, there are always people playing music, artists, and really cool stores

The place for start the party. Just... go. Never before 10pm-11pm, it's emply. There is a famous bar (I don't remerber the name), you can get 18 shots for 6 euros, and half liter of mojita for 8 euros. The bar is on main street in the district, a corner. Which one ? just go and explore !
buzzy, hip and energetic.. clubs, bars, lots of energy. if you like music and drinking out , this is for you.A hipster haven in the old part of the city

Locally among locals. Mostly enjoy in the evening (for dinner) and at night (for night life).
Barrio Alto offers a Whole range of restaurants, clubs, hotels into a dedalus of streets which characterise Lisbon's centre.
Also enjoyable for a walk

A joy around every corner. Great area to explore as it has a good buzz and a good selection of bars playing live music.. Some very nice inexpense resturants in the area. A bit "Party Central", but great fun.
great atmosphere. Great atmosphere no hassle over many streets and hundreds of bars and clubs comes to life at 11pm and still buzzing at 5.30am.
Great places to eat. Found Bairro Alto a very cool area with a good buzz and ambiance. Best places to eat are to be found in this part of the city.

Buzzing atmosphere. The Bairro Alto is a great place for a night out. The streets buzz with people sipping beer and cocktails from plastic glasses, there's a great selection of bars playing live music, and some seriously excellent restaurants too. I enjoy taking friends here when they visit Lisbon- although I don't enjoy the sore head in the morning so much.
amazing night out. being in an old city partying and drinking in the midle of the street is so much fun!! thanks to all of the guys of the pubcrawl!!!

Great for walkers. We kept wondering if we had gone past it. I suppose it comes to life more in the evenings. Still it all adds to the fun of walking the streets in Lisbon. We took Gloria up from Restauradores and walked down hill towards the Carmo Ruins. Then walk out towards Elavador Santa Justa for some great pics. Then towards S Bento. We walk these streets daily.

Best night sport we found. A maze of narrow streets that by day appears run down with lots of metal shutters over the fronts of buildings, it appears quiet and run down...but by night it transforms as the shutters open up to reveal cool little bars for relaxed drinking and eating. All the venues are small, no big clubs or pub here, but a very cool vibe to the place and definitely an area i'd be back to when next in Lisbon. Its high above the centre of the city but you can get the tram up to it from the lower city or the fantastic steel elevator by Eiffel (he of the Eiffel Tower) is another must that will take you up and save your feet for dancing instead!.
must see. A great part of Lisbon worth spending some time wandering the streets and stopping to take the surroundings in.

Timeless place. I didnt eat or drink there since it was a rainy day and most of the seatings are outdoor. But a stroll along the streets was a memorable experience. The place is mesmerizing as it is like a journey back in time. Definitely worth a visit!

it has its corners.... one just needs to find them.
But a lot of tourist trap as well.
Look well. Be careful. And enjoy the beautiful streets, the nice bars and the great food.
"Beautiful". History of the loveliest city of Portugal, typical streets with stone driveway, many restaurants and bars and incredible nightlife area.

Bairro Alto - the party area. Great if you want to go for a drink - almost too many choices of bars. If you want to meet people, go there at night and you have no chance not to start talking to someone. The streets are packed.
www.HeavyTravelAddict.com
Crowded but o so Nice!!. Old city centre! Lots of shops, restaurants and bars.. Must see and must go with the tram! Loved Lissabon for this part of town!!

Not the crazy party place I expected. But maybe it was because I visited on Jan and I come from Glasgow.
Visited one live music bar that was good but I think Fado is an acquired taste.

night life lisbon. Loved to be in Bairro alto.. straight small roads full of public.. restaurants with lots of movements.. seemed to be a hub of port.. music, fashion, drinks.. really enjoyed. straggly recommended to all those who wants to see real portuguese culture, good food and music.

Bairro Alto - Awesome night out!. Bairro Alto on a Saturday night was jam packed with lots of friendly people having fun. The bars were amazing and the prices were reasonable. Visited a load of bars, great music, dancing etc. It was a great night out. Highly recommended!

Food, Fun, Friends. This is the place to go in Lisboa when with friends. With a lot of restaurants from trendy to typical, bars, disco, shops, this is the place to go out in the evening and spend time with friends. Crowded with locals and tourists, it is also known to be a gay neibourhood with shops, bars. From its diversity, Bairro Alto is a must in Lisboa.
Old Lisbon architecture. If you go to Lisbon, go for a walk, it is the old part of the city and the architecture is nice with many shops. Lisbon is not big so it is worthwhile to go for a walk here.

Place for food and drink. The is a an area of small narrow streets filled with cafes, restaurants and bars. Great place to head out at night to. Shame that as much as there are police around they do nothing about the men standing on the corners offering drugs for sale.
Lisbon leisure time. Huge selection of restaurants, wine bars and bars. Safe area to move at night. Close to metro station Baixa-Chiado

Pub Crawl !. We went with a group of other tourists in Bairro Alto for a pub crawl and it was amazing ! People everywhere, safe place, great pubs for all tastes from house music to live concerts, cheap drinks, shots for 1.5€ and so on. Moreover, the crazy lisboeta touch was that people pour out of the pubs to party on the streets. The overall place is quite safe with policeman being around most of the time. Moreover, taxis , which are cheap when taken in groups can be easily found and are also safe.Had a great experience in Bairro Alto and I highly recommend it to other people.

Great for a dinner. The old part full with bars and restaurants, winding old cobbled streets. A lot of Fado bars with live music. Distinguish the real ones from the tourist ones. Since it is on a steep hill, take the funicular from Restaudores sq to the top. On the way out of the tram is the great Mirdouro de Alcantara with perfect panorama of Lisbon.Then slowly walk your way down.
fab bars and restuarants. Lovely little streets to explore the numerous bars, coffee shops and cafes. Particularly enjoyed the 'rock and hard rock bar' otherwise known as WASP bar.

Location location location. Central to everything. Luso for fado music. Shopping, Institute of Port, the tram down to the city center. Loved the area, restaurants, small clubs and people. Would recommend for the 20-50 crowd. Ladies, do your self a favor and do not wear heals!
Wonderful!. Loved this curious area of Lisbon! Literally hundreds of bars and restaurants. Everyone is super friendly and prices are all very reasonable.

Great for a night out. Great neighborhood for night life, drinks, etc. but there were a lot of suspicious people in the streets offering drugs so we didn't feel that safe. Otherwise, if you want to go out and have a good time, great! Just don't wear high heels :)

The best night life!. Bairro Alto is the place to go for night life! Starting with a meeting point at Largo do Camões (try a ginjinha while there). Then venture throught the old narrow streets full of bars and crowded with people from all ages, all countries! Simply amazing"!
Great neighborhood. Bairro Alto is a great place to walk, day or night. The shops, bars and restaurants are lively and fun. The area is safe and a perfect place to wander. Stop, eat, drink and enjoy.
Night time hot spot. Great for night time strolling. Lots of wonderful little restaurants, wine bars and lounges with live music. Some areas are gritty but it adds to the charm. Always felt safe.

Nice part of town. I really like the narrow streets where you can stroll. There are many restaurants to choose from. Only downside is the many waiters that are sking you to come in to have lunch or dinner. We visited borth in July and December. In December there are only few tourists around and some restaurants are closed. Looks like waiters are less annoying this time of year.There are many Fado restaurants in this area.

Dafinitely overrated. There are some goog viewpoints to visit in Bairro Alto and have great views of Lisbon, which is a real magnificent city. We spent six nights in an apartment in Bairro Alto. At first view the place is authentic but when the evening came we had the impression that every door was a restaurant or bar. We did not get the impression that it is an area where portuguese people socialize. It is indeed a very touristic place for eating and drinking. There are lots, but lots of restaurants and bars and when reading reviews a lot of people comment on the restaurants catering for tourists. Well, it is the touristic spot at night so every door in there is waiting for you, non-lisbon residents, to enter. It is a place overrated by guidebooks, very deceiving for what it offers. Try to walk the streets during the day and enjoy the architecture of every different house, every door-way, every different window, residents in their windows looking at life passing-by. I recommend it more day time than night, depending on what you look for. We also found some really, but really expensive Fado restaurants in this area.
Gastronomy. Great cuisine! good ambience! However the rainy weather forced us to take a seat indoors which did not affect the quality of service and delicious refeição

Come at Night if you like to people-watch and have a beer while at it. There are a ton of bars and restaurants, but if you want to do it like the alfacinhas (lisbonites) do, just buy a cheap draft beer and come hang outside. If you need to seat there is always the sidewalk. This is super crowded at night, but it is well worth it if you have the patience and stamina for it. The night can go pretty long while you're here. Head for Bica, slightly south of Bairro Alto to see the tram line and have one of those vistas that you can only have in this city.

Party central. We spent two nights in the Bairro Alto. The first night we spent in a great, unpretentious modern jazz bar with reasonably priced drinks, and the second night in an overpriced Fado restaurant, which nonethless provided some good music. The whole place is fun though just to walk around in the evening, listening to the various sounds emerging from the clubs, restaurants and bars
Surprising zone. Deserves at least 2 visits. One during the day and the other at night. Eclectic area. Fabulous contrast.

Lovely area. As some have written, up and down and up and down again. Cobblestone streets, beautiful houses and lots of bars and cafés. Great views over Lisbon from some strategic points and perfect photo opportunities for enthusiasts. I have only been here during the day, but as everyone speaks of the fantastic nightlife in Bairro Alto I will try it later on.This is maybe not a place suited for all disabilities and you might want to take it easy going up the hills if you have heart problems. It is rather steep. However, there are trams here and there and you can enjoy a ride to make going up or down easier.
Nothing much to say.... A lot of shops, difficult to find grocery shops, and also the roads are not nice if you have a stroller: there are made of collberstone in the city center.

Not as good as all the reviews. After reading how cool how wonderful i was a little disappointed. Not everything it's made out to be though still enjoyed. Went for a meal one night and visited the bars etc. which we're fun.

A great night out if you like bar crawls. Bairro Alto is great if you like a great quirky mix of bars and cheap drinks. One of Lisbon's many characterful areas, it can be lots of fun and you can wander around the alleys where you will find all manner of different drinking holes and eateries. A popular area to have drinks outdoors with lots of locals and tourists alike - very busy on a Saturday night!

Beautiful to wander around. This area is full of unexpected little shops filled with handmade and quaint things and restaurants with Fado. The best thing is to have no plans but just wander and see what you come across as every street and corner has nice suprises!

Fantastically atmospheric, fun and friendly. This area is full of charm, atmosphere and interest. Beautiful old world, narrow streets with wonderful and individual restaurants, bars and shops. Very lively, very relaxed, safe and fun.

Worth seeing. The really is only one way to get to Barrio Alto. Not really, but go by the Elevador da Gloria funicular railway. it goes from Restauradores in the center of Lisbon, up to this barrio. When you alight this lift, there is a pretty little park from where you can see across the city. It is also a district of town where people shop and live, so you get the flavor of this city. Also, from here you can easily get to the Estrela Basilica and the Parliament building.

Fantastic. if you like opened people, live good music, good vibe, acceptable prices, lots of people, dancing and cocktail this is the street for you, very big and sattisfiying offer, I would reccomend to see!

Outstanding night life.... We spent the majority of our evenings in Bairro Alto. Excellent restaurants, shopping, outdoor entertainment. The hills can be steep, but there are trams and an elevator that will take you up there if so desired. Check out the wine bars - We really enjoyed a couple of them and visited numerous times.

Wonderful place for walking around to see the sights of Lisbon. This area is very good for walking. When we arrived at the elevator and found it was out of service we noticed everyone was simply walking up and down the tracks so we went right up. It has the best view of the city from a park near the top of the hill.

Lisbon night starts here. There's nothing like Bairro Alto in Lisbon. Full of stores for every need you might have, great restaurants of all kinds, and great bars and clubs. The mood is awesome, full of all kinds of people. This is the place where all kinds of cultures are welcome! A must go!
Lots of bars and restaurants. If you are is Lisbon you must go to Bairro Alto. It's a very lively place, lots of restaurants and bars everywhere, so if you want to party it's a good option.

Party mood. Lots of people at night, great atmosphere and very busy bars serving tons of drinks. Interesting mix of people across all ages, styles, countries and interests but all very friendly and easy going.

Lots of character. Check out the amazing street art while climbing along Calcada da Gloria, and top it off with amazing views of Lisbon and a port tasting at the Instituto Dos Vinhos Do Douro E Do Porto at the top!
the place to be. If you love to see how locals party, you need to to there during the evening and enjoy some great drinks and great Fado music :)

It needs a special state of minde.. It is a typical neiberwood of old Lisbon. Is not historical neither beutifull. Just fashionable and a spot of nightlife for teens. Lots of bars and restaurants overpricides. For locals it is kind of decadent, but it worth a visit just to look around.

over rated. we were looking for some good tapas and there seemed to be plenty to choose from in this old niehgborhood . most of the menues seemed the same and we didn't find the people to be all that friendly. I think it is ok for a younger crowd who are out on the town for the night. it seemed like a good place to start. after wandering around, we settled on a place that was not too crowded and at the same time didn't have the owner out on the street trying to drag you in. every place had the menu in several languages and photos of the food trying to attract the tourists

A decent quarter with a lot of slopes.. This nice quarter is located on a hilltop, which you will soon enough find rather annoying, as walking the streets gets quite physical in some of the slopes.It is considered to be a picturesque part of town, but we found it to be rather ordinary, yet not exceptional.Avoid visiting this quarter on a rainy day, as you will undoubtedly slip on one of the many, many slopes.

Great views. Our coach guide recommended that if we wanted an adventure during our afternoon in Lisbon that we should take a tram up to the Bairro Alto, which is just what we did and it was great fun. A short ride up the steep hill in our rickety old tram, a great lunch in the Pois cafe (what a find) and a slow walk back up to the top for coffee and Lisbon egg custard cakes and for taking in the view over the bay - a blissful 3 hours well spent!

Great for Strolling , have a Meal and do some Shopping!. Bairro Alto is one of Lisbon's oldest neighbourhood. It has been recently renovated so it looks pretty good! There are lots of good restaurants there , for all range prices , and interesting stores to visit. If you go to Chiado I recommend you to go there. At night its a great spot to go out , lots of bars and also Fado houses.

So much fun!!. Came out to the Bairro Alto neighborhood with a friend while staying in Lisbon and could not have been happier with our experience. Such a fun lively atmosphere where you can meet all types of people. Every bar is different in its own way, and don't judge a book by its cover the bar may look really small from the outside but go in a lot of times there are basements with a large disco going on. If you are looking for a fun night out in Lisbon then I would definitely recommend going here!
Great Neighborhood. Such a fun neighborhood. Great restaurants and nightlife. Take some time to explore...you'll find a great music and bar scene.
trendy. The area is cool but follow my advice and dont get drugs on the streets, they are no good!!! well,... drugs in general arent good but the hash that i got sold I am still wandering what it is.
Is this it?. Sure, it's high up but there's no character in the place. If you must go, take the escalators in Rossio station to give your legs a break

Specially in the night. This is area from the 16th century.
At night f its vibrant nightlife and have a good choice ,restaurants, bars, and alternative shops in Lisbon

Surprisingly good mojitos!. Went boozing around here a few nights during my stay in Lisbon. Can't remember any specifics about bar/street names but the best thing about the place is finding your own favourites I think.I was getting a bit bored of superbock and sagres after a while so switched onto mojitos with no real expectation (especially when i was handed it in a plastic 500ml cup) but the first one I had was AMAZING! Other bars afterwards weren't as nice but they were all still acceptable.The worst thing about the place is the 'looky looky' men constantly trying to sell you cheap tat!

All day round something happening. I lived many years in Lisbon and Bairro Alto is a sure bet any evening on a budget. Bairro wakes up late with dinners between 8p.m. and midnight, which is when the area get's taken over by the nightlife crowds. Very busy on the weekends and you have to choose your bars well to get quality drinks.
Trendy part of the city. It's a great area of the city to go out for a drink, have dinner or simply enjoy the quirky shops and diversity of people, whatever you do surely you'll have fun.

Great night out!!. If your looking for where the hotspot is one the weekend it is hands down Bairro Alto. There are numerous bars and clubs within blocks and the streets are filled with people meeting each other. Tip, get here around 1130 and it will start to get good.
Many fine restaurants. We ate in this neighborhood on both nights of our visit. The restaurants were all top notch and affordable.

heard rave reviews, but just thought it was ok. not quite sure what to make of it, nice bars, but not what i thought it would be, its ok, but nothing special, not the hub of bars with live local music i heard it to be. worth a look though as its easy to get too, but a bit hilly. great views over the city though.

Interesting and gritty. Still good evening and late night energy for both young and older (cafes and bars) and THE place for Fado music in several clubs. Unfortunately very gritty and dirty; verging on feeling unsafe in some of the quieter narrow streets. Noticeably deteriorated from my last visit in 2009.

best night out in Europe. join the throngs. Walk down the small streets & over the hills. Pass bars pulsing with people, music and life. Smile. Eat great food, drink gorgeous red wine. Find live music, smile, dance. You will be happy. I loved the Bairro Alto - a highpoint of my trip. Loved the JazzBar, it was amazing.

Bars and drinks, dinner and fadu songs.. The old townm little streets filled with all kinds of restaurants, bars, cute places... must do! just get lost in here, and see where the road will lead you...

If in Lisbon, you gotta. It is one of the things that makes Lisbon, well Lisbon. Lively, fun and energetic. It is an experience to just walk and get accosted by every restaurant and wine establishment.

Wild! Perfect place for a fantastic night out!. Went here almost every night we where in Lisbon!This is the best place for nightlife in Lisbon! The streets are literally streaming with people all night long no matter what day of the week!Get a drink anywhere and enjoy the surroundings and try lots of different bars on offer! This is a must for all travellers wanting to have a good time in Lisbon!

Perfect Located in Old City. Loved the high floor room with balcony and view of the square, You can't go wrong with the rooftop bar, though you need to get there early or book a table as the place fills up quick (for good reason)! The rooms were comfortable and the service excellent. I'd stay again ... no question.

Completely mad but great fun. We went for the first time at about 1am on a Friday night and it was packed and very very lively. So many different bars to choose from, all playing different styles of music, with most people stand outside drinking pints of caipirinha. It's very studenty but not unfriendly if you're a bit older! It's the only time we were very aware of quite obvious pickpockets, so definitely watch your wallet and probably leave credit cards at home. But as long as you keep your wits about you it seemed fine (so watch out for those pints of caipirinha!! )

Live like a local.. Being based in a holiday rental (apartment) in Bairro Alto you will be able to shop, dine and travel like a local although you will probably draw the line at hanging out your washing in the streets! The houses are tiny and streets are narrow so everything feels very intimate.Trams and buses pass through the area and there are small grocery stores, bakeries, bars and restaurants. The place comes alive at night but watch your belongings.
My new favorite part of town to hang out in. It's crowded, but less touristy, less tacky shops, but tons of restaurants and bars and lots of fun. Oh and there are some great view points there.

A Must to Explore!. This is a unique area of small streets, with quaint terraces, interesting characters and local cafes selling delicious food. The older parts of Lisbon are the most interesting to explore.Tips: You can go on an organised walking tour of this area and come back later to explore it further yourself. Eat where you see the locals are eating as this will usually be cheaper and the food more traditional.
Be sure where you are going otherwise you will walk a lot and uphill.. Check your directions. Lots of turists lost looking for directions. We had to walk a lot to find a restaurant.
Interesting.. This area is full of interesting things. Churches, tiled homes, plazas etc.. It helps to have guidebook.

Viva la Europe & eat in the street. You must visit Bairro Alto. Fresh food cooking fills the night air, beautiful Fado music around every corner and grab a drink in one place and bring it down the street to eat dinner somewhere else. The rules are relaxed and the area & lighting absolutely lovely. If you are there late at night the cabs drive up the tiny streets & you can literally stand up from your table and step into a cab. Enjoy!!!

A jewel high atop the city. Bairro Alto, a very old section of Lisbon at the top of the city which can be reached by the old time tram that is fun to take, is a mish-mosh of very narrow streets and alleys that seem far removed from the hustle bustle of downtown Lisboa. We found an excellent restaurant up a very narrow street named CASANOSTRA, which was delicious and specialized in Italian food. It is a bit of a walk, but the taxi can take you quite close. Also the view from the park once you take the tram is stunning.
for the young. Felt like a red light district at night and I felt uncomfortable. Didn't stay in the area just kept on walking......
Romantic terrace. Check the 6th floor terrace for a wonderful sunset and overview of the bay and bridge. Very good location in small but cozy boutique hotel.

Great in the daytime, some streets a bit scary at night. This is a bustling and vibrant part of the city, with lots to explore. There were a few dodgy looking characters hanging around on some of the back alleys in the evening - having said that, we found a fantastic bar with live salsa music, dancing and wicked mojitos down one of those said same streets!

At the beating heart of Lisbon. The Biarro Alto is a place not to be missed on a visit to Lisbon: the narrow streets, the trams, the restaurants and cafés; the noise, the people! In this area the atmosphere is scintillating, and life progresses at a more leisurely pace, contrasting somewhat with the pressure of the traffic. Here you breathe the feel of the city, of the Portuguese city dwellers, of people going about their daily activities in an area which if not frozen in time, is certainly an area in which time passes unremarked. A wonderfully relaxing area to visit.

Best part of town!. I stayed right in the middle of Bairro Alto and absolutely loved it! It is an exciting and bustling part of town filled with fantastic bars, interesting shops and restaurants. It is sleepy by day and comes alive at night. The atmosphere is quite electric! A trip to Lisbon would not be complete without going here.

Expected more. The trolley ride up was cool but for 3.60euro that was a bit much and the ride was only 2 min tops. We went on a Sunday evening it was dead. My friends and I were told it was a cool place with lots of shops and restaurants. Once we reached the top it was dead and nothing was open. We gave it the benefit of the doubt thinking it was dead due to it was Sunday. So we went another time during the week and during the day. Granted it was a little bit livelier higher we expected something different. We went port tasting in Bairro Alto, In the states when I've gone wine tasting it's normally a bit nosier with people talking, laughing and having a good time. This place was so quiet, my friends and I were whispering when we were talking with each other.

Fun nights out!. Cute little bars and restaurants, this place has it going on! Narrow streets filled with people enjoying some drinks, people selling their goods (usual tat) and great little places to sit and people watch. You must go here if you visit Portugal
Bairro Alto!. Wonderful!!! Very exiting and interesting place in Lisbon, especially tram, walls, peoples, view from hill ...

Great area for night life / people watching / friendly crowds. Something for everyone to eat (we stumbled on a great crepe place with a live saxaphonist, great food and drinks) and of course drink. We were in the area on a Thursday and the bars and streets were very busy (imagine it is even crazier on the weekends). Had a grea time - drinks are reasonably priced.

Pessoa and electronic music. Night life of Bairro Alto is one of the best I have experienced ever...Every moment I was expecting to see Fernando Pessoa dancing in the rhytme of electronic music :) Mix with Portuguese, and people from all parts of the Europe and world, have one cold portuguese beer, and enjoy...

Nights of fun. It is the center of the night life in Lisbon. A lot of bars for all tastes, and different restaurantes, some more traditional with Fado live shows, other a bit more gourmet. Nothing out of ordinary, but a great place to spend a night with friends.
Lively and good fun. A definite vibe in this part of the city at nighttime. Lots of coo little bars with people generally having fun, saw no issues of concern. Would definitely return.
Nothing out of ordinary... Curiosity strikes but nothing special about it. Perhaps because it was a miserable rainy day. Didn't enjoy it at all. I wouldn't go back...
Always a night well spent :). Like nothing else, loved it, huge varieties of bars and clubs, lots of positive and friendly people, very fun!

The place for hanging out. This is the place to be if you want to hang out with friends and enjoy the night. They have plenty of bars and restaurants some of them with live Fado. You don't need a lot of money due to it's permitted to buy and drink in the streets.

Home base. We had our apartment in the Barrio Alto neighborhood. There were plenty of tiny supermarkets to buy your breakfast. In addition to that, there were a lot of larger supermercados nearby.
In the evening you will see the real character of the neighborhood. A lot of restaurants, bars, etc, where you can spend your evening and starting of the night.
The best nightlife district you must visit. This are is a unique area for all nightlife lovers. There are many bars, some with cool live music of all genre. The drinks are reasonably cheap as well.
astounding Beauty. In the Barrio Alto area, do not miss going to the Sao Roque Church. My wife and I were overcome emotionally by its beauty. It was one of the most memorable places we visited

The place to go. I went there every night while in Lisbon. There you can find from restaurants with typical food (cod fillet or sardines!!) to bars which serve local beer. Very vivid area, full of people from places all over the world. You will feel the real Lisbon while in there. Really loved it!

Very good. Great location, boutique hotel with very good service. I would ignore the comments regarding pick pockets or drug dealers. Stayed twice in September and never encountered any a pick pocket or drug dealer. The breakfast is superb. The roof top bar is fine for a brief visit - the view is not that interesting - I would not make a special trip to it. There are far more interesting roof top bars in Europe.

Nightlife!!!. This is where all of the clubs and night life are located. had a lot of fun bar hopping in a different country. My only complaint is that they still allow smoking in the clubs and bars in Lisbon which detracted from the experience for me.
Night life. Beautiful streets with wild nightlife every night. You have to go clubbing there at least once. There are some really cool bars and pubs with cheap drinks

Average age is 18. This area is certainly heaving but I'm not sure whether it's the right quality of heaving for a holiday maker. At 23.00 the street were packed with young people drinking, mostly from bottles. The bars were packed and the streets crammed full of young people intent with getting drunk. I didn't see any trouble but by the police presence it must happen. Give the area a wide berth if you are over 30 and enjoy a civilized night out!

The place to be. Great place to be at night, live music, Fado, resturants, bars. Very lively to wander around-flat shoes only though as hilly and cobblestoned. (Although Portuguese women seem to be able to wear high heels anywhere.) Fun place.
HOME. great place to go for dinner and drinks. lovely alternative shops to browse through during the day but its at night that Bairro Alto comes to life. dont miss it.

Fabulous area. Great area to visit...lots of lovely cafes and food emporiums and plenty of opportunities to purchase cork products. Wandering around provides spectacular photo ops. Very busy and beware of the cobblestones as they can be somewhat tricky when walking about looking up....I know...as I went "a over t" a couple of times. Great shopping...and don't forget to try the local beverages....alcoholic ones!!!

This is where the night life is in Lisbon. Great place to unwind, people watch and have a good time. Many restaurants, bars and Fado music everywhere. Wouldn't want to stay near here, very noisy and litter everywhere late into the morning

Fun neighborhood. Great fun to wander the street and discover this charming neighborhood filled with restaurants, cafes, watering holes and just plain locals and local establishments. Be aware, if you are not already, that Lisbon is built on hills--- and this neighborhood is very hilly. Be also aware that the sidewalks and streets are all cobblestoned, and not in the best conditions. Watch your steps.

Very nice but too crowded at night. Bairro Alto is an excellent place where you can find lots of restaurants and small bars. Price range depends on the type you choose.
For me the only problem is that is too crowded at weekends nights, witch is very good for pickpockets, but I don't like that part.

Barrio Alto. The Barrio Alto area of Lisbon is a great place to spend at night. There are numerous bars and restaurants. You can spend some time listening to Fado in some of the restaurants, just be aware of the minimum spending requirements of the establishment. In the day time the area is sleepy but the area sure livens up at night. Don't forget that the area is hilly like most of Lisbon so bring some good comfortable shoes.

Super. Barrio Alto is a lovely area full of restaurants, bars, impressive sights and wonderful people. The area is a tad hilly so make sure you have a good pair of shoes. You can catch the tram around but really you should walk around and explore.

Not the place to spend your time in Lisbon..... After visiting Lisbon last year, I wondered what all the fuss was about- did not find it either special or charming. Bairro Alto seemed to consist of dark streets, with a cafe or bar randomly shattered about...This year, I discovered a totally different city- I stayed in the Baixa/Chiado district and it was just dynamic! Restaurants, bars, shops, music, lovely piazzas- Lisbon has just sailed up as one of my favourite cities!
Love at first sight!. I think everybody in Lisboa should pay a visit to the Bairro Alto. Beautiful and full of happy people and small beautiful clubs with good music!

Excellent far a walk during the day, excellent Caipirinha and atmosphere at night. Everything is in the title!Definitly the place to be at night for a drink.Also a nice place in which the small streets are typical.

A night to remember. Bairro Alto is one of the many historical neighbourhoods of Lisbon. Started as a mid-upper class residential area after the 1755 hearthquake, it was the centre of the city's cultural life, together with the neighbouring Chiado area.As years passed and with the development of other more modern parts of Lisbon, Bairro Alto saw most of its youth move out. By the 1960's and 1970's, unlike Chiado, Bairro Alto had become increasingly more and more degraded and seedy and with an old and poor population. The neighbourhood was known for prostitution, basic and seedy taverns, cheap and unimpressive restaurants and for being home to some of the country's most representative newspapers, some streets even being named after them, like Diário de Noticias or O Século.Things changed dramatically in the 1980's, when Bairro Alto was rediscovered by the city's students and by a population with an increasing acqusitive power and eager for enjoying life. In the following years, surviving the downfall of Chiado after the 1988 great fire, the seedy taverns gave way to trendy bars and shops, the basic restaurants stepped up a few notches and were joined by more sophisticated options, prostitutes were replaced by a hip young crowd who came to the Bairro not only to have fun but to live there.Nowadays, Chiado has become one of Lisbon's and Europe's chic areas and Bairro Alto lives on as THE place for nightlife, despite the increasing competition from nearby Bica, Principe Real or from Alfama and the Docks. It is loud, dirty, the streets are packed with people drinking, laughing, talking, shouting, smoking (sometimes smoking barely legal stuff), there may be the odd fist fight, many people may find it difficult to like, but you have to forget all that, let yourself go and just enjoy it.It's difficult to set an itinerary to follow, but here are some tips:- Bairro Alto is fairly quiet during the day, but it's the opposite at night. I suggest you experience it during the day and then at night. The difference will blow your mind;- The crowdest nights are Friday and Saturday. Thursday is becoming increasingly popular, but Friday and Saturday Spring and Summer nights are your best options;- Do it the Portuguese way: arrive late. Before midnight is just too early. The routine is to meet the friends at Camões square, have dinner around 10 pm or later, end your dinner around midnight and hit the streets going bar hopping until it's time to go to a disco (never before 2 am). Discos usually close at 6 am, some at 7 or 8, and then there are the after parties to keep the party animals going.- Barroca, Atalaia and Diário de Noticias are the most packed streets and also where the most popular bars are. Try Páginas Tantas (good cocktails and hot toasts), Favela Chic, Tertúlia, Tasca do Chico (live, popular, unpretentious Fado music on some nights) at Diário de Noticias; try the Corner Club, the 41 or the Maria Caxuxa at Barroca Street; check the Portas Largas and Arroz Doce at Atalaia Street. The junction of Barroca Street and Travessa da Espera is usually packed and it's sometimes difficult to move; it's also a popular gay spot as there are a few gay bars around;Another great place for a drink is the Bar at Bairro Alto Hotel, on Camões Square. Get the Purple Mood cocktail!;Try also Lost in Translation (ethnic shop, with a bar/restaurant and amazing views over Lisbon) and Pavilhão Chinês (Chinese Pavillion, extensive cocktails and other drinks menu, eclectic, wacky decoration, try to figure out how they dust the whole place; must see) at D.Pedro V street, bordering Bairro Alto-There are plenty of dinner (or lunch) options for everyone at Bairro Alto. Reservations are highly recommended, especially on peak nights. Here are a few suggestions:A Cabaça, Stasha, Cantinho das Gáveas, Sinal Vermelho at Gáveas street. The last two are extremely popular and together with the first serve traditional basic Portuguese food. The other offers modern Portuguese food. Remember to ask for 'Bife na pedra' (steak on hot stone) at Cabaça, your clothes will stink afterwards but it's worth it;A Baiuca at Barroca Street, practically an institution in Lisbon. Offers traditional Portuguese food, the 'Bacalhau com Natas' (cod with cream) is a must. Also at Barroca you have Sudoeste, your best option to grab a tasty snack after kitchens close at the mainstream restaurants;Bota Alta at Atalaia Street, again traditional Portuguese, great food but a bit pricier option;Novo Bonsai, at Rosa street, for excellent Japanese food;100 Maneiras at Travessa do Teixeira, one of the best restaurants in Lisbon and in Portugal, modern food, inspired by Portuguese flavours, a touch of molecular gastronomy here and there, an experience that will blow your mind. Reservations mandatory!;The Decadente @ The Independente Hostel on S. Pedro de Alcântara street, trendy place, great atmosphere, good value for money portuguese food with a modern twist. Nice brunch on Sundays too (an option to recover from a long night out)- It is likely you are approached by people offering you drugs. My advice is don't buy it even if you're interested. Just ignore them, they are not insistent. - Ladies leave your high heel shoes at the hotel, or else the Bairro's cobbled streets will give you a hard time (or a twisted ankle). Comfortable shoes are in order. Portuguese are very laid back and informal so you won't need to dress up for dinner.- Smoking is not allowed at restaurants and in most bars.- Don't be shy, talk to strangers. Portuguese are welcoming and most people speak at least one foreign language, particularly English. If they don't, they will make an effort to communicate.- There aren't any discos at Bairro Alto. This is the place where you come for dinner and drinks before moving on to the Docks, Alcântara, 24th of July avenue and Santa Apolónia for dancing. You can also try the nearby Príncipe Real area for gay discos.A day at the Bairro Alto is a trip to old, historical, popular Lisbon. A night at Bairro Alto is a roller coaster trip through young, wild, trendy, wacky Lisbon. Enjoy!

Wild but Easy to Navigate!. My friends and I (we are all around 20 years old) thoroughly enjoyed our trip up here one Saturday night. We got all the drinks we could handle for around 8-12 euros each and bar-hopped the whole night. Take a clutch purse or something you can keep your hand on at all times just to be safe and I think it best to go with guys, but you would be OK with just girls if you kept your eyes out and were safe. It is easy to get to from the Chiado/Restauradores area but we climbed a TON of stairs to get up there. Tons of large mojitos/strawberry mojitos/pina coladas for only 5 euros and several places with 1 euro shots (bring a chaser?) and after the bars close down around 3 there is a street slightly below bairro alto with lots of after-hour clubs that stay open the rest of the morning. You really won't find anything else like this but the crowds are huge, the streets noisy, and the drinks are not absolutely amazing if you want them to be cheap, but there are definite hidden gems like salsa clubs and jazz restaurants among the cheaper, less classy bars.
amazing night life. cheap drinks everywhere to order indoors and drink outside, nice atmosphere, especially in the summer
Fun. So many restaurants/cafes/bars. So much fun. Not too keen on the guys flogging useless flashy accessories though. They were a nuisance. Great food and wine!!! Locals very nice.

Set your expectations !. Bairro Alto is a special place in Lisbon, something you won't find in every other city. The narrow, cobbled streets with lively atmosphere, Fado or practically any atmosphere you would like.If you want to see BA at its best, go there in the later evening hours. Make sure you don;t have your car with you, as finding parking slot is almost impossible even in the parking lots in the area.I've seen some reviewers found this place does not worth visiting as it is very busy, crowded and noisy.Well, I've just titled my review accordingly, make sure you don;t expect a place for peaceful calm walk with your loved one, better go to the waterfront if you are after such an experience.

Plenty of Character. Bairro Alto has plenty of character and charisma with lots of small cafés and bars. probably best to visit later in the evening as it only starts to come alive then. Basically it is a string of small lane ways with plenty of different pubs and nightlife.If possible probably best to take advice from locals where to go and not to go. I was lucky and visted with locals. Even though it was during the week it was still busy and there was a good atmosphere.
Lisbon Night Life. Ideal area for dining and wining at night, with a large selection of bars and restaurants to suit all tastes in both food and music.

Don't leave without having a drink at night here. This neighborhood is a bit boring and deserted during the day but comes completely to live after 10 pm. There are hundreds of bars and restaurants and is bustling with people of all ages and types. Find a bar and buy a caipirihna and start some people watching late evening and enjoy the fantastic atmosphere.
Great fun in the evening. Go there at night, walk the windy streets, have dinner, and then go to the main square in Chiado, sit outside, have a drink and watch people go by, and street performers
love the party people !!. Just a great atmosphere! The drinks were cheap, the music is good and the people were great! Love it!

A great selection of bars. Best bar was the weird Capela on Rua de Atalaia. Very atmospheric. Also some good restaurants. Lots of steps and steep roads though! Also liked the Old Pharmacy wine bar on Rua de Diario de Noticias.

Bar street. Get there around midnight and look for narrow streets filled with young people and small bars. Loved this place. It has a good combination of mostly local and some tourists (depends on the season). The area is very laid back, sosial and cheap. XXL drinks for 3 euros and big beers for around 1 euro. Everything closes at 3 am. I really had a blast there - you should go too!

Bairro Alto pubs. Very nice neighborhood with many excellent bars and very lively atmosphere during night. The massive crowds on the streets are just fascinating and you cannot see anything like that to dance and drink on the narrow streets.

Everything for everyone. the best place to go out at night in lisbon. it supposedly closes at 3 a.m. but you can stay out until 5 a.m. just drinking beer from the illegal shopers that walk around the streets. you can find almost every kind of bar in these streets for all tastes and wallets. The only downside is that you have to be on the lookout for muggers and troublemakers, expecially if you are a foreign.

LOVE IT!. Such a relaxed, laid back area! Drinking alcohol in the street is perfectly acceptable - a concept I found strange. Drinks are v cheap but good quality - mojitos approx 5e for a huge cup, shots 1 or 2e. Awesome!!
amazing night atmosphere. nice atmosphere, little street, many bars,many people in the street at late night worth a dining and bar hopping experience

lets have a drink. Just walk around the narrow streets and enjoy. Meet and talk to people from all over the world. Every age and kind of people, its a great place to have a drink, or too many drinks ,as the prices are so low you could get out of there with drinking problems :p the best spot to find dozens of pubs and dance bars before your club destination. Its a must! Been there 3 out of 5 of my nights in lisboa!

Lisboa Nightlife. The restaurants and bars of bairro alto are definitely worth visiting. In particular the atmosphere in the outdoor "nightclubs" was sensational. OK, so its just hundreds of people milling around in the street drinking cocktails or superbock, but in several consecutive late nights in the area I didn't see any antisocial behaviour. As with any big city though, keep your wits about you as pickpockets are active, and those big beers are bigger than they look...
Where walking means pleasure. You can approach here by taking the metro station Chiado-Baixa. Lots of hills, historic buildings, street parties and unexpected views!

Atmosphere. Not much to see during the day but it has a good buzz after dark. Good restaurants and street performers. Main areas had large crowds but did not feel crowded. The queues for icecream was huge, simply stupid!
The nightlife is here. This is a must-see quarter of Lisbon by night. If you're looking for a place where to eat or drink after dinner this is the place to go. The atmosphere is also very warm.
Great place to walk around. This is a great area to soak in the city atmosphere. There are great views of the city, the tram was a great way to get there. Loads of nice restaurants and bars.

Leave the car!. Loved the ride in the funicular up the hill. The views at night are spectacular. We enjoyed walking, listening to the music that filled the air. We are seniors, but delighted in all the young people having a good time. It is an area that you need to walk to appreciate and a car would be a very frustrating experience.

Besides the view from the park overlook, a gimmick.. The view from the park immediately to your right after you get up the funicular, is the best part of this place. And evening is best. The cobbled narrow streets are a nightmare to drive if you get off the main roads and your GPS will send you down impossible streets (I had a Fiat 500 5 speed w/ the side mirrors pulled in and it was still tight) so take the funicular. By the way, it uses the same pass or 10 ride card that the rest of the system uses, and if you change from metro or bus to get on the tram or anything else within 1:15 min.s, it is just one trip off the card. So don't buy a special round trip ticket (about 7E for 2). After you view the city from the park and snap a few, just leave. Food is overpriced and no better than anywhere else. Unless you are a kid and have to be with all the other imbeciles your age (the park filled up with kids toward dark and had a heavy metal band playing way too loud for anyone over 40 to retain equilibrium within a block of the place) just enjoy the view and go back within your 1:15 and it will be almost free! It is a pretty shabby place. The national natural history museum is really pitiful and not worth the price, but same price ticket (1 E more)you into the garden next door. It is great. Just go to the park if you must find one other thing to do up there. From the tram up, follow the street up and around the curve to the left about 4 blocks to the Botanical Garden. I know others will have a different view, but this is a 60's couple from America who no longer thing shabby and run down is "neat". Alfama was not much to me either, except for the views from the Mirador. Hey, finding a clean free bathroom is an exciting thing at my age, so take it for what it's worth and consider the source.

A fun experience. If you visit Lisbon and you like to party then this is the place to visit. It is much like a mini carnival experience with a long strip and of bars and clubs all playing different types of music. This is very different to other European countries as all the bars were free to get into and none of them had doors! It was literally like a mini carnival without the costumes. It gets extremely packed here on weekends so go earlier to get a good look of what there is to offer.

Party meets tradition. What can I say about Bairro Alto that hasn't been said? It can be overpriced, cheap, traditional or completely modern. It has all of these but it is definitely a place where you see Portugals traditional music (fado) connected with the society of nowadays. Lots of bars and restaurants where you always eat well. Enjoy!

All Night Long. Bairro Alto is one of the areas that currently inspire Lisbon nights. It’s a neighborhood with low buildings and narrow streets where, at night, some are dedicated only to pedestrians. Offers many restaurants, many with few tables, and bars, many with live music. But are the streets that from midnight fill with people, which enliven the area that also has near many shops and hotels. People walk just like in groups, parking is possible mostly at garages, better went by public transport.
place to see. very nice and charming place ,fado you can find seldom but if you have a luck its wonderful ,very good restaurants ,athmosfere is perfect
For anyone looking to party. Mostly 20's. It is party central at night for young singles. Most of the people are in their 20's, lots of bars and it felt safe even late in the evening

Lovely neighbourhood full of life. Thoroughly enjoyed wondering the streets of Bairro Alto. There are plenty of hills so make sure to wear comfortable shoes. Lots of restaurants, shopping and nightlife here to keep you entertained. Vibrant square in the centre of the neighbourhood as well.

Wonderful surrounding.. Exciting, colorful and very interesting, this place is a part of town not to be missed for anything in the world.Right here you will breathe the soul of Lisbon, one of the many restaurants in the area I tried the famous Portuguese cod, very cheap and very good, in context, it is an experience worth trying.A wonderful place, thanks to the many bars, restaurants, night life and many young people, but above all to make everything even more characteristic the historic buildings that make this corner of the city tremendously fascinating.

Need to know where you're going. I'm from Lisbon, and therefore I visit quite often this place in Lisbon. It is nowdays a quite safe place to visit, though during night you should be aware of the streets you are going in to: there are streets crowed with nice, trendy and friendly peolple, but there are also some streets a bit dangerous, speciatly for tourists. If you could arrange someone who knows the area to go with with, great! Otherwise, just make sure you keep yourself in the lower streets (the ones next to Largo Camões) and those more crowed, which are usually the more safe.Nevertheless, it is still one of the best places to meet people and the true evening out spirit of "Lisboa"!
Anti stress. More tourists no...Bat I like it...for eat, for fado, for bars, for shops. Don't drink very much and enjoy the spirit in extinction (mutation) of the old Lisbon. No parking.

old Lisbon for young people. a lot of small streets with bars and restaurants . Very nice place to be visited by everybody and by night mainly by young people . Take care in the places that are not crowded .
Lisbon night life essential. Plenty of wine bars, trendy restaurants, fado singing. Very lively in the evening - not to miss if you want to discover genuine Lisbon!

The best in Lisbon. The most beautiful neighboorhood in Lisbon. I´t's a must see in the city. Nice and simply people, good food, full of young people at night, and where you can observe some of the most beautifuls views over the city in "Miradouro São Pedro Alcântara" and "Elevador da Bica".

great neighborhood. This is a very nice area for staying a couple of days in Lisbon. It is right in the centre near all the things to see. And if you want to go a bit further for instance to Belem to see the Jeronimos convent, then just take a taxi, these are very cheap in Lisbon
Authentic living. Small streets are lovely everywhere! Small local coffee places as well as other local shops. Thanks there still are those!

Vibrant night life. It is a neighbourhood to hang out at night, full of bars and restaurants. The actual party takes place on the streets in front of the bars ... which one to recommend? there are so many ... simply go with the flow in the narrow streets and find the one you like ... and enjoy the spirits of night Lisbon :)
Nothing starts until midnight!. A really fun neighborhood, complete with bars, restaurants and shops. Don't plan to go there before midnight, as it will be too quiet.
A view from above. This is an wonderful area with many varied restuarants and shops.Great for the fashionista in all of us.

Night life yes, but more touristic. Its definitely a good place to drink and have fun. But I did miss the authentic atmosphere which makes the city so interesting. After one night there, i would say better go in the mouro quarter or alfama. Quite touristic as well but somewhat more lisbonese atmosphere
Good views. Head up to the higher parts of Lisbon for some good, scenic views and some interesting out-of-the-way shops and cafes.

Awesome Night Out. A great night out - cheap drinks, party atmosphere spilling out onto the streets with a mix of locals and tourists.You can even play the fun game of try to haggle this best price out of the people selling rubbish sunglasses - 3 for 2 euro is my record!

Excellent night out. My trip to Lisbon was my favourite holiday ever and fun and friendly nightlife of Bairro Alto was definitely the reason for this. The bars are fun and lively with people spilling out into the street until the early morning.Mahjong was always a good starter, then see where the night takes you. I don't remember hearing that many tourists in this area, mainly Portuguese voices I think.Desperate to head back to Lisbon some day.

Prepare to stay up late. For my money, the best place to party in Europe. Get lost in Barrio Alto's little side streets and go from tiny bar to bar for live music, great DJs cocktails and a cool, happy atmosphere. I was travelling alone and met people every night, felt welcome and safe and got really rather drunk. Stay at the Independente Hostel nearby for the end of the night crash. Enjoy!

night life. This neighborhood gets going around midnight and is packed with bars and people drinking on the streets. I didn't see too much rowdiness but I only stayed out until about 2am. It's fun to walk around and to try some of the common drinks that the bars offer. None of the drinks seem to be expensive. I saw some strollers but I wouldn't bring young kids here after 11pm.

Worth a visit. The Bairro Alto is an area of Lisbon where there are many restaurants, bars, boutiques and book shops. Old-world elegance, somewhat faded.One gets a good feel of Lisbon when walking the Bairro Alto and we found ourselves returning time and again.
Wild, Cachaca in litres...why not?. Party central with huge, potent drinks and litres of cachaca for 6 euros....BUT BE WARNED....never drink a triple X shot (XXX)....the hangover is HORRIFYING.

Best bars, restaurants and beautiful people!!. All nights we went to this district, really full of all types of parties, people and good good restaurants, unexpensive and tasty!! If you go to Lisboa you have to spend at least a couple of nights there!!

LOVED THE AREA. It was if all the streets became restaurants after dark. We found wine bars, jazz music, and terrific restaurants. The scenic overlook (Miradouros) was a great entrance to this area and we rode the tram up the hill to find all of these hidden gems. Highly recommend a least one evening in Bairro Alto.

Having fun in Lisbon. When visiting Lisbon, you must go to Bairro Alto. The area is recommended for people who like small pubs, narrow streets, crowded of people until 2 a.m. Cheap beer, live music and nice mood. I recommend.
Night Life Immense. This is the area to hit at night time if you are looking for some craic and banter. People fill the streets after buying their drink.

Nice atmosphere, great drinks. This place is a tipical Portuguese style of hang out. Plenty of bars to chose from, people then reverse on the street and there is this chilled party atmosphere. Drinks are cheap: with € 6 you can get an XXL Caipirinha, Mojito,etc and the size it's 75cl (a bottle of wine worth of cocktail!)Top tips: 1. Mind your wallet, pick pockets are around

Great bohemian atmosphere, night life.. This place comes alive at night. Great for a walk tour. Stop by small bars and enjoy a snack or some port. I recommend Bar du Bairro - try the honey beer if they still have it.

Restaurants and night life. This area is filled with a great selection of restaurants and should be visited. At night, the area becomes filled with people walking, drinking, and standing in front of pubs. Lovely place.

Great atmosphere!. It's always nice to walk trough the streets of old european towns bit this one is a little different, The atmosphere is great, people are nice and welcoming, and the little cafe's are charming,

Great for nightlife (TAKE CARE OF YOUR WALLET): live bar, cheap drinking, crowd on the street. Better go on the weekend when is very crowd, be careful that often some people try to steal your wallet walking on the crowd, it's happen to several friend of mine!
Its ok but quite a touristtrap.. Lots of restaurants and shops but all is oriented towards tourism of the mass kind, so nothing much interesting after you have looked around for an hour or so.
Best. During the day this area of Lisbon looks beautiful, at night you have many options of bars and restaurants for any preference!

Brilliant part of Lisbon city. Lisbon is a lovely city and full of history and atmosphere and nowhere in the city does it better than the Bairro Alto. In summer it can get very hot in the daytime but if not too hot then just wondering the streets of the Bairro Alto will give you a great feel for Lisbon and its people, it is a wonderful area to walk around and soak up the atmosphere of a great city.
bars and bites. Plenty of bars along the back streets, as well as restaurants serving traditional Portugese fare. Gay friendly.

Great atmosphere but drug pushers intimidate you. I was excited to go to this lively neighbourhood. We walked around the streets, into different bars with our drinks and its very vaired, with an incredible vibe. We explored it for just over an hour at night,although was dead during the day. Unfortunately, in this time, I hot offered hardcore drugs SEVEN times, with pushers approaching me and my partner and often trying to persuade us to try drugs and then following us down the street, which was very intimidating. If you go here, have your wits about you. This soured an otherwise maxing nightlife experience.

Charming place for drinks. This is the most lively area in Lisbon and therefore it will almost systematically be crowed. Make sure you stop there for drinks after dinner - but for dinner itself, I found you have better options in the surrounding areas.

Meeting Other Exchange Students. Bairro Alto is a remarkable location for each exchange student in Lisboa. If you are a local or a foreign student, who would like to meet the other students, specifically the foreign students who come to Lisboa, under the programmes such as Erasmus, Erasmus Mundus, or Brazil, this is the ideal place to visit. Grab a cup of beer or two, and spend some Friday nights here, to get some new friends or more than that. The place might not be safe, if you are coming with valuables, as it is noted that petty theft is not uncommon in this neighbourhood. However, if you are vigilant enough, you will surely have some quality time here.

We Had A Blast. We spent just about everyone of our six nights in Lisbon wandering the streets and stopping into bars and restaurants of Barrio Alto. It was a bit quite on a Monday, but electric Thursdays through the weekend.
many options. During the day this area of Lisbon looks beautiful, at night you have many options of bars and restaurants for any preference!

Fabulous!!. We went here expecting it to be ridiculously touristy and tacky. But the old town is beautiful and frequented by locals and tourists alike. Didn't feel like a tourist trap, even if it might have been!!! Some gorgeous restaurants and wine bars and very photogenic. Now home, already planning when I can go back to the Barrio Alto/Lisboa!!

quick visit. It is a lovely historical place, with all the churches , museums and theaters. All these amazingly beautiful building give some romance to the neighborhood. However, I would recommend to visit during day, but not at night. Also, you may think to eat to a different spot.A lot of immigrants around, who do not seem to follow the basic rules for discipline and hygiene. (please check out the photos)

Gret place to wonder around. Lots of great restaurants and little shops that offer about anything. The views of the city are great especially in the evening or early morning. Nightlife pretty hopping, watch the odd folks that claim to offer drugs at night, they are seedy but not too threatening.
Walk the streets. Get off the downtown streets and up to the look-outs, shops, bars and scenery of this neighbourhood as fast as you can.
Fun area to walk around and eat and drink on.. Weekends are definately best but you can have fun here weekdays too. Lots of small restaurants and bars. Watch the touts and pickpockets however.

What bars???. Sent over an hour trudging around the area ( maybe too early - 6.00pm) and saw very little in the way of exciting bars and places to go for a drink. Really disappointing. Maybe a better bet for the late night party brigade?

Character abounds!. The Bairro Alto is a great neighbourhood! I loved walking around and exploring the area. There are lovely restaurants, cafes and bars. Be prepared to deal with the narrow and sometimes crowded streets.
Funky small streets to wander. We enjoyed exploring the side streets. Lots of good people watching, small cares and bars and restaurants.
Be careful!. Lively area but if you are over thirty don't go - noisy and dirty. It could be so nice if only the police and bar/restaurant owners discouraged noise and filth

nightlife. This is the place to be at night if you want to go cheap and hang out with the locals. Or for late afternoon drinks or dinner, don't really recommend during the day as not for wandering about.
Party. Somewhat seedy for a young crowd, this is the land of bars and disco clubs. Loud and unique with narrow streets and an old world feel. They party until the wee hours. Great restaurants too

Best place for dinner and drinks. Well...if you want to try Lisbon's nightlife, you must go to Baiiro Alto.It is the place where most people go for dinner or only fot a couple of drinks afterwards.Most people just stay out on the streets talking and meeting each other, while drinking a beer. There's many bars and restaurants from where to chose, si you certainly will find something you like.
Bairro Alto. Very attractive historic area, great for just wandering, but you need to be reasonably fit to manage all the steps and steep streets!

Up and down. Up and down - down and up... Yes, this is Lisbon essentials! If your'e here for the first time, missing it would be a crime. Bars, crowds, alleys, atmosphere, trams, funicular... go there!
Fun and lively area. Crowded with Bars, you must check out Bairro Alto when you are in Lisbon. A fun time is sure to follow.
you cannot miss. Needless to say anything. I think ppl who stays in Lisbon cannot miss this area. I think I can live here ;)

Buzzing area. Great for coffee and a cake, or perhaps a white port in the afternoon. Lots of excellent buskers. A very lively street scene. Eat inside the cafes for the best service and food choice for lunch.

Fairly awful neighbourhood. Travel books often describe this area as quirky and interesting, even charming. I found it depressing, dirty, covered in graffiti. The so-called shopping street was narrow, the shops had narrow frontages, hard to see inside, pavement in disrepair. The bars and restaurants small, gloomy and forbidding. Unless something is done to fix up the graffiti and the dirt it's hardly worth going there.
Must-stop for Lisbon nightlife. Fantastic hipster area. Daytime has many interesting shops while nighttime offers many restaurants/bars and live music. Great for people watching.
spirit of lisbon. Perfect place to go out if you want to meet lots of people. Lots of fun lots of small bars with very cheap drinks . Def must visit !!!

emotional Fado. I was walking around trying to find good place to listen to some music, spacially traditional Portugese music. Locals were really nice and they show me some places. One of the best was Tasco do chico. Small place full of memories from the past concerts. It was really impresive with full of emotions and passion. Whole audience was totally dedicated to Fado and thay really respect music and musicians. They had some short breaks and this was the only time you could get in or out. Otherwise the doors were closed.

fun, interesting, noisy, crazy streets, lots of hills. Another interesting corner of Lisbon. I don't recommend staying here if you don't like the nightlife or you have mobility issues or you're nervous when getting lost in a new city! However, if you're comfortable going with the flow, then go for it. It's a more authentic corner of Lisbon and you'll get a feel for the spirit of Lisbon.

An Energetic and countless Variety unique night life!. This small area of Lisbon is a must visit for at least one night on every traveller's stop through this beautiful city. The Barrio Alto district is packed with beautiful restaurants and night life for every flavor or interest: Jazz, pubs - quaint and modren alike, hard hitting clubs, wine bars, cafes, salsa dancing, and an unlimited number of live music venues.The party first fills the most popular venues then spills out into the narrow streets. Before the night is even started, it seems the streets are filled, nearly shoulder to shoulder. Definitely worth an evening!

Go here for dinner. Loads of inexpensive restaurants and great atmosphere. Later there are bars for the young, and young at heart. If you are in Baixa (the central, lower part of town) you can access the Barrio Alto by funicular just north of the Restauradores metro stop.

A great night out. We visited Bairro Alto for a couple of nights when Newcastle were playing Benfica. It's a rabbit warren of small bars which comes alive after 11 pm. I cannot say enough how friendly and welcoming the Lisboans are.

Favorite part of town. This section of Lisbon has everything you need as a tourist.Great first class hotels, restaurants every ten feet , from economyto Michelin star. You also have theaters, famous cafes, and even antique shops. You also have easy transportation from the square.(taxis), which you don't need because everything is walking distance including the Baixa(down town)

Fun Night!. On the first Friday night my husband and I were in Lisbon we headed a few blocks down from our hotel to the awesome nightlife that is Barrio Alto! The streets were swarming with a friendly young crowd, everyone going in & out of local bars. It kind of reminded me of Bourbon St. in New Orleans, only everyone is way more friendly and it's not as dirty! We had a total blast drinking and dancing around with everyone in the streets! Great time!

Another good view of Lisbon from here.. Take the funicular up to the top! I loved the tiles on the funicular which gives it a lot of character. On top is a lovely garden to just relax in and view the city. Lot's of wonderful things to see, eat and discover in this area of Lisbon.

Best ever cod dish. This is an area that lights up at night, it is filled with amazing restaurants and bars. Every meal there was better than the last.Cod is their speacialty but I had a great steak dinner with the best fries!!!
Best part of Lisbon. You want to drink and eat here. What else is there? See it first empty, before 6 and then return after 10. It will be a sight.
busy streets. great place to visit, busy but worth it. lots of different shops and cafes. best to avoid in height of day, very hot!

Live music and beers till 3am. Bairro Alto is my favorite area in Lisbon. It has everything: great restaurants, tiny bars with live music, big bars with room for dancing, classy lounges and nice shops. If you're going to Lisbon and if you're young (but also if you're old) GO TO BAIRRO ALTO :)

Live music and beers till 3am. Bairro Alto is my favorite area in Lisbon. It has everything: great restaurants, tiny bars with live music, big bars with room for dancing, classy lounges and nice shops. If you're going to Lisbon and if you're young (but also if you're old) GO TO BAIRRO ALTO :)

love this place. We are staying here and the shops the coffe shops the people love everyone have business and the area so life nice place for drinks beer and white lots of places small. cozy, drink in the streets is fun fun fun noise

WOW!!!!!!!!. Where do I start Arrived late on a friday night to lisbon and decided to get a taxi to see the infamous Bairro Alto So worth it Had a couple of drinks and just drank in the brilliant atmosphere Went back again on Saturday night for dinner and drinks and again a great atmosphere Went again Sunday night and it was a bit quiet compared to the two previous nights but still brill!!! Definitely not to be missed
Great craic!. Brilliant atmosphere, some lovely well priced restaurants with great food, one "fado" restaurant had no menu and seriously overcharged us!

Bohemian Life. Full of bars, restaurantes and clubs. One of the best otion to enjoy night life. Get the Santa Justa lift to this high area of the city. The view is incredible, you can see most landmarks in the city centre lighted up.
