Walk through the narrow streets and find a place to have some drinks before a Fado show- there are many houses up there. Than try a typical Portuguese dinner accompanied with wine.

The place to be in Lisbon. Quirky, Rustic, tons of cool bars and great restaurants and a really fantastic atmosphere on a weekend night. Nice and central in the city and not too far to walk to many other areas.

My favorite neighborhood in Lisbon!. Here I spent most of my time in Lisbon, fantastic, loved the small streets, all the squares with small cafes, little terraces, views, elevators, and the night life! Must see and feel the atmosphere!

lovely vibey environ. Stayed just beyond Bairro Alto and pleased that we were not sleeping there as noisy and full of life. Bairro Alto and Chiado glide into each other. Followed many of the trip advisor recommendations and they were very accurate. Nice mix of churches, bookshops, barber shops, cafes, food and shopping. Nice to wander through and get a feel for modern and old Lisbon
Fun and funky nightlife. Lots of charming and eclectic restaurants to choose from that seem very popular. This is a busy area bustling at night time. Fun!

Keep your head cool `cause they will not.. Bairro Alto is adorable. At day. Has restaurants, souvenir shops, locals, tourists, it`s like going through multinational veins. Despite the amount of people, I felt safe. But at evening and night, when you want to grab a bite, prepare for "vultures" staying outside restaurants. I heard they aren`t nasty as the ones in Morocco or Egypt, but put your poker face on if you don`t want to enter that particular restaurant. Looking at them, smiling, talking to them, answering their questions (where are you from? _____ oh, yes I know (smth from your country)____), looking confused and lost, turns them on and you`ll be eating in their restaurant in no time. Unless this is exactly what you want, which is fine too :)

Plenty of clubs and restaurants.. Those "in the know "dine here and party here as this hilly part of town doesnt slow down until about 6 in the morning. If you go out for dinner before 8 they know you are a tourist.. locals head out about 9-9:30 ish. The smaller the sign on the door or wall the likelyhood the restaurant is good.. The better ones may not have anything on the outside to let you a great restaurant is inside! Bring your walking shoes and these narrow streets wander up and down the hillside but its worth the walk to discover some of the best dining gems in Lisbon!

Fine for what it is. I had three drinks at Cinco Lounge (check my review) and said to the bartendar, "Now I'm going to check out the Bairro Alto." "What do you want to do that for?" he replied. "It's nothing but 22-year-olds getting drunk."This was around 11:30 on a Friday night and yes, he was correct. If you are at all familiar with college-area nightlife - cheap drinks, cheap karaoke, weirdos, packs of young 20somethings - you will recognize it here. I went to a karaoke bar, got hammered, met some dude who was a heavy metal fan, walked around, then walked home to my hotel at 2:30 am.Actually, if you're an older adult or with a partner, you can go here and have dinner in one of the many, many restaurants here around 10 or 11, then head home. Still a good night out. A word on safety - I was alone and when I turned the corner to see an empty street, I skipped it. Just a precaution. There are so many people around here that a brisk walk and a firm shake of the head will solve 99% of problems. Not that I had any.

legs. bairro alto i walk up to the top great views nice restaurants watched the trams going up and down that very very steep hill then walked down what seemed like hundreds of steps i made a stop half way down at a great bar restaurant solar do duque,my legs needed a stop,i also stopped at the bottom a little wine bar it was well worth it
lots of places to eat and drink. There is loads of nice places to eat and drink where you can meet different people and taste Portuguese atmosphere.

Sightseeing in the heights. We spent most of our time in Lisbon in Alfama, which is where we stayed, but we were glad to have the chance to visit some of Bairro Alto's highlights: the Miradouro de Sao Pedro de Alcantara, Solar do Vinho do Porto (Institute of Port Wine), Igreja Sao Roque and Convento do Carmo, as well as some nice cafes and shops. It was well worth finding our way up to the top of the hill - we enjoyed our time up there!

Fado clubs. Wine tasting and Fado clubs for night life along the narrow streets/alleys. Take the funicular tram to the top for a view of Lisbon and the castle across to the west and walk down trying some of the wine bars and end at a Fado club for dinner and music.
Great Place to Hang Out. Lots of great bars and wine bars, good vibe, lively, lots of fun. People are friendly, feels very safe. Good restaurants. Fun to walk around.
Steep streets. Nice area to explore but some very steep streets. Not much in the way of shops but nice to wander around and people watch the locals.

No longer what it used to be. This used to be a great place to go out at night, full of diversity and good vibes. In previous years its frequency has detriorated. I see is as almost decadent nowadays....

Nice to walk. Very pleasent district on the one of the city's heights. Has varity of styles in constructions - from late barocco to baohaus. Has very nice observation point and many nice places for apperitive.

Disappointing. I visited Bairro Alto at night, thinking it would be so much fun but I soon realized that if you're not a drinking person you will not have much fun there. Sure it is an historical part of the city of Lisbon, and that is indeed interesting, but I didn't like it anyway cause I couldn't get over that fact that the only thing there is there is a bunch of small bars, so small that you only go inside to get some drink and have to leave right away cause... well, cause that's really what is their purpose: sell drinks to people that only go there to get wasted. Don't get me wrong: if you like to drink this is a place to visit, but if you don't I wouldn't recomend it at all.
Bohemian nightlife. Lots of eateries with Fado music. Don't go before 9pm. Very steep access, but served by trans/funicular. Watch what the locals are trying and go for it.

go in the evening. walked around this area at lunchtime,trying to find something that 'took my fancy' to eat.after about 30 mins ,walking up via rosa and around,i discovered that most places open at night .it was rather a grubby looking area in cruel daytime and i did not return.most places,which displayed a menu seemed to be offering the same thing and the same as in the 'centre'

Nice neighborhood. We had a great night out in Barrio Alto in April 2013. Dined at the Independente Hostel, which has an amazing little restaurant. Trendy, tasty and affordable food comparable to anything we've had in NYC. Walked around the neighborhood afterwards and were very surprised to find how quiet it was at 10-11 pm. Found a decent wine bar (the name escapes me). Worth a visit.

Fiesta, baby!. This is the must see place when you visit Lisbon!Buzzing and crowded nightlife - at night. Great art shops and restaurants during the day!So yes, I visited it twice and I would definitely go back!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

All in all the Alto is a great place to explore. Barrio Alto hides a lot of wonderful places. Just wandering round the little street and up and down the steps gives you a great feeling for the Barrio's character. There seems to be a view , a park , or special restaurant on every turn. You can't come to Lisbon and not wander round here. It might feel like you'd get lost but just head down and you'll find your way back to a main street!

Some good choices for the evening. The Bairro Alto is easy to find and easy to get to, by foot, Tram and Taxi! There is a good selection of Fado restaurants and restaurants for all budgets. We visited 3 Fado restaurants before we made our final choice and returned 2 more times to try other places.

What a place. i loved how chilled the Barrio is there are lots of great little bars tucked away were you can listen to some music have a drink and grab something to eat . There are lots of great people just chilling out going about there own business a great night out for anyone of any age and a beer and a vodka costs less than 7 euros and you can grab a mojito for 3 almost anywhere , a must at least for one night

Buzzing nightlife. We spent one night on the town in Bairro Alto. After dinner we met up with a group from our hostel and hit the bars. The first few bars were very enjoyable. We got a seat and had a few cocktails, enjoyed the music. As the night wore on the bars got busier and people were flooding out onto the streets. The music was very good but the bars were very packed. People were squeezing past each other to get to the bar, spilling drinks and bumping off each other. That was fine. Not very enjoyable but to be expected on a busy night. What I didn't like was when the bars stopped serving there was a massive swell of very drunken people out into the narrow street. I hadn't drank much as I wasn't feeling well and I felt very vulnerable in this situation. Some people were being quite aggressive to strangers standing next to them. When I heard glass being thrown I insisted to my husband that we go home. He was bit more drunk and didn't see the danger. I personally didn't think it was the best night.

Beautiful old area in the evening. Very nice old area in the evenings and nights. Lot's of restaurants and bars with live music! During daytime this area is very quiet. I was there for a weekend, but it was too short. Friday evening is the best evening to be there, because it's not that crowded as on Saturdays. I will visit this area again, definitely!!
Sinal, a great restaurant. Mostly low-end street/table restaurants,with barkers trying to drag you in...but if you search, you'll find some very good restaurants, beyond the bowls of fish and rice.

Elegant with Amazing Views. Lisbon is just filled with the most magnificent and marvelous sites. You must go to Barrio Alta to really appreciate the beautiful vistas of this enchanted city. You will feel transported to a new dimension.

Breathtaking views from the historic area. One must visit the BA, it takes one back in time! My third visit to Lisbon, and always want to return. If you love a sense of history, being in a well preserved historic area, this is the place for you.
Busy back streets. Lots of bars and restaurants to visit, especially on a Saturday evening. Make sure you visit the Old Pharmacy Wine bar, their house red is delicious.

Buzzing and crowded nightlife. Come to Bairro Alto during the weekdays it is a normal neighborhood with bars that have few visitors, come to Bairro Alto friday or saturday you can't even walk there, it will be completely packed and the ambience is great. Highly recommended for nightlife lovers.

Stay here, great neighborhood. I stayed here and loved it. There are hidden restaurants and bars on all the little streets and it has a great neighborhoody feel. Next time I'm back, I'll stay here again. I was lucky enough to have a 4th floor apartment with great views looking down on all the red rooftops. A bit of a workout, but it's worth it. It helps you take it slow and appreciate what's around you.

Stay Here. Great area to stay during your visit. Central and lots to see and do. This area is very "happening" with many options to eat and drink, not to mention great views of the rest of the city from the overlook.

The bar and restaurant area, worth a stay!. The Oasis backpacker hostel is in the Bairro Alto area so if you stay there, you'll be right in the middle of the party area and where you'll get all the good stuff. The district wakes up after sunset and you'll find lots of bars, pubs and clubs with people from every nation.

Quarter for traditional fado music, but many restaurants are over prices tourist traps.. The streets in this quarter are filled with restaurants, Instead of going to a tourist trap place , go to a small qaint ( authentic)resttaurant.... we ate at Petiscos no BairroRua da Atalaia, 133, Small intimate family run place with only about 10 tables!! worth it!

Party Time. It's a great place to enjoy the nightlife of Portugal. People just sit on the street and drink. The place is very lively. People start coming in only after 10 in night. But stay away from youngsters who are very high and looking to pick up a fight. Otherwise it's great.

Where the locals have fun. Bairro Alto is full of great bars, restaurants and cafes that spill out into the cobbled streets and laneways in the evenings. You have the choice of Tapas, Italian, Indian and Traditional Portugese cuisine, as well as some of the best little wine bars in the city. Many of the locals crowd into the area at night to soak up the lively music and vibe.

Stay Here!. If you are planning a trip to Lisbon I would highly suggest finding lodging in this neighborhood. It is a great central location with lots of great restaurants and a beautiful overlook with views of the city.
The best. For one, two ore more drinks, lots of conversations, lots of friends. we can spend our night here or spend the first "half" of the nice...

Very nice. I loved taking the tram and going through all the streets listening to the story of the places. We hopped on and off to take a closer look at each place. Tram took a bi to show up but it was worth it.

Day trip. Tom a few day trips, it is worth it to purchase a ticket on the bus, you have 48 to hop on and off as you wish, it is not a city transit it is a tourism bus. Worth it for sure, we took the 3 bus option for 22 euros each

Bustling. Yep a really bustling fun part of Lisbon howver when we wvisited we were with about 5000 Newcastle Untied fans and the local guys were selling us everything yo can think of sunglasses umbrellas trinkets and lots of beggars but if you can let this go over your head then the shops are very cool.

The place to be at night!. This area is a must tour - day or might, for a snack or a meal in one of the many Fado restaurants. The nights can be REALLY busy with a lot of young people drinking but join in the fun and have a cocktail while you tour and peoploe watch!The views at the little park over look Lisbon and at night its nothing short of breath taking.

Barrio Alto is very cool.. If you can't find your pleasure in Barrio Alto you must be not capable of having fun. Food , drink, people, music, visual stimulus is all there. Start your exploration in the early evening ( 9ish), get a bite to eat then go enjoy ! Music, more food, drink, smoke, it's all good till the morning.
Best area in Lissabon. And in the World. Fantastik area for food and drink and vintage shopping and groning out in the Night. Best atmosphere ever.

Great fun in the weekend. Bairro Alto is the place to be on a weekend evening. The streets are full of people of all ages, but it's definitely more attractive for the young people. Here you can find a lot of bars, pubs, but also some fancy restaurants, and some great places to listen to fado and enjoy a traditional Portuguese meal.

great place to wallk. We walked in the area day time and night. Nice little streets, nice atmosphere and great people.Some restaurants send people to fined tourists and try to convince them to come dine there. It's a little disturbing, and make you uncomfortable to walk by
Funky. Lots of great places to have a drink and to eat. Always really busy and great for people watching. Definitely go for one night when in Lisbon.

fun night out. we had a lovely meal in a posh restaurant and then did a pub crawl which involved my 80 year old mother and a few of us heading for a pub that had fado music as we drank wine. We loved it.

Good area for finding good food. The best area to find nice restaurant to have a great lunch or diner. Also this area contains many small bars or pubs its a perfect place to hangout during the evening. A must to visit when your traveling in Lisbon.

Party in da City!. We were lucky to live just 10 minutes walk from the area. It's a perfect place for a young couple for a city trip as it's full of bars and restaurants for all kinds of taste. Drinks are cheap and you can find live jazz or other music playing in several of them. Even on Mon-Tue you can always find an open place to sit of most of the night.Definitely a must to hang out at in Lisbon. Bairro Alto is the area making Lisbon even cooler!:)

Great place for a night out. I really like that the nightlife is lived on the streets. You can get cheap beers and cocktails here, drink in the bars with live music or go outside. It's a really nice atmosphere, everyone is out for a good time, and you will certainly enjoy it.

Check this area on a weekend night. During the day the area looks empty but at night the doors open up to reveal allyways filled with bars and restaurants. it can be a party in the street when the weather is nice. The drinks are cheap and there is plenty of action. A must stop area for night life seekers.
Funny area. Funny bar area to go for a drink ! Dont be afraid, its crowded and you have also some strange people hanging around there but its real safe - we enjoyed it :) !

Gangsta. 3 good mates on a 5 day break,looking for a laugh but love chatting to each other and others too....perfect location, so good one of my mates has ended up moving to Sweden to shack up with one of a group of amazing swedes/Iranians we met...rest of the time we walked the streets spoke with other travellers and locals, drank cheap beers,bar hopped under no pressure, played fubball just a genuine good vibe in a safe environment, irish lads dream

The vibe of the city. Definitely you want to experience this piece of Fado city culture and dynamic lively bars, shows, restaurants that you can find on the very famous stairs in Bairro Alto. You get a surprise at every corner and you can easily find yourself at a party without even knowing that was there..Surprisingly beautiful and charming.

Eat, Pray and Panoramic view. Best way for enter to Bairro Alto is hill tram close to rossi place. when you rich to top of the hill , youd' better make ready your Camera to shot many poses of panoramic view of lisbon . after that lose your self into the streets of bairro. After that I'am sure that you find your ways and restaurants by the listenning of Fado music. Fado will call you .

Must visit if in Lisbon!!. Definitely worth walking through the Barrio Alto neighborhood. It is a real mix of old and new, not just buildings but in every way...traditions, ages of people, foods, restaurants/bars, shops, etc. Take the elevator up to the top and walk downhill...your feet and legs will thank you!!
Great neighborhood in Lisbon!. We went to the Bairro Alto all three nights of our stay in Lisbon. On its windy streets you'll find great restaurants, bars and fado music. Definitely recommend!

Interesting old town. Very high up so good to visit by funicular, which is a must do in Lisbon. The Bairro Alto was born as a response to the social and economic transformation in Lisbon in the second half of the 15th century.
Funny Place at any time of the day.. If you enjoy walking between little picturesque streets with nice squares between coffee shops, art shops or at night some bars, then its a great option to visit.

Lively area. Stayed in Bairro Alto with friends, Convenient area that comes alive at night. Full of little bars, restaurants and shops. Plenty of character with old buildings and narrow streets, Would stay there again.

So much life late at night. If you going out in Lisbon and fancy a late night drink or a bit of live music the Bairro Alto area is difficult to beat. Busy narrow streets bursting with life have numerous bars on every corner, many with life music.

Nice to visit. The Bairro Alto is charming as all areas of the city, but it is very touristy, especially the main road junction where the tram stops. However, we found the cafe at the top of the funicular in a park on a view point, and it was very pleasant, with great views across the city.

The place to go at the weekend. More bars restaurants and clubs than you could imagine, hordes of revellers all out in the street socializing, amazing on the \Saturday night. although we returned midweek it was so disappointing! There were more waiters trying to coax you into their restaurants than there were people.

woow!!!. I spent here almost all my nights in Lisbon!
Funny and maybe the best place in the planet to interact with people from everywhere, and practice any languaje.
Is crowded but you have a hundred of bars to go during the night, and during the day you have small but interesting stores.

the old town. This has all the character of old Lisbon: little windy streets full of shops, bars cafes and a glimpse of how it used to be. Lovely area just to wander around. Also great at night, of course, full of life day and night

Buzzing District. All the finest independent shops, and some more familiar in Bairro Alto. By day, wander and you'll go from town to village and back again in seconds - and by night watch restaurants appear around every corner.

Portugal at it's best. In our way to Rome, we where extremely well served as we listened to some Fado from the local "friends" of Chico!
The place was crouded but it's easy to know why: the joy, the music and the food is what it makes Portugal so special.

It's a great tourist neighborhood to promenade. Even in a wheelchair.. The Bairro Alto is an old touristic neighborhood in the center of Lisbon. At the end of the fifteenth century it was named Vila Nova de Andrade and it consists of the “frequesias” of the Incarnation and Santa Catarina. The streets are narrow and very steep. The houses in the area are very old. The local trade is small. Its main attractions are restaurants and bars resulting in a wonderful place for enjoying the nightlife. The views from the belvedere are spectacular, including the beautiful Tejo river. Climb in the trolley. Mingle with the locals who are friendly, welcoming and cheerful. It will be a pleasant experience. However, if you are a disabled person you will have to take a taxi or a van. The trolley has no entry for the wheelchair. The steps of the Monorail’s entrance are too narrow. There are no restaurants or bars suitable for the disabled. A cool thing to do is sit on the sidewalk tables of bars that extend beyond the inside. You will be able to use the wheelchair in the region as long as you have someone to help you on the more difficult spots. There are unexpected holes and the streets narrow with no warnings. There are no appropriate recesses to climb up and down the sidewalks. Walking on crutches will present the same difficulties. Despite all that, the beauty of the view, the contact with the local and the food and fun in the bars and restaurants are a good reward for all the effort. Just sit and relax with an incredible view,

Fun place with lots of restaurants and clubs.. Must visit during both day and night at least once. Can be touristy, but easy place to wander, find a restaurant or club to sit and then walk around some more.
Bairro Alto. Fun ride up in the funicular, amazing views of the city from Bairro Alto, fun place to be, some parts look a little sketchy at night but all in all safe and fun.

Nice area!. This area of the city is a must place to go. It's the place to walk and sit at one of the cafes and enjoy the scenery ... the neighbourhood is full of small restaurants and bars. Very touristic and friendly.

Old, beautiful!!. If you want to get into Lisbon life, Bairro Alto is one the place to go. Old construction, a very Portuguese style, remembering the time of empire. Palaces, Old remodeled house can be found all over.. Surely take the tram 28.. or you will be tired to walk. :)

Get in touch with the Portuguese youth. It is a fun place for younger people. things get hectic late in the evening and the best starting point is my Camoes square. It has many houses of Fado, so why not get 2 activities done at once!

Lots of restaurants & bars. This area is full of very good restaurants and bars. You can walk around quite safely and choose what menu you like best. Don't be put off by small entrances as once inside they are all pretty big and food was excellent.

Very trendy boutiques and a diversity of restaurants. This old neighbor in the heart of Lisbon offers an array of trendy boutiques and a diversity of restaurants. Located on a hill, Bairro Alto is packed in the evenings with a youngish crowd, mostly tourists, lots of Spanish and Germans. My favorite these days is "A Taberna da Rua das Flores", Rua Flores 103, 1200-194 Lisbon, Portugal. Phone:+351 213 479 418. You'll get the sit cheek to cheek with Bairo Alto's bohemia and experience the best of Portuguese cuisine's!
historic. variety of bars and restaurants, lots of fun and nightlife, good place for groups, fabulous architecture.
During the day or by night. go there at day light and after dinner. Go for shopping or just discover the narrow streets and shops and places or go to the bars at night.
Graffitti Graffitti Graffitti. The plastering of walls with so much graffitti is very off putting as it makes the area look very run down and dingy.What may be art to some is just grotty graffitti.

take the tram. take the tram to reach Bairro Alto if not you will go straight to the hotel to sleep. it is a very nice location in Lisbon that offers you an excellent view of the town. the small streets and buildings create a perfect atmosphere

Liked it. Very beautiful, filled with amazing looking houses, but it felt a little ran down. Didn't like some of the many bars in the area because of that reason. They are not very well taken care of. Also restaurants not very impressive. But the history and the architecture are worth seeing.
Smaller than expected. Underwhelming area, suffering badly from the Lisbon blight of graffiti. Look for the Japanese buffet restaurant - might not be 'local' but very good and outstanding value.

A must-see in Lisbon. Once the very heart of the city's night life, it has regained its allure in the last years. You can find a young crowd over there, enjoying life. Beware of the dark side of the neigborhood. Seek advice and find a way to visit it safely. It is going to worth every pennie.
Not to be missed!!!. Can't miss this neighbourhood in LIsbon! Full of bars, restaurants, little shops...get lost in the narrow streets!!!

Small Restaurants. Many local, small restaurants located in this area. We also recommend a small local Fado Bar named Tosca da Chaco...The owner sings as well as his waiting staff and local friends. Open on Monday and Wednesday nights...no pressure, no cover charge...get there around 8 PM to get in...the music started around 9 PM
Unique. It's really great if you love party and how doesn't i went there every night, you can find local people but many many many tourist, but after a few drinks who cares... :D

A great place for dinner and for late drinking. This is still one of the best places to have a dinner in Lisbon. One can find here all kind of restaurants (portuguese or international, from cheap to a bit more expensive). Later in the evening there are bars almost in every door...

not the safest place. it has a very romantic and artistic image, it feels like a place you want to discover, it has some great viewingpoints (miradouro), but in the night it can be spooky. don't go there during the night unless you are in a medium to large group (at least 6-7 people).go and see the ruins of the convent and go to cerveceria trinidade.

Go at night!. Go to Barrio Alto to see it during the day or in the afternoon to take some pictures. Ok, but not so special, it did not impress me. I made that mistake of judging too soon. You must go there at night and it will be THE place! If you stay away from the extremely touristy restaurant you will find excellent food and relatively inexpensive.

Fun! Fun! Fun. Seems like that's where all the nightlife fun happens:))I had the best nights out here! The area itself isn't big (more like Soho, London), but it has lots to offer!!! You start off in the bars that are open until 1-2am and then everyone moves on to the clubs, main,y in the same area. The company I was out with(around 15-20people) they all loved bar Bali and club Bali (two separate venues, run by the same people). You start in a bar and finish off ta the club. Great atmosphere, great staff and great people. Casual all the way..If you ever in Lisboa I can guarantee that's where you will end up:)Have fun x

Nightlife haven. For the last years this neighbourhood has been the undisputed nightlife district of Lisbon. During the day there is not much going on but from sunset onwards there are bars and restaurants on every other door. The atmosphere is great (especially if it is not raining since people just fill the streets) and there are bars for all tastes and budgets. Nowadays the Cais do Sodre neighbourhood down the road is also gaining strength in the Lisbon nightlife. Ideally go to both since they have so much to offer!

lively streets. Enjoyable wandering around the streets and great views of the splendid setting of Lisbon. One gets a sense of how Lisbon developed from the castle to the river. Even though it was a weekday, the streets were very lively. The weather was perfect too. We did not take Tram 28 but walked down to the cathedral, which made a good visit as well. We had a good lunch at the cafe of the Museum of Decorative Arts in a pleasant courtyard, but it was Monday and unfortunately the museum itself was closed.
shopping. little shopping places, big shopping places and that hugely famous cafe next to the metro stop. the cafe is not worth is, keep walking and find yourself something more portuguese

Fun at night, but plan to start late. Bairro Alto is a ton of fun on a weekend night, with so many small bars and restaurants and LOTS of people in the small alleyways and streets. This is also where you will find the best (most well known) of the Fado houses in Lisbon. All in all, this is an area and a night out that should not be missed if you are there for a weekend (and can schedule a "recovery day" for the following!!!!

The heart of Lisbon nightlife. The Bairro is picturesque during the day. Lots of shopping and sightseeing to be done (Sao Roque is gorgeous!) At night, though, this area transforms. There are so many bars and restaurants here, you could go to a different one every night for weeks. Hang out with locals and tourists alike. It's a vibrant scene. Chiado is right next door, and offers even more.

Large range of unusual shops. A very nice area to while away the time, a vast variety of shops, and many coffee shops and restaurants in the area.A shame about the limited luggage if you have traveled hand luggage only. There is always theancient viewing tower to travel up to the top, but ensure you have a travel card to pay for the lift otherwise risk being charged 5 euros each, as we saw others pay out.

The Party District of Lisbon. If you are looking for a bar with one type of music and be able to go to the next which plays the exactly opposite type of music, this is the place. From Fado, heavy metal, rock and techno all within a few feet of each other. The bars are all small and inviting. The prices are lower than you would expect in the States or the rest of Western Europe.Also, there is quite the selection of restaurants in the area.

Great Experience. I didn't know what to expect when told to visit the Bairro Alto. It was a balmy night, warm enough to wander the lanes and alleys. Every other house seems to have opened its doors to show a small bar area beyond to offer you drinks on the streets. Small crowds stand and banter outside some of the most popular. Thorougly enjoyed the experience and ended up at Mob - espaço associativo on Travessa da Queimada 33. Can highly recommend this bar/club with live music. It's a student place which costs 2 Euros to join and enter. Very good atmosphere and cheap drinks.
Climbing. This is the ultimate place in Lisboa, Climbing up´n´down, good athmosphere and good restaurants. Love it.

Take the elevator. Take the Santa Justa elevator, built by the same engineer who bilt the Eiffel tower and visit the Bairro Alto, going firts to the ruins of the Convento dÁjuda,kept as it was after the big earthquake that destroyed 1/3 of Lisbon in 1755.

Genuine barrio with a lot of restaurants. Genuine barrio with a lot of restaurants, but I wouldn't want to live here. Dark streets but filled with small restaurants and bars. I would stay in Chaido and walk to Barrio Alto for dining (very close). The restaurants are very small and I guess you have to reserve a table in the high season (visited in January)

Great quarter of the city. The narrow, hilly streets, team with people and a happy atmosphere at the weekend and is a great place to visit in the evening. The downside is the restaurant touts who pester tourists and the quality of the restaurants, which offer average food at inflated prices compared to other parts of the city.
very cool. Just loved it! A lot of bars and restaurants. If you're lookin' for a night out that's the place to go.

Nice but be careful at night. Being in the center at Restauradores you can take the funicular and go up to the Bairro Alto. During the day you can appreciate the panoramic view at the park of S. Pedro de Alcantara. At night open lots of small restaurants and bars. However after midnight be careful because there is not a secure place to walk around afterhours.

Do not take your car!. I made the mistake of driving up the Bairro Alto...very narrow streets (TWO WAY STREETS) and really hard to find parking. Very steep roads also. Beautiful though. Experience the area by streetcar instead. Great little shops and you can visit the St. George Castle ruins when you reach the top.

Perfect for New Year's Eve. Stayed in one of the few hotels in this neighborhood. I made it sure that I would get an inside room since I knew about how late into the night people filled its streets. The bars had live music. A experimental theater had a very good play on the 30th of December. You can walk to Chiado and do your shopping at brand stores. Most specially Bairro Alto has the charm of old neighborhoods, with old architecture and yes you get to accept as beautiful their clothes getting dried out of their windows and balconies. Coloful and quiet during the day. Fun, good music and great restaurants at night.
Nightlife as its best. Ful of trendy bars and discos,saunas.The place to begin the fantastic nightlife of Lisbon.You start whith a caipirinha and you never know how you will hend you night
Casa Luna for FADO. Not to miss this cabaret. Book early and come late when the real Fado begins. Early evening is folklore dancing. You go for the music not the food.

great. first time in Lisbon on a girly weekend, didnt really know where to go so we looked for pub crawls and found wild walkers. are guide was Hugo, really friendly guy, met lots of people from different nationalities, great night out !

Loud, chaotic, fun. … with crumbling buildings, acres of graffiti, steep narrow streets, pounding jazz/house/fado/rock and bright young things rambling around tipsy in the early hours. I booked an apartment here (from AirBnB) which was exceptional - very reasonably priced (especially as it was new year), vast, impeccably furnished and with a lovely landlord… All around are small restaurants and bars, nightclubs, but also derelict buildings, crumbling stone and cobblestones that would make a 20 yard walk in heels something of a challenge. The Bairro Alto has rather a bad reputation, but I felt entirely safe, I found the local fauna charming and friendly, one or two of the bars (El Gordo, Portas Largas) really pleasant, and the warren of streets gloriously atmospheric.
Nice area, excellent wine bars. An area with a great atmosphere and with excellent wine bars. Just a fun area to visit, many churches, squares and Tram 28.

Bar our History?. Peculiar place in Lisbon with a history of more than 500 years, but it really depends if you go there by day or night! Nice place to take pictures, to walk or just have lunch! If you go there by night it will be similar to he Ramblas in Barcelona, cheap beer and a lot of fun as there will be people all night in the street! However be careful with pickpocketing!

Funky alternative shops and restaurants. We explored this area on the last night and i wished i would have explored it on the first. Well worth a visit for the views, get the Elevador Da Gloria up as i thought i was having a heart attack when walking up all the steps. Lots of quirky shops and a large selection of culinary experiences.

Elegance Meets Seedy. The Barrio Alto district of Lisbon is a must see, must linger area. Within the 10 years since I previously visited this area, gentrification struck. Beautifully restored, buildings, parks, fountains, churches, hotels, have attracted trendy restaurants, designer brands, and the fashionable trend setters. But walk a, few blocks, and you still find empty decaying buildings, cheap restaurants, hostels, edgy bars, offering a variety of music and entertainment venues and those that follow that scene. The fashionable area is alive during the day, and early evening, while the seedier area, is in full bloom late nights and early mornings. Not sure, how long the two will live side by side. My bet....gentrification takes over Barrio Alto completely!Difficult, if any handicap accessibility, to many restaurants, bars, night life, historical sites, churches, etc.

Fado. Party loving neighborhood , Bistros and Bars. Go to Cafe Luso and the best Fado Singers. It is a place fit for all generation . The food served in this Cafe is good but a bit expensive. But if on holiday, it is ok. Just be careful of your personal belongings otherwise a good place to relax

i had visited Lisbon in 2010, and i stay at Barirro Alto, actually it is very nice place to stay,. but the bathroom should be improved and equip hot water, but everything ok, i enjoy staying there.The kitchen is clean and the living room is clean and well organised big enough for come around,there were also the TV, and the comfortable Saloon

Interesting streets- a little shabby, but nicely laid out. A bit on the touristy side with many tourist sips. But as it was raining a lot in Dec, the cheap and cheerful umbrellas were a good send! Nice street cafes to sit at and watch the world go by.

Real 'feel' of Lisbon. Beautiful steep streets with incomparable atmosphere. Great views 'downhill' towards the river and loads, loads. loads of incredibly good restaurants, bars, clubs and pubs. Loved it and spent hours just wandering around, stopping for food and drink. Take it easy and absorb the beauty

Superbe!. As i am from Athens (GR) we have some similar districts in the center of Athens. But Bairro Alto is so unique place with some incredible hospitality feeling that i couldn't find anywhere else. Α pedestrian area which is full of little bars and the summers outside of the bars the streets is filling with people drinking their Mojitos (or caipirinha) and chatting, beatboxing, etc. A wonderful iconic urban area, which i bet my fortune you gonna love it. I have visit Lisbon twice and i can't wait to go for a third time :)

Funky bar district .... Our Portuguese friend showed us around this neighborhood and we had some drinks in a cool rock-bar at the "upper" end of the Bairro Alto ...Half the experience is the walk up past all the dives and now some higher-end locales in the neighborhood ... quite a party at night ...

Really Good for drink.. I loved that wonderful place to go out and have some drinks and have fun.
It has excelent small clubs and beautiful people.

Cafe Buenos Aires. Dua do Duque. Great Argentinean restaurant, excellent food service and price. Need to book always full. Good wine list but be sure you are hungry. Nice for a evening meal but bijou.......

Up the hill. As you venture into Bairro Alto, you zigzag through little side-streets, watching the tiled building facades as you make your way up the hill. You will pass countless restaurants, bars, fruit-vendors -- you won't starve while exploring this neighbourhood. You'll also find the presidential palace if you go far enough!

Wild Walkers pub crawl. Last year I went on a trip to Lisbon. One night we joined the Wild Walkers pub crawl with Tiago Dinis and Ricardo Bernardo as our tourguides in the Bairro Alto district. They showed us several bars with live bands. Because we had so much fun that night, we rejoined the tour the next day and the day after that. We met a lot of nice people. And they all spoke english very well.
Go at night!!!. There's a lot of bars, most of them with live music,,, drinks are so cheap and great!!! people from Portugal is really kind

Have a Nice Night. Old neighorhood, homogeneous architecture, bars, cafes, boutiques, dancing places, live music, lots of people in the street, thematic restaurants, nearby city center and shop area, footwalk only at night.
Great night life. A good place to visit if you want some night life. There are lots of Fado venues, bars, restaurants and nightclubs.

A very nice neighborhood atop the Elevador da Gloria. Bairro Alto is a neighborhood atop the steep incline of the Elevador da Gloria. The neighborhood is accessible via the funicular from Praca das Restauradores. The neighborhood gems are the Iglesia and Museu de Sau Roque. The infamous O Trevo Cafe and Cafe A Brisileira are also near by. This neighborhood is a nice stroll.
the nightspot of Lisbon!. It is full of clubs and little spots where you can taste bacalhau and good portuguese beer until early in the morning.
Best Caparinha's in Town. A must for anyone on Holiday in Lisbon, in the summer it gets packer, and really gets going from about midnight. Btw the caparinha's are excellent.

Great for drinks, interesting music and meeting locals. We heard a great deal about the area but were not real impressed when we first arrived as it was very quiet. Then when we came out of our restaurant at 10 that night the pàrty was starting to pick up. Plan to get there after 10 if you want to experience a great selection of small bars, live local music and tasty food. We had the best time in this tiny neighborhood. It is full of friendly local party goers and we hope to come back before we leave Spain.

Great location to stay!. Bairro Alto is a great location to stay in Lisbon. It puts you within blocks of one of the best scenic overlooks, two of the funiculars, the tram that will take you to the castle and the Belem district... It is filled with small restaurants and bars (and they stay busy well into the night). If you don't like nightlife, avoid this place. I didn't go to any of the bars, but it is a part of town that I found to be safe late at night because there are always lots of people in the streets!Many of the attractions, shopping etc are within walking distance, and the ones that aren't are served well by public transportation right in the neighborhood. I will definately stay in Bairro Alto next time I go to Lisbon!

Exciting nightlife. There are lots of bars, some smart shops and cafes, shops and street performers. Very entertaining. And you can ride the elevator for the experience, but it's a bit touristy and a long wait.

Warning.... It's a great place if you like to party a lot (by a lot I mean being surrounded by drunk men and women who are throwing-up and falling down) but if you like a more relaxed place I would suggest not going up their during the night... I do have to say that their are great clubs and bars, but it was too wild for my taste
weekend delight. hundreds of small bars and restaurants crammed into numerous alleys.you cannot fail to find what you want. great entertainmnt

Take a stroll. Well worth a walk around...if you can pick up a guide and stroll on foot. All the tiled frontages of the houses are a photographers delight. Stop at a cafe and just watch the world go by...

For a night of having fun!. Little streets, small bars and a lot of people. This is a little bit of description of what you can expect of Bairro Alto. The atmosphere there is always energetic!! A really nice place to have a few drinks and have a good time. Be prepared: the whole place doesn't get "alive" until after 23:00!!

Lots of fun restaurants, shops and cobblestone narrow streets to browse.. Nice overlook of Lisbon from a park located in this area, as well as lots of fun restaurants with many different ethnic specialties and very nice shops.

Touristic area. In this area there are mostly bars, where you can hear fado or other music. It is not very clean and there are not many good restaurants in the "Old Town". The prices for food are far to high and also the prices in the touristical fado places are to expencive. Rather go to the "Alfama" area to find better and nicer fado-restaurants.

Lots of great bars and clubs. Went here in the pouring rain and ducked into the first bar that we saw that had music on. It turned out to be a great bar with lots of friendly locals. Many of the other bars on the street were great too.

Best Terrace in Portugal at Bairro Alto Hotel. Everything is great about this area, walking, restaurants, cafes, boutiques and a super boutique hotel., Loved the Terrace at the Bairro Alto Hotel. There is everything to like about this location and services.
Noisy and overrated. Tiny bars, expensive drinks, smoke galore and rowdy people. Try it if you like being out and about in narrow, smelly and crowded streets
Great nightlife. Great spot for a few drinks, bit to eat and live music, packed with tiny little bars n restaurants. Doesnt get going proper until after nine

Overestimated. OK, this part of the city has a special atmosphere, you can still taste here the depressive life of poor people of old Lisbon, but I think it's overestimated. For sure you have to make a walk aroud the small streets, but a lot of places around are made only for tourists. Reataurants are more expensive in comparison with other areas of Lisbon, but not of better quality.

From Chiado to this "bairro". Leaving the Chiado streets above, we arrive at is that this same site. If aprentemente old, found in him the most youth overnight. features narrow streets of any city that has been building and rebuilding over time

Ouch!. Great fun, Super range of places to eat (we pushed the boat out and eat at 100 Maneiras). The viewing plaza is excellent. The Fado bar we visited to was great. Beware, the cobbled streets are very uneven. I fell badly in a pot hole and have been told it will take 2/3 weeks for the bruising to heal. For that reason, take care, particularly after dark.

Great shopping street. Full of buzz and good shops. Mind you it is similar to most European cities for the same shops. Wonderful for first time visitors as you continue down the street and under the arch, you come to the sea ! What a lovely surprise if you are not aware of this !
Restaurant Ville. Place to find some excellent places to eat from simple to more expensive. Dont worry about the hasslers that try and get you in some of the places are worth it.

Good Views, many steps. We took a walking tour, Pancho Tours, and enjoyed a wonderful overview of Lisbon and the Alto area. Recommended if you can handle the stairs and 3 hour walk. Fun especially for the first days while getting oriented.

Excellent. Great neighborhood for dinner and drinks! It gets very busy on weekends. For me the best side of the Bairro Alto is the one closer to the Camões square on Barroca street! Everybody is there, funny, happy, polite, beautiful, gay and not gay people... Have fun!

Atmospheric and plenty of interesting restaurants. The area is undoubtedly scruffy but the restaurants and bars spilling out into the narrow streets are fascinating. Watch for the "charge by the bite" pre-starters than get wheeled out, but I had 3 meals in the area and they were all good food and very good value.
Great place to explore winding streets, tiny cafes. We walked through the area after viewing the city from the miradour. Enjoyed the tiny streets and shops.
go there have fun spend nothing. Want to have fun? Saturday night there, wait after 11 pm ;-) must go there once, eat and drink for peanuts
Tourists. Set up for gullible tourists with scores of restaurants, do not eat there as there are far better places to eat and enjoy in Lisbon
Great place to mingle!. Loved the energy here. You've got to come here to feel the city's vibe. Fantastic place to meet friends.

Old area of Lisbon, to experience real Portuguese food.. The Biarro Alto is the old area of lisbon. Lots of cobbled streets,a bit of a climb up along. Lots of Alley ways typical of the time. We went during the early evening and had a meal recommended by a local we met on the street. We felt we needed to experience the old area of Lisbon. We wanted to try typical Portuguese food. We enjoyed our trip. We left in day light but if coming at night I would be wary and book a taxi - Dining TipHad a lovely relaxed meal out door at Restaurante Sinal Rue Das Gaveas,89. In Biarro Alto. We declined the cheese and bread offered as we were not very hungry, there is always a charge for this. I tried the pork wrapped in bacon with potatoes and veg, so lovely. Great flavour. My friends had the brill and the salted cod both good. The salted cod can be an acquired taste which my friend wanted to try but did not love. Over all the meal was nice. Great Value at €8.50 for mains (late afternoon) prices may vary later in the evening for dinner). Wine and beer was good and well priced. We shared the chocolate cake and this was lovely. Recommend if on a budget. Nice friendly staff. Good prompt service.

GREAT AMBIANCE. This corner of Lisbon is pretty dead during the day, but at night it comes alive. There are lots of great restaurants up there, and although a little touristy, they are more authentic than the restaurants in the Rossio area, which is considered downtown Lisbon.

Great people watching. Here you can find many restuarants, cafes and shops of every kind. Try to eat early before 7pm because between 8-10pm everyone comes out and the crowds thicken. Great time just walking around and taking in all the sights and sounds of the city.

Great spot for restaurants. Loved the small streets and tables outside in the night air. Had a drink at Bairro Alto Hotel on the roof, wonderful, and then ate in the restaurant downstairs. Also great food.

Where the real night vibe is. In Bairro Alto you can start a perfect night out with friends,with your couple or even alone. You'll find every type of restaurants, from luxury to low cost places (Tascas). After diner, You can find every type of ambience, tribe or genre tendency or indie pub / music. In Elevador da Bica you have a more indie ambience. Bairro Alto have a curfew hour around 2AM, so, people start strolling down to Cais do Sodré to continue the night.

Great night out. Well worth a visit, especially on the weekend. It is a bit of a climb to get there but the atmosphere on the tightly packed streets and in the tiny bars makes it all worth while. Age isn't a factor either just go with the flow, get a Super Bock in a plastic glass and wander the streets enjoying the sights and sounds.

it is a must see in Lisbon, something you don't see elsewhere, especially if you take the tram to get there.. I like old quarters, even if many houses are really not refurbished at all and some have bricks instead of windows. But at night the atmosphere is fantastic, with many people enjoying a drink and music and talking loudly.

Cool. Worth visiting and hanging out and lazing around on a weekend to shop and eat and enjoy all this place has to offer. Please enjoy coffee at the esplanade since it is worth sitting around for a while if you want to enjoy all the things around here.

Best Party in Lisbon. Lisbon is a great city with a laid back vibe, a lot of class and charm. Its exuberance and vivacity is evident in Bairro Alto. One of the coolest spots with the best DJs is the inimitable A Capela at Rua da Atalaia, 45.

Ambiguous place. This place is very ambiguous for me and my wife. It is old and narrow and located on hills. We went there using the tram #28 and then were going by foot through its streets. The buildings are old and poor but there are very beautiful ones. And the nice thing is that every house has a ceramic plate with number. Trams go using the same track in both directions and only on some crossroads they have 2 lines to let each other go further. Interesting place to walk.The best is to walk without any guide.. just to see how it is.

Great neighborhood. This was a great neighborhood recommended to us by our guide. Accessible by funicular and cabs. Lively neighborhood with lots of fun bars, music, Fado clubs. Great area for young and young at heart.
Excellent Place for Going Out!. Huge Bar & restaurants options here, from cosy to typical, from fusion to traditional, just select wat you prefer! Fado, rock, pop...the Night IS Bairro Alto!

Go to the bars, skip the food. The clubs are a riot, lots of strange personalities and a lot of fun. Very chilled out. But BEWARE!! We sat down at a little eatery on some steps for a quick midnight feed and were shocked to be charged 75 euro... all the 'complimentary' items they gave us when we turned up added 8 euro to the bill.

Enjoyable evenings in the Bairro Alto. During the day you'd be forgiven for wondering what all the fuss is about. The Bairro Alto is a tangled maze of narrow, cobbled alleways with shuttered shops covered in graffiti and hardly a soul to be seen.As soon as the evening commences bars and restaurants throw open their doors (though some bars do not open until much later).We had four nights in Lisbon and the first of them we spent in Chiado, however the remaining three nights we ate and drank in the Biarro Alto. We are both in our mid-fifties and were a little concerned that we'd feel totally out of place. Yes, the Bairro Alto attracts a lot of younger people who stay out until the early hours, but it also welcomes "oldies" such as us. If you can find a table and chairs outside all the better, but most people stand, lean and prop themselves up against the walls. Everyone chats to each other and the whole area had a buzz about it.Probably bececause of our age we were never approached or offered drugs and did not see any evidence of this going on. The whole area felt completely safe and everyone was good-natured and friendly.We had three wonderful dinners - one in a traditional restaurant, and the other two in an Indian restaurant - all were reasonably priced.

Steamin' Night Life. Fabulous winding cobbled alleys of fun! Misic blaring in the cavernous caves - but not a soul inside! of course it is a little warm and - noone who is anyone would go out before midnight, but whebn you do there is gem after gem - with different music - congregations of scenesters of Lisboa - unite and pretend you are one onf them - even if just for the night.!!! Nowhere will ever be as good

A must see if you're in Lisbon. Have dinner at a Fado restaurant here on the weekend and then ask the taxi driver to drive thru the streets ... the weekends are a street party and one you won't forget!!

The place to be!. Bairro Alto is so lively and bustling at all times. It has got everything and everything is open late (including small grocery shops). The crowd here is amazing, and so are the locals that you see in the morning. Some curious little shops and studios, too. In my opinion, the best place to be staying in Lisbon.

Great part of town all day round.. Bairro Alto is a great place to wander around. During the day it feels like the authentic local place, with all the elderly lady carrying their shopping, having a chat at their windows across the street, or just going about their business. At night (and especially Saturday night) the place changes completely, various late opener bars & restaurants with hundreds of people on the narrow streets sipping cocktails and listening to all sorts of music. It can even get a bit overwhelming but is definitely a thrill!
Awesome area for bar hopping. If you are in Lisbon for partying. This is the area to go to. Huge drinks for only 6 Euros. Very crouded though, so watch out for pick pockets.
Less touristy, great restaurants. If you want to get away from the crush of humanity in Rossio, head up the hill and wander the streets in Bairro Alto. Lots of great restaurants the locals frequent.

interesting night out. Bairro alto is an old hilly area in town, filled with very nice and popular street restaurants, clubs and bars. A very good idea for a night out, full of tourists but locals too, many locations with good live music (fado and not only)

Buzzing atmosphere - a must see. If you happen to be in Lisbon on a Saturday night, head to Barrio Alto and go bar hopping. Its a fantastic place, lively and fun with lots of interesting themed bars. Too words of advice: wear flat shoes and don't bother heading out til late- the place is dead til 1am!

Try and avoid the tourist traps. Bairro Alto is precisely that - a high neighborhood!! Not for those with mobility problems. Best in the evening and at night. Get your taxi to drop you off somewhere near to Travessia da Queimada and walk around these old streets, redolent of old Lisbon. Plenty of restaurants, take your pick inside or out on the street. Sardines and cod obvious specialities. Unfortunatly also a lot of tatty drinking dens (avoid). Apart from eating and drinking , the big attraction here is the fado. There are a number of largish establishments offering twice nightly fado shows, but these are often jammed with tourists off coach tours and are perhaps best avoided. Try one of the smaller, more modest places for a different experience. The "Caldo Verde" is one that springs to mind. Just ask around and someone will point the way. A meal with drinks there costs about 30 euros. The show is free but the fadistas sort of expect you to buy their CDs, which they will gladly sign (15 euros). And please remember, as a mark of respect, to avoid loud conversations while they are singing these wonderful songs.
Fascinating old part of Lisbon. Great area to just wander around with a layout largely untouched by redevelopment. Feels untouristy with lots of little neighbourhood bars.

Restaurant quarter. A nice enough place for an evening meal in Lisbon however most restaurants seem tourist trappy and tacky. Some unsavouries float about in this area also. Stick to Rossio for an evening meal and main tourist area along the promenade.

Lisboms beat. This kind of freeminded atmosphere of cheer is unique in europe!
Stores offer intresting desing and the portugese buffet offers many delicaties. Art and culture can be felt in the air.

Awesome place to drink beers among the locals!. Make sure you get in contact with some of the locals there to know the places to go to when the bars close.
Cheap beer, lot's of locals and not many touristy stuff

Interesting Area. In the Bairro Alto you can find the Sao Roque Church. For me this was the most beautiful church in town. Its Chapel of St. John the Baptist really impressed me. This area is a place to explore.

Cool very packed with local night life. Don't go to Fado, its a ripoff, even though its beautiful to hear. SAd, but nice.
They overcharge on everything

Busy, Noisy, Vibrant!. The Barrio Alto quarter of Lisbon during the day is quiet, but at night transforms into a busy and vibrant place packed full of restaurants, bars and quirky little shops that stay open until late.

It's a RAVE on Friday and Saturday nights!. We were enjoying FADO music inside a well known bad and I heard a loud crowd outside- when we left FADO into the tiny ancient alleyways of Bairro Alto we were completely surrounded by a huge RAVE that went street after street, never experienced anything quite like it. I wished I were college age again. The taxi could barely get through the huge surrounding crowd and it was so much fun, they were blowing kisses at us and smiling at us inside the taxi. Even the taxi drivers are accustomed to this RAVE on the weekends and laugh about it. Luck young people in LISBOA to party and live it up like this on weekends.
great night out. Brilliant live music. You have to walk a fair bit...but after check out as many bars as possible and then just stay at the one without any tourists.

Panoramic views and an amazing church. There was not a great deal of special interest to see after leaving the funicular, but the steep, winding streets and alleyways provided one gem: the amazingly ornate church of Sao Rocq. There were also some splendid views.

Touristy. I know it is supposed to be touristy, but with all the people outside trying to hustle you into their restaurants it is hard to know what is a good place or not. Found a nice Wine bar, but other than that I think there are better places to catch a meal or drink in the city.

Overcrowded lively place. We went during both the day time and evening. During the day it was very quiet in part especially around the area where 100 Maneiras Restaurant was based. Taxi drivers didn't know where this was, we popped into the nearby Museum and the portugese gentleman used googlemaps to tell us where the street was! We did find it but not eat here (no veggie options) We walked back to Avenida da Liberdade using the hill where the furnicular is based. The Gloria funicular connects Lisbon's downtown with the Bairro Alto. This place has lots of bars and restaurants and was very busy in the evening. We eat here one evening at the Sukhothai Restaurant on Rua da Atailia and the streets around the restaurant were heaving with people sitting/standing outside smoking and drinking. The streets are very narrow and claustraphobic and there was little breeze here.

Good for a fun night out. This barrio is fun if you go in the evenings. Loads of music, nice restaurants and happy people. During the day it's a bit quiet, most restaurants are closed but as soon as the evening starts, it's a lot of fun.

The heart of Lisbon. The most chameleonic quarter of Lisbon. During the day is very quiet and calm as every traditional and old quarters, with a touch of vanguard and trendy flavour given by some of the shops (Fatima Lopes, Filipe Faisca, Lost In, Cork & Co, Bairro Arte). At night it's the most incredible place to be: lots of restaurants (some very good and others targeted to tourists) and plenty of bars with thousands of people drinking and getting around. An amazing melting pot. An experience to remember.

BAIRRO ALTO. I have visited Baiiro Alto and the experience was really unique. There are several beautiful bars at a very traditional area and many people sit not only inside but also outside bars, or standing with their drink. All these among beautiful houses and some small beautiful plazas. The bars also have a different style so u can choose according to your music preferences. People usually openminded and easy going, no need for ''official code dress''..

Street party. This place is dead during the day and comes alive after 10pm when the shutters are drawn up and hundreds of bars open up along the many alley ways. People are chilled out and the drinks are super cheap. Make sure you have a few shots of ginghina!

Must visit this quaint old world style town in Portugal. When in bajo alto you must visit a tapas and fado bar! Just when you think Portugal can't get anymore interesting...there's bajo alto. Here you can find friendly people, cheap and tasty eats & cheap drinks!! It's is laid back and much fun. When visiting you must experience Fado performance but beware you must stay silent during the performance or they will not appreciate your presence. Take the tram 28 & the trolley ride which is definitely worth the nostalgic experience.

Very nice party place for younger people. I really enjoyed my trip to Bairro Alto. The atmosphere is very good, the drinks are very cheap and the place is just lovely. Basicly, Bairro Alto are (/is) a couple of streets, with a lot of bars. Most people buy their cheep drinks (i.e 3-4€ for a Mojito, 1€ for a shot, 1,2€ for a beer) inside the bars, but drink them outside. Both streets and bars get very crowdy in the weekends, but it's better to go on friday or saturday. Other days can be so quiet that its actually boring. You can't say you really saw the charm of Bairro Alto if you went on an other day. It's like attending a church on wednesday evening instood of sunday morning. If you come from down town by foot you have to climb up A LOT of stairs. Not recommended if you aren't in good/normal shape. A must see for all young people. I think that older people would annoy themself on the extremely loud music, crowdy drunk people and a lot of smoke. But isn't every bar? :)

lights & shadows. Many people, too many people and many pub/bar, too many bar/pub... this is the way people cannot control their thirst and get completely drunk and start vomiting in every corner. It would be a great place if just people would have some fun and not destroy themselves
Party-hearty!. It was so full of life! Cheap food and drinks and awesome atmosphere. Where the party people of Lisbon hangout

favorite place to dine. Really loved the view from the steps up to the Bairro Alto located just behind the train station. Many resturants located here. The food was adequate but the view for me made it all perfect. I loved watching the sun set and the city lights come up. Especially the lights of the castle in the distance.

Alive & Kicking. Great in the day time for browsing charming independent shops.By night its an impromptu street party with everyone crowding the small streets to enjoy cheap beers and caparinhas. Love this place.
Great Fun. Great social scene and nobody falling around drunk! If you like to socialise then you will love it we went on a Friday and Saturday night and people say its always busy on the weekends

You could be in Havana!. Streets full of revelers at night, relaxed drinking atmosphere, old buildings with residents' washing hanging out, music from umpteen houses. This is your night time destination.
Great music,drinks and atmosphere. Great spot to nighthop; bars abound. We went to one called Porta Larga, I think - it had really good live music
beating heart of Lisbon. if you want to understand the Portugese people: go to Bairro Alto! Walk in the amazing streets, discover talentuous artists, enjoy the fish... you won't be disappointed!
party central. bars serve cheap cocktails in plastic glasses so everyone drinks on the street, wandering in and out of bars. a good laugh.

It was ok. Fun during the night, not worth it during the day. The landlady of the place we stayed in warned us of pickpockets especially during the night, but isn't it just a rule of thumb to be aware of them wherever you go.

Wrong time of day for our visit. We went during the day as we wanted to see the architecture. It was very dirty and smelly from the night before and we now know that it's for the nightlife that you go there. Very happening place after dark but not really worth a visit during the day.

GREAT FOOD GREAT WINE GREAT ENTERTAINMENT. This area is one of the more lively areas in Lisbon , Its streets are lined aith retuarants and wine bars and pubs. Good place to go and hang out in. For all the "oldies" this place might be a bit to lively after midnight """ if you know what i mean""".
Place to go at night. Lots of bars and restaurants. Pub Crawls and lively drinkers! If you are bothered by that sort of thing then best to avoid this area after 10 pm.

Fun Fun Fun. This is the go to area for late night festivities in Lisbon. This area has it all from nice wine bars and trendy eateries at the base of the incline to the more rustic and earthy establishments the further up you go. You can gain quite a few insights into Lisbon by entering into some interesting conversations with the locals here, even if you are not speaking the same language! As others have said, don't arrive here too early, from 8pm onwards it really starts to come alive.

World Class Night Out. Jump in a taxi (which are very cheap) and ask for Bairro Alto, the best part of town for a night out. Theres loads and loads of bars along narrow streets and everybody stands in these streets drinking and chatting. Stupid amounts of beautiful girls from all over the world. Closes around 4am during the week, then everybody heads down to Cais de Sodre where the big clubs are, the bars stay open til around 6am down there.

We dont get up there often but lots to see. Shops, with unique flair, long nightclub type nights, fashionable and hole in the wall eateries. Every little turn will reveal the character of this ancient area in the heart of old Lisbon.
Lively streets teeming with people and eateries. Forget the high heels and just give various bars a try. Great atmosphere and loads of places to eat in the lanes. Don't go out too early!

For youngs. This region of Lisbon is full of youngs during the nights. they are all on the streets drinking and having fun. They really have fun.I like the idea of being outside with your friends. I went to Lisbon with my mother. so we were not able to spent so much time at this street because she was always tired but I definitely recommend to go there if you are with your friends.

It comes alive at night. We made the mistake of going by day first of all, and there was nothing to see. However this year it was about 9.30 when we got there and the whole area was alive with probably hundreds of people eating on the narrow streets. A great atmosphere and a great choice of restaurants. You must eat here when staying in Lisbon.
Just amazing. we did a pub crawl in this area. it was amazing how many people were on the streets, dancing, laughing, having fun and all that. you definitly need to go there and party.
Bars and restaurants galore!. The place to be at night, the only problem will be deciding where to eat and drink as the choice is just too good and too much!
Nightlife. If you want nightlife go to bairro alto, it is amazing to see a lot of People listening to the music and drinking!
Good place at night. Great restaurants and bars to be found here...well worth a visit in the evening, and some nice shops to look in during the day

The best night life neighbouhood. In warm summer nights, the bairro Alto is probaly the most crowded place in the world (at around midnight). You can find all types of music bars (from techno to fado), you can even drink outside, you can have dinner, you can go shopping. Just wonder around!
Night Life. Feel of Bourbon Street in New Orleans, set in a historic area with lots of charm, energy of the masses celebrating well into the morning.
Good for restaurants and bars. A trendy area for bars and restaurants along with interesting shops. Take the Elevador da Gloria it stops at a great viewing area overlooking the city.
Variety. Good place to stroll, shop, and take in the old Lisbon. Some books refer to take the elevator up but street access is just as easy and free.
Ideal for a night out in Lisbon!. People lay around the streets of Barrio Alto, drinking alcohol and having fun. It's a great place to be, I wish I'd go at least once a week :)
Mad at night!. Stacks of bars and restaurants, there's sure to be something you'll enjoy there if bohemian is your thing. Reminiscent of Raval/El Born in Barcelona.

A definite must visit. A definite must visit to this place at night. It is the place where a lot of young people hang out drinking beer and meeting up new people. Not a rowdy crowd and completely safe, this place is one of the highlights of our Lisbon trip
What a place!. A definite place to visit during the day and by night. You cannot say you have been to Lisbon without seeing Bairro Alto.
For the younger visitor. This area is next to Chiado and the same comments apply. Lots of Hen parties etc., but, at least not of the British variety.
Great place to eat. Lovely restaurants. Nice view of the Lisboa bridge and the Jesus statue.
300 pubs. Amazing atmosphere on Saturday night. The party starts late, after 1 a.m., but lasts until the morning.
cool area. definitely worth checking out this area. full of youth and excitement.

A bit seedy late in the evening. Saw a nice show at Luso with Fado singers and lots of dancing. Decided to wander around the many bars, some were very dingy although music not too bad. As it got past 11pm the whole place seemed to become a bit seedy with beggars and drunks. Did not feel threatened at any time just a bit uncomfortable.

nice place to go at night. walk around these small streets which become alive after sunset. Small bars and restaurants, fadoplaces and more. The area seems safe to me but you will be approached constantly by drugs sellers. More crowded during weekends.

The Greenwich Village of Lisbon. Narrow, hilly little streets with many restauants, bars, and boutiques that remain open until late because daytime is so quiet.
There is something's different around every little corner. There is a great restaurant not to miss-- 100 Maneiras is the name.
I went for a drink. It's nice because it's an old side of Lisbon city, although it's a bit dirty
Cool area, mostly for young people.. crowed area especially at nights,you can find very cheap drinks at every bar of the area.

Mostly authentic old Lisbon. lovely old buildings and alleyways. some restaurants are tourist ripoffs but others are very good indeed - do your research if wanting to eat. Just walking around and soaking up the atmosphere is lovely, highly recommended
Amazing by night. Great night out, just wander from one bar to another, literally door to door throughout the streets. Livee bands in some bars and great chill out music.

Best Area in Lisbon. It's got all the feel of old Europe, with the vibe of new shopping and restaurants. Every corner seems to have something interesting to draw your attention, restaurants have outdoor seating with vibrant umbrellas and funky musicians cut their teeth by playing in the open squares here.
Hidden Gem. Fantastic area with some very cool and chic bars. Also some great little boutiques.An excellent area to chill after a day of sightseeing and shopping.
Great for foodies. Many nice small restaurants in this maze of streets that at night becomes a festive area of interest to locals and tourists.

Nice area but hard work. a very steep climb as whole area on a hill but its worth it as its loverly roundhere
recommend you go to Fado music club called Laso, food average but music WORLD CLASS! there is a very nice indian restaurant literally right opposite the club there so eat before you go in for the music!
Best part of Lisbon. Not so crowded, more authentic. People actual live and breathe here. I really enjoyed it.

Wow. This is party central for Lisbon with bars open late and early in to the morning. Drink is very cheap here and the mojitos are excellent, try Heidi's for a great selection of DJ's and music. You can walk, taxi or take the funicular up to the Barrio Alto, you will more than likely roll back down!!

party!. If you wanna party, go there! A lot of pubs and clubs. Check with your hostel the pub crawl with the wild walkers. 15 euros and you go to 2 pubs and a club in one night. The first pub you drink beer or vodka (or both) as much as you can included in the price.

Don't miss the Port Institute. We followed the Rick Steves walking guide so that we would hit all of the "tourist" sites. We ate lunch in a restaurant that was an old converted monastery. I cannot remember the name, but it was great.
Highight of the walk was the Port Institute where we sampled a few 30 & 40 yr old vintages in air-conditioned comfort.
so many restaurants. go here for great food and quirky bars just dont get lost in the maze of streets

Walk this lovely district. The old centre of Lisbon is a gorgeous enjoyable walk and I would encourage everyone to spend a couple of days walking in all the areas. Just walk the streets and allys. Stop at the small shops off the beaten track and take you time exploring this fabulous city.
A bit like Montmartre. Nice views quaint little squares, take the funicular back dwon to praca reatauradores

Cool, happening and confusing in a great way. Labyrinthine and confusing this part of old Lisbon is perched on the hills. Get lost for hours discovering little dives offering great food and wine - or just wander and take in the stunning old buildings...the tactile seduction of the tile-covered houses - you simply must explore and let yourself get lost.

Put your climbing shoes on!. We visited the Bairro Alto during the day and with its very hilly terrain, a comfortable pair of shoes is an absolute must. We were told that this place really comes to life at night, but we had a very good lunch there instead.
very vibrant in evenings. stayed in this area and loved it. Lots of eateries to chose from and feeling of old Lisbon.

Nightlife area. We walked this area at night last Friday. It seemed to be a wild party area with a lot of heavily drinking youths. Drugs where used quite indiscreetly, and the entire scene seemed very noisy. I guess if you are having a stagg party, or just want to binge out, this is the area for you. Not for me though.
very picturesque. not good for people with walking difficulties but go on a tram tour
have some drinks and dance. the night is amazing in bairro alto,lots of clubs and drinks
Interesting Area. Take the various elevadors (some are actually funiculars). See the old convent at top of Elevador de Santa Justa. There is a nice place for a drink or lunch with great views.

bairo alto dirty& dangerous. so all teh reviews were good ,saying tis the temple bar of lisbon ,its youthful and lively and latin.However this was not our experience.A group of four of us arriving at the bairo at about 11pm we were immediately offered cocaine or hash or sunglasses .this persisted throughout the night.Certain arrears of the bairo were seedy and dirty and we saw a syringe sticking up from the cobbled streets, stay away if you want a trouble free holiday

One of the best places in the World to party!. The vibe is brilliant and electrifying. There are tonnes of Pubs you can visit. Its similiar to Lan Kwai Fung in Hong Kong. I had the best Mojito I ever had in one of the Pubs. Advice - Take the TRAM dont try to walk up

Good by night. My friends and i rented an apartment at Bairo Alto for 2 nights and it was great. Most of theme are old but well restored and offer all you need for a short stay. Small picturesque streets, full of shops, restaurants and bars. Quiet and pleasant during the day and lively during the evening. It gets really noisy as everybody is outside, drinking and laughing very loud. So it's a good place to go out but definitely not to stay overnight as you won't be able to sleep, especially if you are a light sleeper like me...
Don't go for Sunday Lunch. Lots of great restaurants..... the majority of which do not open for Sunday lunch (as we discovered to our chagrin!).
Busy, noisy but very nice. Relaxed during the day, but very loud, noisy and great during the evening. A lot of restaurants and bars and everybody drinks and has fun outside
Uitgaansbuurt. THE place to be for nightlife, but also traditional stores, alternative brand stores and gastronomy
