Best place to go at night. Always crowded , all kind of people , good restaurants and places to dance.
Night life center of lisbon. Visit this district for the night life untertainment and bars. Happy hours are until midnight and.

perfect nightlife. great experience to go out. unique in europe with hundreds of people standing in the small streets through bairro at night with an uncountable number of bars and restaurants. Various places with live music as well and different bars for every taste and across the price span! Perfect place to start a long night or just to have a few drinks and enjoy the atmosphere outside!During the days it's a completely different sight with small shops and boutiques in the narrow streets displaying part of Lisbon's alternative scene.

Great place to explore. We loved this area, filled with little shops, narrow streets and local colour. My husband bought 2 hats from a great family owned and run hat shop - they took endless trouble to help please, and spoke many languages too. Interesting antique shops and clothing boutiques too.

Entertaining but disappointingly shabby. The Bairro Alto has a wealth of bars and restaurants and many of them are pretty decent, the place as a whole has a rather shabby feel however which detracted a little from its charm. The caipirinhas served in many of the bars are tasty, moreish and generally reasonably priced however and we did have a very entertaining few nights there, you just get the feeling that with a little effort it could be so much more..
Nice area. Cool streets, a lot of fado restaurants, small shops, andon top of it park with absolutely breathtaking views
Restaurants and night life. Partucularly on the weekends, a big crowd, goes to Bairro. Go and see!

Great neighborhood for a stroll. Bairro Alto is picturesque and lots of fun. Just stroll around the neighborhood, poke your head into a few bars, grab a cup of bica for refreshment and enjoy. There also is a wonderful little park to the right at the top of the funicular with great views of Lisbon. We visited at night.

winding streets and fabulous views. Old and full of character, the winding streets and lanes of this typical Lisbon area are a joy to wander. They are peppered with wonderful small shops and workshops, jewellers, clothes designers, food shops, cafes and bars. We found a wonderful hat maker with the best selection of fabulous hand-made hats in Rua des Rosas ?- I think! At night things can get very packed and party, but we really enjoyed wandering around this charming quirky area during the day. The local independent businesses are enterprising & thriving, and it is such a joy to discover all those brilliant unusual designs which you won't find anywhere else.... not to be missed. The you can catch the Alfama bound 28 tram on Calcada do Combro , getting on before the crowds of tourists join at Chiado or Baixa... you might even get a seat! Or wander through to Santa Catarina and have an evening Vinho Verde at the Miroudoro -(Viewpoint) at the Golden Hour as the sun sets over the Tejo... Bliss!
The pulse of Lisbon. Bar? restaurante? people? tradition? everything is here.
Nightlife!. This seems to be the place to go for bars and restaurants - the place comes alive at night!

Packed. We only stayed a little while because there were 10 of us and hardly any room for us in the popular bars. But the time we were there was great fun, and is great for a bar crawl with locals and tourists

Rocking!!!. Try the Caipinrhas!!! This area is bouncing late night into early morning. The bars are dotted along the streets and have something for everyone. Music in lots of bars. Don't expect a seat though - most people drink out of their plastic cups and go from place to place. Beware of pickpockets. Visit during the day as well to see the funky shops and amazing architecture. Be prepared for a late one ;-D
Good for bar hopping. This is the area to head to watch the sunset before hitting the bars. A good mix of chic bars.
A very good place to have a few drinks. A really nice place to have a few drinks with your friends. Lots of different bars and restaurants. A bit crowded on Friday and Saturday nights.

Thriving. Great during the day for sightseeing & thriving in the evening for restaurants, bars & nightclubs if required.Cannot be accessed on foot without a climb, but all travel services get you there.
tapas. good for tapas-type food. Buy a day ticket for metro,bus and tram before getting on the funicular, though!

noisy, but fun. Lots of bars here, and people in Lisbon drink in the street and extend the party to the street. Don't book a room in this area unless you're a heavy sleeper. There are other places in Barrio Alto away from the 3 or 4 main bar streets.
Hoppin'!. Head out to Bairro Alto at about 8 pm and stay into the a.m. Fun for all ages....pub crawl, dine in a local spot, people watch on the cobblestone streets...there is something fo everyone.

Nice neighborhood, great bars and night life!. We stayed at a Hostel (Rossio Patio) nearby and loved the neighborhood, its nightlife and great little bars, theaters and shops.
It's a cool neighborhood to explore! Try it out...

Interesting anytime; amazing at night.. This neighborhood which is easily reached by heading uphill from the Biaxa-Chaido Metro stop really hops at night (any night). A must visit for dinner, drinks or music.
Kind of Scary. We were targeted for pick pocketing several times n a lot of the streets. Great caves etc, just make sure to use extreme caution.

Best restaurants and bars in Lisbon. If you visit Lisbon and don't spend two nights here you don't know what Lisboa is.
Try Papa acorda restaurant to eat and Lisbon Serviced Apartments to stay
The Nicest part of Lisbon. One of the nicest place in Lisbon. It offers great restuarants and blasting night life. Make sure to tjump on the little yellow tram to take you up there

Cheers!!. Perfect area to enjoy some drinks :) There is a wide range of pubs to choose.But watch the time :( Unforntunately they close kind of early (around 3a.m.)- Since I am Spanish and I am not used to bars closing so early, that was a bit annoying for me and my friends. So, make sure you get there with time enough with time to paint the city red! :)
the place to be at night. We had dinner here with life Fado music, there are plenty of restaurants and bars in all price ranges
Great neighberhood. Small streets, little shops, nice restaurants, tram 28, close to Baixa and Chiado!

Fun area but found it more for young adults. An area in Portugal with tons of bars and restaurants. We did eat in the area and found it interesting and the food good. Lots of good fish restaurants. The area reminded me of the east village of NY. Not in the look but the number of young adults looking for a night of drinking. We were approached to buy drugs so be aware of your surroundings this may occur. But we did not feel uncomfortable in the area, and were not bugged once we said, no thanks.
Cafe a Brasileira. You should go to "Bairro alto" and stop for a coffee at this coffee shop. It´s a authentic 20's experience. It´s good to see portuguese life style.

Barrio alto - Fado night. Unique experience, Fado night at a restaurant where suddendly waiter, owners and Fado singers starting all singing :).
Nothing to dislike!!
Delicious food
Fado and much more. Great for young revellers I reckon, but some some super places to eat at reasonable prices.

Lovely place to visit at night!. We stumbled into Bariro Alto after being a bit disappointed with our experience in alfama. We heard loud music and sat in on what looked like a brazilian cultural dance which was pretty cool. It reminded us of the Art Deco version of south beach with cool small bars and theatres (unique artsy vibe). This area was much less touristy than Alfama. As a fellow post I read stated so well-you know you are in a good Portuguese restaurant when the menu is not in english. Restaurant was an authentic italian one called Casanostra. we were recommended to try an antipasto octopus dish which was a 9/10! I had the duck with a type of cheese that made the flavour of the dish come to life and dance in my palette. My wife had a fish dish w shrimp that was equally as good. We finished the night with a trip to the haagen dasz (located right outside the Biaxa metro station) and wolfed down 5 scoops of ice cream between us. Omg soo good!

A great place to view the city for free. You can take either funicular tram or the lift to get here but we just walked up the hill, there are some nice shops and restaurants, as well at a couple of viewing points and a nice small park area. You enter the botanical gardens from this part of town.

all about the atmosphere. Great feeling, this area is full of viewpoints, cafes, restaurants, bars. Nice in the evening specially, many people go late for drinks. Do not trust the prices stated outside or on the board! Plus, everything extra they bring you will appear on the bill. Best part of Lisbon for me!
Lively Atmosphere. Great selection of bars and Restaurants. Mahjong Bar was our favourite!

Fado, fado, fado. There are many restaurants, night clubs and fado houses in the lively Barrio Alto, and I was privileged to have heard Lenita Gentil and three other fadistas sing fado at O Faia, on the Rua da Barroca. I don't know fado well enough to know whether the place is touristy or not--it didn't seem so, and I didn't hear English being spoken by anyone else but my dinner companion--but I know that the food and the fadistas at O Faia made the evening the most memorable one of my visit to Lisbon.
Grab a beer..... And enjoy the live music. Be aware: 80% tourists.Didn't see much locals.
for a walk and a glass of vino verde. it is for me one of the nicest area in Lisbon. many small shops and bars and restaurants... this part of the city doesn't sleep much.

Fusion of styles. This is the main spot to go out at night in Lisbon. Here you find a fusion between old and new, rich and poor, black and white, straight and gay, etc. It's a manhattan-style area but of very small streets that are filled with small bars right next to small shops and restaurants. The whole are is very dynamic since throughout the day shops and general commerce is open with neighbours speaking to each other and then as the night turns up, restaurants start to get their crowd and then bars open until 3am.Things are also dynamic since bars tend to close and then reopen somewhere else. Also, the crowds change location every now and then as one spot becomes more "in" than another. It is a walk-only location. Do not attempt to drive here since it is closed to cars apart from taxis and local traffic.Accessible from any direction, it's main entry point is Largo de Camões, reachable by tram, bus, underground and taxi. Also, the Cais do Sodré train station is about 400m from Bairro Alto.
Interesting but worn down. Many places was worn down and dirty while other had a cosy atmosphere

bairro alto. great bars restuarants shops cheap drinks cool place, most bars you don't drink in the actual bar, you get your drink and then hang out outside, lots guys trying to sell cheap glasses/hats/flowers they are harmless, fun scene

Fantastic area, but loud at night!. We stayed in an apartment rental right smack in the middle of the Bairro Alto in March 2012. It was a fantastic location in terms of proximity to Tram 28, the subway and the general downtown area (all within a very short walking distance). However, anyone staying in this area should be aware of how incredibly loud it gets on Thursday, Friday and Saturday nights. There are a lot of great little restaurants and bars in this area, and on weekend nights things really get going around 11pm-ish. My first night there was a Friday, and I woke at 2:30am to a full street party below the apartment window! If you're a sound-sleeper, it probably won't affect you. And if you're looking for an area to party, you'll love it. Otherwise, you may want to choose a quieter area of town.

The night spot. Definelty the hot spot for all nightlifers that are more abbout 'pubbing' than 'clubbing', specially on weekend nights, when you can barely walk in this old town narrow streets. Lisbon's movida at his highest.

Traditional Lisbon. A bit of old Lisbon with great bars and restaurants - but prepared to be shocked by the graffiti ! Make sure you take the old tram car up and take advantage of the view in the nearby park.
Also a must see place in Lison. Just to tell you that you must to visit Bairoo Alto. I will not telly you anymore and I let you to discover it
Nightlife is here!. The best nightlife place in Lisbon, with a lot of bars, good music and a safe place.

No money, no taste, go here. If you have no much money, not too much expectations and if you like shots and caipirinhas, this is your place. The good bars, clubs and restaurants are found elsewhere but not in Bairro Alto.
old town. if you have time to wander, it is pretty. but be sure to bring a good map or you will get lost.

THE Bar District of Lisbon - For 18+. This is the place to go to drink and party in Lisbon. There are people out every night so if you need a drink or 12 this is the place. The system is go into any bar and get a drink. they will give you a plastic cupand you then walk around the cobble stone streets from bar to bar chatting with your friends and meeting new people. the weather is great in lisbon so you are outside all night long. It starts late though, may be empty at 11pm, but packed by 1am where you cannot even walk through the streets. watch out for the 5 euro liter size caipirinhas... your hangover will be epic

Bairro Alto. Up above Lisbon, there is a section notable for its restaurants and the presence of some Fado venues. Some of the Fado shows are expensive and a bit unauthentic, but there are some good restaurants up here.
Excellent night life. Spent a saturday night in Barrio Alto moving from bar to bar ended the night in a excellent little Jazz bar but there was every type of bar there so something for everyone
lovely. Nice to wonder round in the evening as well as during the day.

All cities must have one Bairro Alto. Yes, all cities must have one Bairro Alto. Great night atmosfhere with lots of people, lots of bars, lots of restaurants, Fado, music, smiles and joy everywhere. Don't forget to visit at daylight, you'll be surprise by the alternative stores, and by local people who live in a small city inside Lisbon
charming neighbourhood. old neighbourhood reight in the heart of Lisbon, old buildings, nice srteets, lots of shops, and by night the best meeting place for drinks and laughs!
Best place for your Lisbon night. Like: Quite, safe and nice neiborhood. You can enjoy with drink, music and dance.Dislike: Get a map with you...
Best place to have a drink. This is the best place to go out at night in Lisbon! Full of bars and fun people, this is the place to be, if you want to have fun!
Lively!. Does not get going til 12 so for us British its a bit odd, but the bars were very varied and drinks potent!
Great bar hoping. wonderful bar area, lots of small bars, just go from one to another, most are fairly lively and drinks were cheap
Meh. Supposedly a fashionable neighborhood, but I wasn't that impressed and everything was more expensive without tasting better because I climbed some stairs. Nice views from the park.

Tradition. Place with lot of restaurants, bars and Fado (Portuguese traditional songs) houses.
Nice place for a walk, have dinner and after, drink something in a bar.
walk around. While lots of graffiti the whole place was virtually litter free. It is well worth doing a bit of exploring in this area but make sure you have your walking shoes on

Interesting streets and monuments. Walk from the front to the main square but zigzag as much as possible. The two statues - the 'ineffective king Dom Jose 1' from the time of the earthquake (was it his fault?) overlooks a beautiful arcaded square in the Praca do Comercio near the river front and the one in Rossio maybe with the head of Napoleon's brother, Maximilian that might or might not have been used dominate contrasting squares. One is buzzing and busy, the other relaxed and refined. Between and beyond are numerous alleys and streets, shops and buildings to explore.
Interesting. Spend a night there (maybe more than one night), look for a small nice restaurant, enjoi the night there
Take a Walk. Using the funicular, walk all the lanes, watch the traffic, check out the homes and just take in the ambience of Lisbon.

The Lisbon night-life. During the day this place will be packed with the usual tourists, during the night the side streets that are empty at day will fill with all those after whatever night-life you may wish, music, drinks, sex, drugs... all very openly and calmly...
BAIRRO ALTO. A well known Lisbon old quarter that resisted the 1755 earthquake. Nice restaurants, bars and shops. Full of night life all year around
Amazing views of the city. And lots of authentic places, terraces, tascas, etc
Great bars - lively at night. Visted several bars, great cocktails. Got a ripped off at Grapes and Nibbles as took the owner recommendation
so much fun. most bars per square mile in the world. great cool local places

Nice place. Bairro alto is away from the crowd , so it is less expensive but still as good that is eating drinking or just a cup of coffee just take the escalators in the train station up and walk down ,nice wiev aswell

Incredible Night Life!. What an amazing area of Lisbon. With what felt like 100 bars, we were engulfed with foreigners and locals alike sharing drinks and stories. There was one bar that had live Brazil music, that we were later told was quite famous, called Portas, which we have to recommend, the drinks were huge and the party went late into the night, a deffinate return from us.

Amazing views and lovely area. fantastic views from the top of the town. an amazing walk up, it was not to bad. Go to the Convent and work your way up and it's not such a steep hill.. well worth a visit and a walk..
Great views across to the Alfama and over the Baixa. Fascinating narrow streets on steep slopes - use the elevadors to get up to the Bairro Alto and walk downhill!
Bairro. If you´re loking for night fun, beautiful people and some beers this is the place to go!
nightlife. Lots of bars and restaurants,the best of nightlife in Lisbon!!!!
Great drinking and eating. Great drinking and eating, bars a plenty, lovely view from up at teh top of the funicular.
Interesting area with cafes, restaurants, bars. Incredible how you have to get up here from the downtown. Well worth seeing though!

Great place to get lost and explore. Getting lost in the small narrow streets then walking to the view of the castle to rest can be done in an afternoon or even better in the evening. Great shops to go in and out. Bringwalking shoes not heels

The Lisbon night starts here. Old neighborhood with narrow streets filled with restaurants, bars and fancy stores catering for the open minded.
Start your night out by eating dinner and then go bar hopping until 2am, before moving to the other late night Lisbon areas.

this part of Lisbon is worth to visit. This part of Lisbon is worth to visit, you can feel the atmosphere and I suppose that ot could be considered as one of the most interesting spots in the downtown of this nice city.

Party!. Collection of bars, cafeterias, and parties... you can seriously get lost, there are dozens of streets, with too many places to choose... just don't expect to prove the true - as every bar claims to serve - brazilian caipirinha, they just can't get it (I'm a brazilian, tasted 3 caipirinhas there, that's a bad joke!).
great place to eat and shop. very safe place at day or night nice warm people. bars and cafes ...wonderful city
Nice. It was quite nice the concept of the people in the street, but it was usually too crowded for my taste.
Full of atmosphere. Really nice place to wander around and have dinner with lots of clubs and bars.. Just quite atmospheric with clubs and bars and restaurants.

Seedy. The liveliest area we visited but we struggled to find bars without being grabbed by pushy staff trying to drag us into their establishment. It was very very seedy. We were openly offered drugs every 50 feet. Garbage on streets. Broken glass and filth abounds. Homeless beggars outnumbered tourists when we visited on valentines day....

Great place for a night out. Firstly I wouldn't recommend staying in this area, unless you are a very heavy sleeper. If you want a night out though it is great. A diverse crowd, many different bars, relaxed yet bustling and cheap drinks. Great area of Lisbon.
Fun area. Fun area for all times of the day. Sites, shopping, eateries, bars, and people watching!
Scenic views. Worth exploring the area which gives good panoramic views of the city

Can be a little edgy but worth a visit. Barrio Alto is one of those areas that seems a little edgy / dodgy but the people of Lisbon are usually great and it's worth going here as this is where the best Fado places are found! When in Lisbon, Fado (dinner with live traditional music and singing) is a MUST!

Try it. You can go there have dinner drink some portuguese wine, and after that at 12Pm go out so some house of fado or if you are more adventurous you can go to bar scenne, open till 3 pm with a lot of young people, drink one 2 3 caipirinhas or something like beer, and when you go hope i hope you still remembering everything ;)
Colorful and Busy. This area was full of fun restaurants, shops and plazas with beautiful flowers planted for color. We enjoyed walking in this sunny area and seeing Lisbon. Very enjoyable!

Loved it!. We went there at night to a Fado restaurant & loved the area. Unfortunately we didn't have time to stroll by for a long time & wish we were told that it was worth some time to enjoy a great walk. The view is wonderful from up there. There were people all around the place, with small crowds of young people around every bar/small resaturant. Overall, I think this is the place you want to go to at night for a little fun!

Mandatory for a night out!. This neighbourhood is THE place to go. Avoid Fridays and Saturdays or you won't be able to walk through the crowd. You can drink outside everywhere. All kinds of people.Try also the Bica area if it gets too crowded.
Very lively at night. We went up and down Barrio Alto during our sightseeing of Lisbon . The neighbourhood really come alive at night with many restaurant and bar all over.

Came alive at night!. This area is where alot of the young Portugese go on Saturday nights. As well as young bars there are lots of traditional Fado clubs/restaurants. I believe that this is an area of controlled prostitution.
The old feel. Its is nice to stroll in these little streets, unfortunately the nights in the weekends attract some minor figurs selling dope and stuff, wich gives you that uncomfy feel.

loved the area!!. full of old Lisbon colours...we walked this area so many times and we loved it more and more,full of bars and young people,good prices for the drinks...one of the most alive areas in europe!!!you have to try it!!!
Bairro Alto is the place to go at night!. Amazing place at night, fun to walk during the day. Bairro Alto is totally different in the day and in the night.Just go!

Bars, restaurants, tascas and people. Lots of bars, lots of tascas, lots of restaurants, lots of people. Great atmosphere both in the many establishments and outside, where invariably you'll find most people. If you intend to go out at night, definitely go here.
life for movida. young people quarter, full of strangers and typical restaurants, wine bar and pubs. unforgettable
enjoy!!!!!!!!!!!. lots of things to see and do, good places to eat, relax and simply enjoy the saty
New Year in Lisboa. It still attracts us allthough we've been there so many times.

Cool but dangerours. Narrow streets and crowds define what Bairro Alto is. There are lots of bars and restaurants (and some of them pretty cool), but I cannot say it is a safe place to be. Lots of drug dealers especially
A must in Lisboa. The most eclectic place in Lisbon, for Shop by day or dinner and grab a drink by night
Good nightlife. Normal backpacking neighborhood. Be careful. The bars and club scene is great, but there are frequent fights on the weekends.

Wander the Streets and Enjoy. Bairro Alto is a neighborhood simply to wander around and get lost. There are parks, cafes and outstanding old stairs aplenty. Jump into a game of dominos with the old men in the park or grab an espresso and people watch at the cafe!

This is where it happens.. This is the place to be for expats and trendy Portuguese. All kind of shops and restaurants. The downside is the people trying to usher you in their restaurant. Too many tourists apparently, although it was a quite night when I walked through the neighborhood. I did find a cheap and authentic restaurant in one of the steep winding streets.

have a coffee with Fernando. In the Chiado square ..outside a cafe you will find a statue of Fernando Pessoa ..one of Portugals most famous poets.. I love going there , sitting amongst the locals especially on a warm day in march or october ...when it's a little quieter ...enjoy
Nightlife. Lovely bars and restaurants on Rue Norte particularly

Fun and a bit of a booze up!. Didnt visit in the day, but came twice in the evening and it is bustling to say the least! Its just a road full of bars and they are all friendly and really quite cheap. Its not going to be a place to get nice cocktails or enjoy a quick one- this is the place to start a bar crawl! I went with a group of friends I met at my hostel and we had a whale of a time. Would recommend it.
Why is so famous. Sorry but our opinion about this area wasn't the best. We liked Lisbon but avoid bairro alto. Go to expo or belem

A contrarian view. I live in Chiado, 2 minutes away from Bairro Alto where I go twice a week to listen to Fado at the Tasca do Chico (highly recommended). Otherwise I would go to Bairro Alto if I wanted to:Buy drugsGet drunk (a beer costs around one euro)Get laidSmell urine at every corner (Portuguese guys like to use the streets as bathrooms)See streets full of garbage and broken bottlesEat horrible food (there are a few exceptions such as Papa Açorda)Have my wallet pick-pocketedWatch lots and lots of drunken teenagers (drinking age is 16 and nobody checks ID´s)I am not being too critical, just telling the truth from a non-tourist point of view.
Really lovely. Very omportat to be visited and know the calmness of the day and the absolute life of the night. The narrow streets and houses, very local colour, different in a way.
Interesting. Great place to stroll and take in the taste of Lisbon. Quaint shops and eateries lining elegant and historical twisting streets that give Lisbon its essence.

My favorite 'barrio'. We celebrated New Year at Praca do Commercio and then headed to Bairro Alto. The streets were full of bars and people celebrating. The atmosphere was contagious! Even though it was New Year's Eve and people were a bit more 'cheerful' than usual, one felt safe, nobody was violent, there were no firecrackers or other safety threats. I must give my thumbs up to Lisboa police as they organized surveillance at every city corner just to be on the safe side. Can't wait to go again!!

Funky, old part of town. Being of an age where finding an ad hoc party is no longer an aim in life, I cannot comment on the partying qualites of this area, but it is certainly worth a visit or two. It is most easily reached by riding the Elevador da Gloria which starts/ends just off the bottom/southern end of Avenida da Liberdade. If you've any sense you'll already have purchased a Lisbon Card and so ride for free. At the top turn right and enjoy the views from the small park across towards the Castelo S.Jorge. If you turn left you have a good downhill route to the Chiado. Barrio Alto is a pleasant area to walk around and explore with various restaurants although we didn't try any of them.
Nice streets. Full of people and shops, restaurants and tourists!

portuguese tiles, flowers and great food. Try the SINAL restaurante on rua das gaveas. Varied and tasty menu, helpful and friendly staff. Delicious food and atmosphere. Love it here and it has become one of my favorites in all of Lisbon.

The PLACE to hang out. If you're looking for a genuinely good time in Lisbon, forget Alcantara. Bairro alto is the place to be every night of the week. There is always some eclectic group hanging out here ready to invite you to their party. Some of the most genuinely friendly people hang out here and you will be wanting to go back by the time you're meant to leave.

Nightlife. Plenty of bars and clubs. I went there on Monday and Tuesday and didn't have much luck as most of the bars/clubs were empty. It was kind of sad, perhaps the economy is not affecting this nice area of the city. I love the street paved in stones and lots of people walking.You can take the subway to Baixa Chiado station and walk from there.

fun to walk around, wish government jumped in to care for the buildings. We enjoyed our walk here, with a number of small restaurants and a wonderful atmosphere of night life. The warmth of Portuguese people and the authenticity of the buildings were just what we were looking for.

Yet another wonderful-to-wander Lisboa neighborhood. Great architecture, waiting to be restored. Much of it waiting since the 1700s, which makes for a shabby chic ambience. Enjoyed a super meal at Cervejaria Trinidade (former convent, incredible tilework) which is open on Sunday night too (hard to find, many are closed). Locate the way-up-high view park/terrace (called Mirador, something like that) and walk down from there. Around every corner you'll find something interesting and charming. That Junta elevator gets you halfway up, a good way to start.
Good views and nice little haunts. You have to visit the Bario Alto when in Lisbon. It has a plethora of restaurants to choose from, at every level.

Nice architecture, nice bars. Bairro Alto is the postcard of Lisbon city. Here you find beautiful buidings from churches, squares and the houses itself. Nice to enjoy a walk thru this neighbourhood and pick a cosy restaurant to eat and have fun.Unfortunately I didn't try the nightlife here... yet.

Wonderful local people serving up great food and a wonderful time!. Great local color. Delicious food, inexpensive, intimate restaurants with wonderful seafood, chicken, fried potatoes, vino and great local pastries (everywhere). Lot's of good local shopping and lot's of fun loving people everywhere you go.
This area. Great atmosphere, an abundance of good restaurants ( we tried two but only there for two days) Really helpfull staff in restaurants , courteous and friendly
Head here in the evening. Best place for restaurants and bars by far and the elevador is an experience in itself.

Full of contradictions. We walked through the Barrio Alto for about an hour on a Saturday afternoon, literally trying to find the Barrio Alto! It was so quiet that we thought we'd accidentally stumbled upon a very quaint residential area. Six hours later, the whole district was heaving with young people drinking, smoking and being merry as hundreds of bars opened out of nowhere - spilling out onto the streets with people and music... Great fun at night if you're a student or in the mood for a big night out but not the place to go for a quiet, sophisticated glass of wine (and be warned - the Barrio Alto bars have certainly NOT imposed the smoking ban!)
Great restaurants and nightlife. Enjoyed going to Barrio Alto for dinner and shopping in the evenings.

Oh! what a night (s). A trip like no other as the sights, sounds, flavours and feeling of Lisbon comes alive , Barrio Alto is the soul of Lisbon. When you research the area you can feel it maybe a little rough but this is far from the truth. It is the heart beat of the nightlife, there are other places to have a drink but the Barrio makes you friends, give you the experience and new bars open to give us all more variety.Strolling the cobbled street is only done in hard shoes never heels unless you are not drinking. As for the wonderful array of cocktails at only £2.00 - 4.00 for a very strong double shot. The crowds are friendly, the music is alittle dated but loud, and the atmosphere is vibrant. A must if you want to know Lisbon.
Dangerous at nigth. My wifes handbag was stolen at nigth after leaving a restaurnat in the area. Don't go at nigth at least with values with you
Beautiful place. Bairro Alto e great at any time of the day. You can find several nice restaurants, bars, art galleries, gifts shops, etc... It is really a pleasure to stroll around.

A great homebase for solo travelers. This was the place that I gravitated towards during my 4 days in Lisbon. It´s young, vibrant and if you want to engage with lcoals at night this is the place to start off. The party floods into the streets by 11 at night and its more festive than it is a drunken party scene.I made a few friends over beers and they invited me to the beach with them the next day. The Portuguese are very warm and friendly and excited to share their lives with others. I will be returning to Lisbon and cannot wait to reconnect with the people and places I discovered.
Great Place to Eat and Drink. Went in summer and everyone out in streets drinking from bar to bar and nice little reastaurants place to go in Lisbon.

Good place if you know where you are going. It's a charming hilly location full of bars and restaurants. But you must know where to go and what to eat as you could easily end up eating crap for a terrible touristic price
Excellent night spot. A little but studenty, but full of life and energy.
A lot of shops. Close to Chiado , Marqueze de Pombal scquare , walk and enjoy the shops and restaurants. You need 2 days to see all the downtown ( Chiado , etc
Nightlife!. Don't bother heading to the bars in Bairro Alto until at least midnight, but then you can mingle with the locals and other travellers and party in the streets!

Bit quiet by day, comes alive at night. Catch the Elevador da Gloria from opposite the Hard Rock Cafe, close to the Restauardores Metro station, for a quick ascent up an extremely steep street to the top, once on top you are rewarded with an exceptional view of the city, well worth the journey for this alone, the No. 28 Tram also stops here too.The area itself is quiet during the day, but comes alive at night with most bars playing the local Fado music.
cafe atmosphere. As with all areas of Lisbon there are always museums to be found, but equally the streets are fascinating.

Fado, etc.. An amazing place to explore at night, where you can stumble upon some amazing architecture, see the nightlife, and most importantly for us, experience true Fado in some amazing environments. We went to Cafe Luso, and it was INCREDIBLE. I will never forget that dinner for as long as I live- the food and the Fado was amazing.
night life. Great place to hang out at night. You'll find restaurantes, bars and clubs but ths best is to hang out in the streets.

Party Central. Booked this apartment on www.homeaway.co.uk3 adults, 460 euros for 7 nights. The apartment was wonderful, modern and clean but ..... we hadn't done the research about the area and it turned out that the bars become lively from 10pm onwards through till 6am most nights!Admittedly we stayed during student thresher week .... bad timing because the noise in the narrow cobbled streets was incredible, shouting, singing, music, laughing etc. then at 7am an army of refuse collectors march through sweeping up bottles, broken glass and hosing down the cobbles.On the Tuesday night we went down about 3am and got involved, the bars were packed out, the narrow streets rammed with people drinking and every street seemed to have music coming from somewhere.Apart from getting back to the UK quite tired this was a great holiday, our friends were lucky to book their apartment a little set back off the main streets and in hindsight..... we'd definitely do this if we went back.

The heart of nightlife. Bairro Alto is the heart of nightlife. Many good restaurants, many nice bars, thousands of people friday and saturday night in the streets talking and drinking.However all of this drinking has taken its toll and the place can be quite dirty and unapealling.

amazing place to hang out. we returned to this area every evening and spent time exploring the narrow lanes and shops. loads of eating places here from irish pubs to chinese sit down joints. A great place for picking up ceramic tiles and handicraft.
open ears and eyes. artists shops, strange people, this part of Lisbonne is full of life.

Unique. These is a unique place in Portugal. A block of bars and restaurants in a old neighborhood, if you go early you can have dinner quietly, after 10pm to 2am the streets get full of people coming to the bars. They are very small places so they pick the drinks and come to the street. The drinks are quite cheap.Here you'll find all kind of people: young people completely drunk, older people, well dressed, hippies, people selling weed, students, locals and turists.If you are going to dinner I recommend Sinal Vermelho, Bota Alta, (portuguese food) Stravaganzza (Italian) Bubbly (champagnerie).There are a jazz bar: Páginas TantasBest Mojito: Clube da Esquina (ask for a glass not plastic cup, it will taste better).
A terrible area in Lisbon. We didn't like, and we didn't feel safe in this area, Chiado, belem and oriente are much better
Lots of good restaurants around this area. Good places to eat.. lots of little alleyways to explore!
One of the most pleasant area. In the heart of Lisboa, one of the most friendly area

The place was pumping!. Had dinner at Trinidade (find it - it's fantastic) on the Friday night (end of conference) then just wandered from tiny bar to tiny bar. In the end there were thousands completely blocking the laneways, but always allowed the occasional unfortunate taxi to pass through. The best part was - 3:00am and had not seen one sign of violence or anger. A real credit to the locals. A very memorable experience!!
great restaurants. Full of business people and classy restaurants but not at classy prices - good value

During the night. Oldest part of Lisbon. The experience of walking past century (or more) old buildings during the night is really a goosebump experience. Very very good place for night time photography of the old town.

Food, food and bars.. An excellent place to spend a few nights out with loads of restaurants from cheap to posh, loads of good live music and nearly everyone is very friendly. Avoid the more touristy restaurants and go for the small quirky ones - the food is better and cheaper.
PARTY!1. What an awesome phenomenon. People partying in the street, different music loads of bars, if you're up for a full night if partying, this is the place to go!

Touristy? Heck yes and no!. Half the reataurants on the way to Barrio Alto tell you, don't go there, its 'Touristy'.If Touristy is good restaurants, a real buzz from lots of tourists AND locals, and music abounding from bars etc..then yes it is.
The best place to eat and have fun. Many restaurants and bars,locals and tourists,fado shows.
Lots to see. Liked it all, especially at night. Just beware of pickpockets
diner and fado !. cross the avenida and take the yellow tram to the uptown in 10 minutes. Nice tipical restaurants with fado perfomance.

The night life is here too. Alfama, Bairro Alto, Baixa are the places situated in the old part of the Lisbon. In them you can taste the portuguese wine, the portuguese food and of course to hear the amazing portuguese music - fado and guitarra portuguesa.
wonderful spot. That's were we stayed and shopped. It is a designers paradise, if your body is designed for the cat walk. But it is fun to look!
Very unsafe. At nigth was very unsafe, don't go at nigth, special at weekends. During the day we prefer chiado

Beautiful stroll. We got a guide book that included walks through the different Lisbon neighborhoods. There were so many different architectural things to see in Bairro Alto. It made for a lovely and relaxing afternoon walk.
lively area. lots of choice for bars and restaurants plesant walk from hotel

A Night-time must see. We were fortunate to stay 3 nights in Bairro Alto and loved it. The atmosphere of the cobbled streets and old buildings was unforgettable and, although quiet and deserted by day, was transformed into a different place by night full of excellent restaurants and bars.Despite what other correspondents have said, we never felt threatened nor felt anxious in the area and recommend a visit when in Lisbon.
Fun night out. Well, fun 3 nights out. Cocktails aplenty. Great atmosphere.

fantastic night out. cheap drinks,great atmosphere. ii went here on my last night in lisbon, absolutley loved it, it caters to all ages, im 45 and went with my 6 nieces and nephews, all aged under 35. wished i had gone a few times before i left, would definitley recommend it to anyone who likes a good fun filled night out. the streets do get very crowded and you have to squeeze through, so i suggest if your with a group select a meeting point because you can get separated very easily or just hold hands and create a chain, thats what we did. its lively and there is not one bar the same as another. you come out of one and literally 2 to 3 foot across the cobbled streets your in another. brilliant, i loved every minute of it. LADIES.... wear comfortable shoes as there are alot of steep streets and as you will already know they are cobbled.

Like the Vegas strip or Bourbon St. Cheap drinks that you take out of the bar and drink in the street. No place to sit really, except inside the hot/stuffy bars. Live music in some palces, DJs in others. You will be offered drugs - coke, weed, hash. Just say no thanks if you aren't interested.A must visit if you are between 18 and 40 yrs - probably not so much for older folks.

Interesting area, but doesn't feel safe at night. We had dinner at a couple restaurants in this area during our recent stay. We walked to one as it was not very far into the Bairro Alto area, but took a cab to and from the other which was in the heart of this district. Aside from the walking challenges (very steep with sidewalks that sometimes disappear) the whole vibe at night is a bit sketchy. Many nightclubs and Fado music places in this area which seemed like they might be fun, but after dark it is a bit creepy.

Great, just ignore the drug dealers. Just wanted to post for anyone thinking of going there with older or younger relatives for a meal in the evening. The area seems safe, but like much of Lisbon, you will be offered drugs by quite normal-looking people in the street, and it's weird.

Lovely place. Bairro Alto is very charming with its narrow cobblestone streets. The best time to visit is night time when the streets filled with locals, the only day we did not see a ton of people there was on Sundays. It has tiny bars where you grab your drink and go to the street to socialize. I has something for every taste, although mostly lovely holes in the wall, it also has some more upscale bars as well as wine bars. We also ate at a lovely restaurant, delicious traditional Portuguese food and listen to some wonderful Fado. It is a relaxed place so most people are wearing jeans and flats with a cute top, and men wear jeans and t-shirts, some shirts here and there but definitely informal.We felt safe at ALL times, not only in Bairro Alto but in Lisbon in general and we were out until 3-4 AM every night.

Really charming. Bairro Alto is a really charming place. It has beautiful narrow streets, where you can get lost and walk admiring the buildings. There are also a lot of bars there. It is worth going there during the night, even during the week, as there is a wonderfull atmosphere. All the bars are open, and people are standing outside them drinkling, chatting and dancing. Everyone is very friendly.

Make sure to visit it in the night-time. Great atmosphere & nice restaurants. It's definately the thing to experience in Lisbon: having a glass on vino verde on the outside table of one of the small bars and enjoying the warm evening.

Go there if you are a teenager and want to pass all night on beer. Go there if you are a teenager and want to pass all night on beer. This is a place to avoid after hours. Lots of people drinking and smoking on the street, litter, touristic restaurants and bars.Visit this place during day if you want, but there is not much to see anyway. This is really a night spot, and in my opinion, a tourist trap

One unique place to go out and feel the real Lisbon spirit. I've lived for 10years in Lisbon and what I miss most besides the food is Bairro Alto. Definetly is "the Place" to go out. Whether for dinner in one of the typical and inexpensive Tascas (Adega Dantas - great food) or the fancy Pap'Acorda. In any case the night starts late (dinner never before 21h and going out never before 23:30). Then diversity is the right word, whether you go to a Fado house or to grab a beer and stay at the street, a lot of fun is assured.

Fair skinned equals local opportunity. What charm this area could have is soon lost by the overwhelming feeling that your being taken for a ride by almost every barman in town. Only after meeting other tourists on a night out did we actually realise how much more we are charged compared to the locals, don't be afraid to haggle on the price of drinks as they strangely come down depending on how much Portuguese you can speak and your willingness to argue, also don't under any circumstances eat in Bairro Alto as this is a MISTAKE! The place is filthy, very overpriced, stinks to high heaven and bloody dangerous as hygiene simply isn't a concept that's understood.

Fun place in Lisbon. We walked up to Barrio Alto a couple times but the easiest way is to take the short tram ride near Restaurdores metro station. At the top, turn left & squeeze down the little sidewalk for a couple blocks. Then to your right you'll find the little streets of Barrio Alto. With lots of restaurants, shops & bars, you're sure to find some place you'll like. We enjoyed having a drink outside at a restaurant on a small side alley with a guy that played some nice Brazilian music on his guitar.

My favorite place in the world!. The Bairro Alto comes alive as the sun sets in Lisbon. The many wonderful, small and intimate restaurants begin to open around 8:00 p.m. Many of the restaurants can only seat 10 or 12 couples, and some, even less. The food is spectacular. Having been to many of the restaurants, none of them have been a disappointment. There are many Fado clubs there that are very commercial. We were fortunate enough to find one that is strictly for locals who get up and take turns at the microphone. There is nothing like a cover charge, and seating is first come, first serve. Drink prices are beyond cheap. There are perhaps 8 tables similar to a picnic table, only smaller. In order to get a decent seat, arrive no later than 7:00 p.m. and don't leave your seat! We were very fortunate to meet someone who lives in Lisbon, and is a regular at the club. He was kind enough to hold our seats for us while we had dinner. Actually, he did that for us on our many trips to Lisbon. The most phenomenal singers in the world. Even though neither my husband nor I speak Portuguese, we were brought to tears many times at the sheer emotion that surfaces when one of those very gifted people stand up to sing. They are not professionals, they range in age from 12 to 90, all have "day jobs" and share the emotion of the history of their country and the difficult and sad times when sailors left their families and loved ones to find a means of support for their families. Songs that are passed down from generation to generation and sung with all the feelings that are deep in the souls of the Portuguese. These people were poverty-poor, and losing the breadwinner in the home as well as the strong and undying loves of their lives., they developed this marvelous way of expressing their feelings through song. Amalia Rodriguez is a legend among Fado singers and although she has passed on, she is revered in Portugal. I'm hesitant to give the name of the club, because i would hate for it to become too commercial. On the other hand, I want everyone to experience an evening at Tasco do Chico. They don't start singing until at least 11:00 p.m. and usually end somewhere around 4:00 a.m. so be prepared for a late night experience that you will never forget.

A must in Lisbon. If you ever go to Lisbon, you must go to Bairro Alto, the place is full of design stores, bars and nightlife. Also you will find the first open air museum of street art. Is called Museu Efemero and is sponsored by PAMPERO FUNDACION. You can download the podcast, the map, and go to with your mp3 player on the galeries of this museum: The streets. Then you can learn more about the artists and their artwors and have a hole museum expierence, but on the street. Among the artworks you will find great stecils form DOLK, EIME, POBEL, MIR, BITMAP. Learn more about it at museuefemero.blogspot.com

Bairro Alto, Cool, Young and Energetic. Bairro Alto was our cool shopping spot during the day with numerous, tiny fashion forward boutiques that are dotted along the narrow streets. By night, my friend and I circled the same areas that had now turned into crowded, fun, and lively bars that were bursting with people hanging out and people watching. I recommend this area and will go back soon.
